3-9-1: DEFINITION:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the words "alcoholic liquor", as used in
this chapter, shall include alcohol, spirits, wine and beer and shall mean
every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or
beer and capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being. (Ord. 845,
10-12-2015)
3-9-2: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any merchant, either by himself or his agent, or any
person acting as an agent, barkeeper, clerk or servant of another, to sell,
offer for sale, give away or otherwise dispense in the city any alcoholic
liquor without first having obtained a license to do so as provided herein. It
shall likewise be unlawful for any such merchant to sell, offer for sale, give
away or otherwise dispense any intoxicating liquors or alcoholic or malt or
vinaceous liquors in violation of the terms and conditions of such license.
(Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-3: INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
No license authorized by this chapter shall be issued to:
   A.   A person not of legal age or under any legal disability.
   B.   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community
in which he resides.
   C.   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   D.   A person who has been convicted of a felony under any federal or state
law, if the mayor determines, after investigation, that such person has not
been sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust.
   E.   A person who has been convicted of keeping a place of prostitution or
keeping a place of juvenile prostitution, promoting prostitution that involves
keeping a place of prostitution, or promoting juvenile prostitution that
involves keeping a place of juvenile prostitution.
   F.   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
   G.   A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for
cause.
   H.   A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued under this chapter, would not be eligible for such renewal upon a first
application.
   I.   A copartnership, if any general partnership thereof, or any limited
partnership thereof, owning more than five percent (5%) of the aggregate
limited partner interest in such copartnership would not be eligible to receive
a license hereunder for any reason.
   J.   A corporation or limited liability company, if any member, officer,
manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the
aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, would
not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than
citizenship and residency within the city.
   K.   A corporation or limited liability company unless it is incorporated or
organized in Illinois, or unless it is a foreign corporation or foreign limited
liability company which is qualified under the business corporation act of 1983
or the limited liability company act to transact business in Illinois. The city
shall permit and accept from an applicant for a license under this chapter
proof prepared from the secretary of state's website that the corporation or
limited liability company is in good standing and is qualified under the
business corporation act of 1983 or the limited liability company act to
transact business in Illinois.
   L.   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless such manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
   M.   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, or
shall have forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such
violation.
   N.   A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a license
is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the
license is to be issued.
   O.   Any law enforcing public official, the mayor or member of the city
council, and no such official shall be interested in any way, either directly
or indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquors.
   P.   Any person not eligible for a state retail liquor dealer's license.
   Q.   A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated
by the licensee.
   R.   An adult use or a business located in the same building as an adult
use. The following definitions apply to this subsection:
ADULT BOOKSTORE: An establishment having, as a substantial portion of its stock
in trade, books, magazines, films, records, recording tapes, videotapes, or
other periodicals for sale or for viewing, either on or off the premises, which
are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting,
describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical
areas.
ADULT DEVICE STORE: An establishment having, as a substantial portion of its
stock in trade, any device, appliance, instrument or object which is
represented either by the operator of the establishment or by its packaging,
advertising or other literature furnished therewith as enhancing, assisting,
representing, depicting or relating to specified sexual activities or specified
anatomical areas, or an establishment with a segment or section devoted to the
sale or display of such material.
ADULT ENTERTAINMENT CABARET: A public or private establishment which is
licensed to serve food and/or alcoholic beverages and which features
entertainers, dancers, waitresses, waiters or any other employees acting in
such a way as to display, depict, describe or relate to specified sexual
activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein.
ADULT MINI-MOTION PICTURE THEATER: An enclosed building or drive-in theater
with a capacity for less than fifty (50) persons used for presenting material
distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing
or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for
observation by patrons therein.
ADULT MOTION PICTURE THEATER: An enclosed building or a drive-in theater with a
capacity of fifty (50) or more persons used regularly and routinely for
presenting motion pictures having as a dominant theme material distinguished or
characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to
specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by
patrons therein.
ADULT USE: An adult bookstore, an adult motion picture theater, an adult mini-
motion picture theater, an adult entertainment cabaret, a massage
establishment, a body shop or model studio, an adult device store, or an
establishment that conducts a substantial portion of its business through some
combination of any of the foregoing adult uses.
BODY SHOP OR MODEL STUDIO: Any public or private establishment which describes
itself as a body shop or model studio, or where, for any form of consideration
or gratuity, figure models who display specified anatomical areas are provided
to be observed, sketched, drawn, painted, sculptured, photographed or similarly
depicted by persons paying such consideration or gratuity, or where, for any
form of consideration or gratuity, nude or seminude dancing, readings,
counseling sessions, body painting and other activities that present materials
distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing
or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas are
provided for observation by or communication to persons paying such
consideration or gratuity.
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT: An establishment having a fixed place of business where
any person, firm, association or corporation engages in or carries on, or
permits to be engaged in or carried on, any of the activities mentioned in the
definition of "massage" in this definition; provided, however, that the term
massage establishment shall not apply to hospitals, physical rehabilitation
centers, nursing homes or sanatoriums. The term massage establishment shall
also not apply to a spa, salon, barbershop, or other establishment focused on
grooming wherein a massage is given by a cosmetologist, barber or masseuse
licensed by the state of Illinois in accordance with such license; and
provided, that such establishment does not permit anyone or anything to display
or depict specified anatomical areas and does not permit anyone or anything to
engage, display, or depict specified sexual activity. For purposes of this
definition, a "massage" means any method of pressure on or friction against or
stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating or stimulating of the
external soft parts of the body with the hands or other parts of the human body
or with the aid of any mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance with or
without such supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptics,
oils, powder, creams, lotions, ointments or other similar preparations commonly
used in this practice.
NUDITY: The showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, or
buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering; the showing of the female
breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any part of the nipple; or the
showing of the covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state.
SPECIFIED ANATOMICAL AREAS: Any of the following conditions:
      1.   Less than completely and opaquely covered:
           a. Human genitals, pubic region or pubic hair; or
           b. Buttock; or
           c. Female breast below a point immediately above the top of the
areola; and
      2.   Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if
completely covered.
SPECIFIED SEXUAL ACTIVITIES: Any of the following conditions:
      1.   The performance of acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse,
masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, or flagellation, in addition
to any sexual acts which are prohibited by law.
      2.   The actual or simulated touching, caressing or fondling of the
breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals.
      3.   The actual or simulated display of the breasts, buttocks, pubic
hair, anus, vulva or genitals.
      4.   Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any activities
otherwise set forth in this definition.
   S.   A person who has been convicted of a gambling offense as proscribed by
any of subsections (a)(3) through (a)(11) of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
28-1, or as proscribed by 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-1.1 or 5/28-3, or
as proscribed by a statute replaced by any of the aforesaid statutory
provisions.
   T.   A person or entity to whom a federal wagering stamp has been issued by
the federal government, unless the person or entity is eligible to be issued a
license under the raffles act or the Illinois pull tabs and jar games act.
   U.   A person who intends to sell alcoholic liquors for use or consumption
on his or her licensed retail premises who does not have liquor liability
insurance coverage for that premises in an amount that is at least equal to the
maximum liability amounts set out in 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-21,
subsection (a). (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
All applications for the license required herein shall be made in writing to
the mayor, or to the party designated by him, signed by the applicant if an
individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof if a corporation, association
or partnership, verified by affidavit, and shall be submitted and filed with
the mayor at least fifteen (15) days prior to the issuance of any license, and
shall contain the following information and statements:
   A.   Name, Age And Address: The name, age and address of the applicant in
the case of an individual; in the case of a copartnership or association, names
and addresses of the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; and in
the case of a corporation for profit, the date and state of incorporation, the
date of qualification to do business in Illinois (if not an Illinois
corporation), the object for which it was organized, the names and addresses of
the officers, directors and managers, and also the names and addresses of every
stockholder owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock of
the corporation.
   B.   Citizenship: The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and
if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
   C.   Character And Object Of Business: The character of the business of the
applicant, and in the case of a corporation, the objects for which it was
formed.
   D.   Length Of Time In Business: The length of time the applicant has been
in business of that character, or in the case of a corporation, the date on
which its charter was issued.
   E.   Amount Of Goods On Hand: The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on
hand at the time the application is made.
   F.   Location And Description: The location and description of the premises
or place of business which is to be operated under the license.
   G.   Disposition Of Other Applications: A statement whether the applicant
has made similar application for a license on premises other than described in
this application, and the disposition of such application.
   H.   Former Conviction Of Felony: A statement that the applicant has never
been convicted of a felony, and is not disqualified to receive a license by
reason of any matter or thing contained in this chapter, the laws of the state
or other ordinances of the city.
   I.   Suspension Or Revocation Of Previous Licenses: Whether a previous
license by any state or subdivision thereof or by the federal government has
been revoked and the reasons therefor.
   J.   Agreement Not To Violate Regulations: A statement that the applicant
will not violate any of the laws of the state or of the United States, or any
ordinance of the city in the conduct of his place of business.
   K.   Ownership Or Lease Of Premises: A statement that the applicant either
owns the premises for which the license is sought or that he has a lease
thereon for the full period for which the license is to be issued. In the case
of a lease, a copy of same shall be submitted with the application.
   L.   Ownership Of Business: A statement that the applicant is a beneficial
owner of the business to be operated by the licensee.
   M.   Not A Law Enforcing Official: A statement that the applicant is not a
law enforcing public official. (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-5: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Each and every applicant for a license under this chapter shall simultaneously,
with the application therefor and prior to the issuance thereof, execute and
deliver a bond in the penal sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to the City
as obligee, conditioned for the faithful performance of the provisions of this
chapter and of the laws of the State relating to the sale of alcoholic liquor,
and the payment of all security to be approved by the Mayor or such other
persons delegated by him to approve the same. The maximum liability of any and
all securities on such bond shall be limited to five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-6: CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES:
Licenses to sell alcoholic liquor at retail are divided into the following
classes:
   A.   Class A: Class A licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor in packages and not for consumption on the premises where sold.
   B.   Class B: Class B licenses shall authorize the retail sale on the
premises of alcoholic liquor in packages and also for consumption on the
premises where sold.
   C.   Class C: Class C licenses shall authorize the retail sale on the
premises of alcoholic liquor, only for consumption on the premises where sold,
and not in packages. Also, at least sixty percent (60%) of the gross revenues
of a Class C license must be represented by food sales (including sales of
nonalcoholic beverages). An applicant for a Class C license must certify that
this food requirement will be met every calendar quarter of operation. The
holder of a Class C license must provide suitable documentation to the Mayor,
as often as he may reasonably require, to prove that this food requirement has
been met every calendar quarter of operation.
   D.   Class D: Class D licenses shall be issued only to "convenience stores",
which are defined as stores engaging in the retail sale of products customarily
found as part of product sales from grocery, drug (excluding prescriptions) and
hardware stores, and which may or may not also be part of a fuel station that
sells gasoline and other petroleum products. Class D licenses shall authorize
the retail sale on the premises of alcoholic liquor, only in packages, and not
for consumption on the premises, and subject to the further condition that
there be no sales of beer in single, separately sold cans, bottles or other
drinking containers and no sale of other alcoholic liquor in miniature bottles
(those containing 50 milliliters or less). Also, no more than thirty percent
(30%) of the gross revenues of a Class D license (or 30 percent of the gross
revenues represented by inside sales, if the convenience store is also part of
a fuel station) shall be represented by sales of alcoholic liquor. An applicant
for a Class D license must certify that this limitation will be met every
calendar quarter of operation. The holder of a Class D license must provide
suitable documentation to the Mayor, as often as he may reasonably require, to
prove that this beer and wine sale limitation has been met every calendar
quarter of operation.
   E.   Class E: Class E licenses, also known as special use permit licenses,
are largely patterned after licenses of the same name as described in the
Liquor Control Act of 1934. Only a holder of a Class B or C license is eligible
to apply for a Class E license. A Class E license shall allow the holder to
transfer a portion of its alcoholic liquor inventory from its licensed premises
(i.e., the premises for which the Class B or C license was issued) to a single
premises specified in the Class E license, and to sell or offer for sale the
transferred alcoholic liquor inventory at retail only on the specified
premises, only for consumption on the specified premises, and not for resale in
any form. The specified premises need not be licensed premises under this
chapter. A Class E license shall be used only in instances where the sale or
offer for sale of the transferred alcoholic liquor inventory is incidental to a
specific event on the specified premises, where food is offered for
consumption. A Class E license shall allow the holder to provide the services
described herein at the specific event and at the specified premises described
in the application. A Class E license shall be granted to license holder no
more than three (3) times per calendar year for a specified location. At least
fifteen (15) days before the start of each specific event at which a Class E
license will be used, the holder of the license shall give notice to the Mayor
of the date and hours of the event. An application for a Class E license shall
identify the holder of the existing Class B or C license and identify the
premises at which the Class E license will be used. Otherwise, except as
provided herein, a holder of a Class E license shall abide by all provisions of
this chapter. Moreover, a violation of any provision of this chapter with
respect to the use of a Class E license shall subject the holder to potential
discipline not only for that license, but also for the Class B or C license
that was a precondition for applying for the Class E license.
The application and license shall be further subject to the following
conditions:
      1.   All entrances to the specified premises shall be attended at all
times. At least one emergency exit shall be provided.
      2.   Adequate measures shall be taken to prevent the removal of alcoholic
liquor from the specified premises and to constrict noise to the appropriate
area.
      3.   The time period for which a Class E license is issued shall not
exceed the lesser of: a) the duration of the special event, or b) three (3)
days; provided, however, that the Liquor Commissioner may further limit the
hours of operation of the special event as the Liquor Commissioner deems
necessary or desirable.
      4.   The applicant shall present to the City proof of liability and
dramshop insurance, thereby relieving the City from any and all liability. Such
insurance shall be issued by a reputable insurance company doing business in
the State of Illinois and naming the City as an additional insured. A copy of
the proof of insurance shall be presented to the City Clerk at least fifteen
(15) days prior to the scheduled event.
      5.   The applicant shall present to the City a security plan outlining
the security arrangements for the special event, which shall be subject to
approval by the Liquor Commissioner.
   F.   Class F: Class F licenses shall authorize the sale and service of
alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises of a banquet facility only as
an incidental part of food service pursuant to a contract or agreement to cater
a private function in the banquet facility. For purposes of this section, a
"banquet facility" means a place available for rental by the general public
designed to accommodate a minimum of one hundred (100) persons safely and in
compliance with the local Fire Code. The business operating from such a place
is typified by functions such as wedding celebrations or other prearranged
private parties, functions, or events for a specific social or business
occasion, either by invitation or reservation, and not open to the general
public.
   G.   Class G: Class G licenses shall authorize the sale and service of
alcoholic liquors for consumption in a patio dining area on the following terms
and conditions:
      1.   "Patio dining area" means an area located directly adjacent to and
contiguous to an existing licensed facility and generally open and subject to
the direct influence of the outdoor environment which has been established in
accordance with this section.
      2.   Only the current holder of a Class B license or a Class C license
under this section may apply for and receive a license to establish and operate
a patio dining area which must be located immediately adjacent to a totally
enclosed permanent structure which is the site of a dramshop lawfully operating
under any such liquor license. In addition, at least thirty percent (30%) of
the combined gross revenues of a Class B and Class G license and sixty percent
(60%) of the combined gross revenues of a Class C and Class G license must be
represented by food sales (including sales of nonalcoholic beverages). An
applicant for a Class G license must certify that this food requirement will be
met every calendar quarter of operation. The holder of a Class G license must
provide suitable documentation to the Mayor, as often as he may reasonably
require, to prove that this food requirement has been met every calendar
quarter of operation.
      3.   All applicants for a license to operate a patio dining area shall
submit to the Mayor a written application which accurately and completely
describes the proposed patio dining area, its proposed hours of operation and
any other pertinent information, along with scaled plans, specifications and
drawings which demonstrate that the proposed patio dining area will comply with
the terms and conditions of this section and with any other applicable
provisions of local, State or Federal law including, but not limited to, the
City zoning title.
      4.   The area of a patio dining area shall be considered to be a portion
of the immediately adjacent dramshop operated by the holder of the underlying
liquor license for purposes of establishing any applicable parking
requirements.
      5.   A patio dining area shall be constructed, maintained and operated in
accordance with the descriptions, conditions, plans, specifications and
drawings submitted with the application for the license to construct and
operate the patio dining area.
      6.   The patio dining area square footage shall not exceed the square
footage of that portion of the attached totally enclosed permanent structure
from which the holder of the underlying liquor license operates a dramshop. The
patio dining area appearance should be consistent with the character of the
existing structure. The patio dining area shall be constructed with a hard
floor surface, such as decking material, concrete, or paving brick.
      7.   Except for emergency entrances and exits which shall be used only in
the case of a bona fide emergency, no access to a patio dining area is allowed
except through that portion of the attached totally enclosed permanent
structure from which the holder of the underlying liquor license operates a
dramshop. The patio dining area shall not be accessible to any portion of any
building to which it is adjacent other than the building used as a location for
a dramshop by the holder of the underlying liquor license, nor shall a patio
dining area be located such that it is necessary for a patron to travel through
any portion of any other building to obtain ingress or egress.
      8.   A patio dining area shall be completely enclosed by an attractive
fence, wall or other similar barricade having a height of not less than four
feet (4') and which defines the seating area and sets that area apart from the
surrounding property.
      9.   No portion of any patio dining area may be located within two
hundred feet (200') of the lot line of any parcel zoned or used for residential
purposes.
      10.   No alcoholic beverages may be served or consumed within a patio
dining area except between the hours authorized for the sale of alcoholic
liquor as set forth in section
3-9-13 of this chapter. Except for employees of the licensed facility engaged
in employment related activities, no person shall be allowed in the patio
dining area other than during the hours specified in section
3-9-13 of this chapter.
      11.   The issuance of a Class G license shall not diminish the
responsibility of the license holder to comply with all applicable laws,
ordinances, rules, or regulations. Failure to comply shall be cause for
suspension or revocation of the Class G license.
      12.   A patio dining area shall not be occupied by any number of persons
in excess of the maximum established by any other applicable law or regulation
including, without limitation, the Building Code of the City.
      13.   A license authorizing the operation of a patio dining area does not
authorize the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages at any location other
than within the confines of the patio dining area or within the confines of the
attached totally enclosed permanent structure from the licensee operating the
qualifying liquor establishment.
      14.   It is unlawful for any person to transfer, pass or deliver
alcoholic beverages from a location within a patio dining area through or over
a fence, wall or other barricade to a person located outside of the patio
dining area. It is unlawful for any license holder or employee to permit any
person to transfer, pass or deliver alcoholic liquor from a location within a
patio dining area through or over a fence, wall or other barricade to a person
located outside of the patio dining area. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this
subsection G14 shall not prohibit any person from passing, delivering or
transferring alcoholic liquor between the patio dining area and the wholly
enclosed adjacent Class B or Class C licensed premises for which the Class G
license is issued.
   H.   Class H: Class H licenses shall be issued for special events to any
chartered, not for profit corporation, or any religious, political, charitable,
or other organization that can show tax exempt status and desires to sell
alcoholic beverages at a special event pursuant to the following criteria:
      1.   A Class H license shall entitle the licensee to sell alcoholic
beverages for consumption only on the premises and the dates listed in the
application. Such application shall include a scale drawing of the proposed
outdoor facility which shall, at a minimum, include the following:
         a.   A method by which the area shall be confined to prohibit the
removal of alcoholic beverages and constrict noise to the approved area; and
         b.   A reasonably substantial structure across which alcoholic
beverages shall be served which shall afford bartenders reasonable protection
from patrons; and
      2.   The duration of a Class H license shall be for a period of twenty
four (24) consecutive hours, but may be extended up to ninety six (96)
consecutive hours; and
      3.   The hours for the sale of alcoholic beverages with a Class H license
shall be seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.; and
      4.   During alcoholic beverage sales, the presence of a minimum of two
(2) police officers is required. For each hour the licensee offers alcoholic
beverages for sale, the licensee shall pay a fee of forty dollars ($40.00) per
hour for each police officer who is working at the special event.
      5.   Class H licensees shall have the appropriate State of Illinois
special event license pertaining to the same date and location as applied for
under this section of this Code. (Ord. 896, 8-12-2019)
3-9-7: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
One Class A license, one Class B license, one Class C license, one Class D
license, one Class E license, one Class F license, one Class G license, and one
Class H license shall be issued hereunder. A holder of a Class B or C license
may hold only one Class E license during any calendar year. (Ord. 857, 10-10-
2016)
3-9-8: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   Established: The annual fee required for a Class A, B, C, D and F
license shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); for a Class E and G license,
two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00); and for a Class H license, two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first day and one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) for each additional day that the license is extended. Fees are
payable at the time of application and for each renewal. (Ord. 857, 10-10-2016)
   B.   Payment Of Fees; Refunds: All liquor license fees, including renewals,
shall be paid to the City. Indication of the payment of such license fee shall
be attached to every application for a license or for the renewal of a license
to sell alcoholic liquor. In the event the license applied for is denied, the
fee shall be returned to the applicant less twenty five percent (25%) for
processing costs. (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-9: EXPIRATION OF LICENSE; RENEWALS:
   A.   Each license required by this chapter shall terminate at the end of the
calendar year next following its issuance, unless sooner revoked as provided in
this chapter. The fee to be paid shall be reduced in proportion to the full
calendar months which have expired in the period.
   B.   A license issued under this chapter shall permit the sale of alcoholic
liquor only in the premises described in the application and license, and only
under the conditions and restrictions imposed in this chapter on the particular
class of license described therein. Such license shall not be subject to
attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or
transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or
hypothecated. Such license shall not descend by the laws of testate or
intestate devolution, but shall cease upon the death of the licensee; provided,
that the executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee and
the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in
part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale of alcoholic
liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of
the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of such
decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy, until the expiration of the
license, but not longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy or
insolvency of such licensee. If such administrator or executor does not
continue the business under such license, there shall be a refund made of that
portion of the license fee paid for any period in which the executor or
administrator may not operate. Any licensee shall have the right to a renewal
of such license; provided, that he is then qualified to receive a license, and
the premises for which such renewal is sought is suitable for such purpose, but
nothing herein shall be deemed to restrict the right of the mayor to revoke any
such license.
   C.   All applications for the renewal of a license shall be made in writing
to the mayor at least fifteen (15) days prior to December 31 of each year.
(Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-10: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Every licensee shall cause his license issued under this chapter to be framed
and kept in plain view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. (Ord.
845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-11: LOCATION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Near Certain Establishments: No license shall be issued for the sale at
retail of any alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any church,
school other than an institution of higher learning, hospital, home for aged or
indigent persons or for veterans, their spouses or children or any military or
naval station, or adult use, provided, that this prohibition shall not apply to
hotels offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to
restaurants, food shops or other places where sale of alcoholic liquors is not
the principal business carried on; nor to the renewal of a license for the sale
at retail of alcoholic liquor on premises within one hundred feet (100') of any
church or school where the church or school has been established within such
one hundred feet (100') since the issuance of the original license. In the case
of a church, the distance of one hundred feet (100') shall be measured to the
nearest part of any building used for worship services or educational programs
and not to property boundaries. In all other cases, the distance of one hundred
feet (100') shall be measured as required by the Illinois liquor control act of
1934, and as such may be interpreted by the courts of the state of Illinois.
   B.   Change Of Location: The location described in the license and
application required by this chapter may be changed only upon a written permit
to make such change issued by the mayor, and only if the proposed new location
is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under the laws of the
state, the provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the city. (Ord.
845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-12: SANITARY PREMISES:
All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor or for the storage of
such liquor for retail sale shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
(Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-13: DAYS AND HOURS OF SALES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale at retail or
otherwise dispense any alcoholic liquor in the city between the hours of one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on Monday through Sunday;
provided, however, that on New Year's Day, sales may take place until two
o'clock (2:00) A.M., after which time, the holder of a class B, C, or F license
shall have a one hour period to clear the premises of patrons and close the
doors. (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-14: EMPLOYEES:
   A.   Age Restrictions: Licensees shall be subject to the following:
      1.   No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall open, draw,
mix or pour any alcoholic liquor.
      2.   No person under the age of nineteen (19) years shall act as a waiter
or waitress or otherwise deliver or serve alcoholic liquor at any licensed
premises.
      3.   No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall sell any
alcoholic liquor at any retail operation.
   B.   Citizenship Required; Health Status: It shall be unlawful for any
person licensed under the provisions of this chapter to employ in any premises
used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor any person who is not a citizen of
the United States or who is afflicted with, or who is a carrier of any
contagious, infectious or venereal disease. It shall be unlawful for any person
who is afflicted with, or who is a carrier of any such disease to work in or
about any premises, or to engage in any way in the handling, preparation or
distribution of such liquor. (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-15: SALES TO CERTAIN PERSONS:
No licensee under this chapter shall sell, give away or deliver alcoholic
liquor or malt or vinaceous beverages to any person under the age of twenty one
(21) years or to any intoxicated person, except as provided in 235 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/6-16.1. (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-16: MISREPRESENTATION OF AGE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person under legal age, as defined by the state of
Illinois, to misrepresent his or her age for the purpose of purchasing or
receiving alcoholic liquor in any tavern, store, or other place in the city
where alcoholic liquor is sold. (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-17: SOLICITING DRINKS:
   A.   No licensee under this chapter shall permit any employee or entertainer
in the premises to solicit any patron or customer thereof to purchase alcoholic
or nonalcoholic beverages for himself or herself or any other person on or in
such licensed premises; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall
prohibit any waiter or waitress who shall be regularly employed therein from
accepting and serving the order of a patron or customer in the regular course
of his or her employment of such waiter or waitress.
   B.   No person shall frequent or loiter in any premises licensed under this
chapter for the purpose of soliciting the purchase of alcoholic or nonalcoholic
beverages. (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-18: RECORDS KEPT:
The mayor shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all licenses
required by this chapter, issued by him, and all licenses issued shall be given
a number beginning with number one. (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-19: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The mayor in his capacity as local liquor control commissioner may suspend or
revoke any license issued under this chapter for any violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter or for any violation of any state law pertaining to
the sale of alcoholic liquor but only in accordance with the provisions of the
Illinois liquor control act. (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
3-9-20: PENALTIES:
In addition to the suspension, the local liquor control commissioner may levy a
fine on the licensee for a violation of any one or more of the provisions of
this chapter. The fine imposed shall not exceed one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for a first violation within a twelve (12) month period, one
thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation within a
twelve (12) month period, and two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for
a third or subsequent violation within a twelve (12) month period. Each
violation and each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a
separate violation. Not more than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) in
fines under this section may be imposed against any licensee during the period
of his license. (Ord. 845, 10-12-2015)
CHAPTER 10
VIDEO GAMING
SECTION:
3-10-1: Definitions
3-10-2: Video Gaming Establishment License
3-10-3: Video Gaming Terminal Permit Sticker
3-10-4: Regulations Governing Licensed Establishments Operating Video Gaming
Terminals
3-10-5: Inspection Of Premises
3-10-6: Revocation/Suspension Of License And Permit Stickers
3-10-7: Seizure Of Unlawful Video Gaming Terminals
3-10-8: Monetary Penalty
3-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
LICENSED ESTABLISHMENT: Any establishment that is both licensed to sell liquor
at retail in the City and licensed by the Illinois Board to operate a video
gaming terminal on its premises.
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: Any electronic video game machine that, upon insertion
of cash, is available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including,
but not limited to, video poker, line up, and blackjack, utilizing a video
display and microprocessors in which the player may receive free games or
credits that can be redeemed for cash. The term does not include a machine that
directly dispenses coins, cash, or tokens, or is for amusement purposes only.
(Ord. 898, 8-12-2019)
3-10-2: VIDEO GAMING ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE:
In order for a licensed establishment to operate a video gaming terminal, the
licensed establishment is required to obtain an annual video gaming
establishment license from the City by submitting a written application, on a
form provided by the City, to the City Clerk. (Ord. 898, 8-12-2019)
3-10-3: VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL PERMIT STICKER:
In order for a video gaming terminal to be operated at a licensed
establishment, the licensed establishment is required to obtain an annual video
gaming terminal permit sticker from the City for each video gaming terminal
located on its premises by submitting a written application, on a form provided
by the City, to the City Clerk. Each video gaming terminal permit sticker
issued by the City shall expire April 30, next, after the date of issue, with
an annual fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per video gaming terminal,
payable in full at the time the application is filed with the City. (Ord. 898,
8-12-2019)
3-10-4: REGULATIONS GOVERNING LICENSED ESTABLISHMENTS OPERATING VIDEO GAMING
TERMINALS:
The following regulations apply to all licensed establishments operating a
video gaming terminal on its premises with a valid gaming establishment license
and valid video gaming terminal permit stickers for each of its video gaming
terminals:
   A.   A valid City gaming establishment license must be clearly displayed at
all times.
   B.   A valid City video gaming terminal permit sticker shall be clearly
displayed at all times on each video gaming terminal.
   C.   No more than five (5) video gaming terminals may be located on the
licensed establishment's premises.
   D.   Other than having up to five (5) video gaming terminals with valid
video gaming terminal permit stickers, a licensed establishment is prohibited
from having, anywhere on its premises, an electronic video gaming machine that
may be available to play or simulate the play of poker, line up, blackjack,
faro, roulette, craps, slots or any other card or dice game, or other game of
chance or that is otherwise akin to a gambling or gaming device under this
Code, even if solely for amusement purposes.
   E.   All video gaming terminals must be located in an area restricted to
persons twenty one (21) years of age or older. The entrance to such area must,
at all times, be within the view of at least one employee who is at least
twenty one (21) years of age.
   F.   No licensed establishment may cause or permit any person under the age
of twenty one (21) years to use, play or operate a video gaming terminal.
   G.   No video gaming terminal may be played except during the legal hours of
operation allowed for the consumption of alcoholic beverages at the licensed
establishment pursuant to this Code.
   H.   The licensed establishment must fully comply with the Illinois Video
Gaming Act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq., and all rules,
regulations and restrictions imposed by the Illinois Gaming Board.
   I.   The licensed establishment must fully comply with all regulations of
this Code.
   J.   The licensed establishment must fully comply with any and all Federal
and Illinois State regulations and laws. (Ord. 898, 8-12-2019)
3-10-5: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
Every licensed establishment where a video gaming terminal is kept shall be
subject to inspection by the Chief of Police or his authorized agents, at any
time, to ensure compliance with this Code, including those establishments
applying for a video gaming establishment license and/or video gaming terminal
permit sticker. It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, resist, oppose
or attempt to hinder, resist or oppose the Chief of Police or his respective
agents in the course of an inspection. (Ord. 898, 8-12-2019)
3-10-6: REVOCATION/SUSPENSION OF LICENSE AND PERMIT STICKERS:
The City of Marquette Heights may revoke or suspend any video gaming
establishment license and any video gaming terminal permit sticker issued by
the City if it determines that the licensed establishment has violated any of
the provisions of this chapter. The license and video gaming terminal permit
stickers shall not be revoked or suspended until the licensed establishment has
been given a public hearing before the City Council, with a three (3) day
written notice to the licensed establishment, affording the licensed
establishment an opportunity to appear and defend. Notwithstanding the
foregoing, any licensed establishment that has its liquor license revoked or
suspended by the City or by the Illinois State Liquor Commission, or has its
video gaming license revoked or suspended by the Illinois Gaming Board, shall
automatically, without a hearing before the City Council, have its City video
gaming establishment license and all City video gaming terminal permit stickers
revoked or suspended for the same time frame as its liquor and/or Illinois
Gaming Board gaming license is suspended, whichever may be the case. (Ord. 898,
8-12-2019)
3-10-7: SEIZURE OF UNLAWFUL VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS:
Every video gaming terminal that does not have a valid video gaming terminal
permit sticker, or is otherwise unlawful, shall be considered a gambling device
and subject to seizure, and shall be turned over to the Illinois Gaming Board,
in accordance with board regulations and applicable law, unless otherwise
ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 898, 8-12-2019)
3-10-8: MONETARY PENALTY:
Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of
not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a first offense in a twelve
(12) month period, and a fine of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
for a second offense and each subsequent offense in a twelve (12) month period.
This penalty may be enforced by issuance of a "notice of violation" for the
fine amount, or by issuance of a "notice to appear". Each day any violation
continues shall constitute a separate offense. This monetary penalty shall be
in addition to any and all other remedies which may be available to the City
under this chapter, or under any other provision of this Code, or Federal or
Illinois law. (Ord. 898, 8-12-2019)
CHAPTER 11
RENTAL REGISTRATION AND INSPECTION PROGRAM
SECTION:
3-11-1: Purpose
3-11-2: Scope
3-11-3: Definitions
3-11-4: Registration Of Rental Property
3-11-5: Application Requirements
3-11-6: Registration Renewal
3-11-7: Changes In Information
3-11-8: Fees
3-11-9: Inspections
3-11-10: Notice Of Inspection And Right To Refuse
3-11-11: Assignment Of Classification
3-11-12: Class Listings And Violations
3-11-13: Local Agent Required
3-11-14: Safety And Security
3-11-15: Violations
3-11-16: Affirmative Defense
3-11-17: Notices
3-11-18: Records And Reports
3-11-19: Administrative Appeals
3-11-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the City of Marquette Heights Rental Registration and
Inspection Program adopted herein to assure that rental housing and non-owner
occupied properties in the City are maintained in a good, safe and sanitary
condition and does not create a nuisance or blighted conditions to its
surroundings. To ensure these conditions and to aid in the enforcement of
Property Maintenance Codes, Building Safety Codes, Zoning Ordinances and other
relevant provisions of the City of Marquette Heights ordinances, the City
Council hereby establishes the Rental Registration and Inspection Program for
all applicable residential rental units and non-owner occupied properties
within the City. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-2: SCOPE:
This chapter applies to any dwelling unit and its accessory units that are
leased as rental units located within the City of Marquette Heights, with the
following exceptions:
   A.   Nursing homes, as defined in the City of Marquette Heights Zoning
Ordinance;
   B.   Hotels and motels, as defined in the City of Marquette Heights Zoning
Ordinance, as well as other similar facilities where occupancy thereof does not
exceed thirty (30) days. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the
meaning respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context
otherwise requires.
DUPLEX: Means a building with two (2) rental units.
LEASE, LEASED, RENT, RENTED, OR RENTAL: Means any payment made or other
consideration given to the owner or an owner's agent pursuant to rental
agreement.
LOCAL AGENT: Means one or more persons who has charge, care or control of a
building in, or part thereof, in which rental units are maintained.
NON-OWNER OCCUPIED PROPERTY: Means any property, which encompasses contract for
deed situations or those situations in which there is no formal lease
agreement.
OWNER: Means one or more persons, jointly, severally or in common, or any
organization, in whom is vested all or part of the legal title to property, or
all or part of the beneficial ownership of a right to present use and enjoyment
of the premises, including a mortgage in possession. As used herein, an
organization shall include a corporation, trust, estate, partnership,
association or any other legal or commercial entity. The term owner shall not
include a lessee who previously occupied a rental unit and who is subleasing
the unit for the remaining part of his or her lease.
PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE: Means the Marquette Heights City ordinances
pertaining to property maintenance and the 2009 International Property
Maintenance Code, as well as all other codes adopted by the City relating to
property maintenance.
RENTAL AGREEMENT: Means all agreements, written and oral, and rules and
regulations embodying the terms and conditions concerning the use and enjoyment
of rented property, including subleases.
RENTAL INSPECTOR: Means the Marquette Heights building inspector or his/her
authorized designee.
RENTAL PROPERTY: Means a structure which is leased for occupancy for
residential or dwelling purposes. However, it does not include structures or
dwelling units as set forth in section
3-11-2 of this chapter.
RENTAL UNIT: Means each room or portion of a rental property used for
residential or dwelling purpose that is separately leased, rented, or otherwise
legally occupied by any persons other than the owner thereof.
SINGLE FAMILY DWELLING: Means a structure with one rental unit. (Ord. 889, 6-
24-2019)
3-11-4: REGISTRATION OF RENTAL PROPERTY:
   A.   After the effective date of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any
owner, as defined herein, to lease, rent, or otherwise operate a rental
property or non- owner occupied property without registering it with the City
of Marquette Heights and complying with the provisions of this chapter,
together with other applicable codes and ordinances of the City. The
registration of rental properties required herein shall expire on December 31
of each year.
   B.   No owner shall be allowed to register any property if the owner has
outstanding fees or fines due and owing the City.
   C.   Registration may be denied or revoked by the rental inspector as
provided in this chapter. If registration is denied or revoked, the building
official shall notify the owner or owner's agent, in writing, of the denial or
revocation and the reasons therefor, pursuant to section
3-11-17 of this chapter. The owner shall have the opportunity to appeal the
decision pursuant to section
3-11-19 of this chapter.
   D.   The City shall provide written confirmation to owner or owner's agent
upon receipt of each application for rental property registration or renewal
thereof via personal delivery, or first-class, or electronic mail. Such
confirmation shall contain the date of issuance, the owner's name, and the
address of the registered rental property or non-owner occupied property, and
shall be prima facie evidence of registration of the rental property or non-
owner occupied property as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019; Ord.
902, 10-14-2019)
3-11-5: APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS:
Applications for registration shall be filed with the City office and
accompanied by a registration fee as established in the schedule of fees in
section
3-11-8 of this chapter. Such application shall be made at least thirty (30)
days prior to the expiration of the registration, and shall include the
following:
   A.   Name, street address, city, state, zip code and telephone number of the
owner of the rental property.
   B.   Name, street, address, city, state, zip code and telephone number of
the owner's agent responsible for the management of the premises of the rental
property.
   C.   Legal address of the rental property.
   D.   Occupancy as permitted under the Zoning Ordinance, or as specified in
the Certificate of Occupancy.
   E.   Signed statement of owner or owner's agent indicating that the owner is
aware of the City's Building Safety Codes, Nuisance, and Zoning (occupancy)
Codes and the legal ramifications for knowingly violating said codes.
   F.   Name and address of the registered agent, if the owner is a
corporation.
   G.   Name and address of the mortgage holder, if there is a mortgage on the
rental property.
   H.   Name and address of any buyer on a Contract for Deed.
The City may require additional information, at any time, to clarify or support
the information provided on an application, or with respect to compliance with
any other provision of this chapter. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-6: REGISTRATION RENEWAL:
If there are no changes in ownership or agent representation, renewals of the
registration may be made by filling out the registration renewal form furnished
by the City and paying the appropriate fee. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-7: CHANGES IN INFORMATION:
Within thirty (30) days of any change in the registration information as
required by this chapter (e.g., a change of owner due to the sale of rental
property), the owner or owner's agent shall provide notice to the City of the
same in writing. There shall be no additional charge for the remaining period
of the annual registration. A change of ownership shall include any change in
ownership rights, including the execution of a Contract for Deed, whether
recorded or not. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-8: FEES:
   A.   It being the goal of the City that the Rental Registration and
Inspection Program be self-supporting, the Council shall establish a schedule
of registration fees. From time-to-time, the Council shall review income and
expenses arising from this chapter to determine any appropriate adjustments in
the fee schedule. Fees shall also be set for failure to register, incomplete
registration information, failure to register by the due date, and re-
inspection of rental properties.
   B.   It shall be illegal for any owner or owner's agent to charge a tenant
or tenants a fee greater than the actual pro rata cost of the registration fee
and attribute that greater than actual fee to the City. Any explicit pass-
through of the registration fee must be accurately represented, calculated and
communicated to the tenant in order to be effective, regardless of how the fee
may be characterized in any lease document.
   C.   Schedule of registration fees:
      1.   Single family units - one hundred dollars ($100.00) yearly.
      2.   Duplex units - one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) yearly.
      3.   Owner occupied with room rentals - one hundred dollars ($100.00)
yearly.
      4.   Multi-family units - one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) yearly.
      5.   Late registration - fifty dollars ($50.00) per month.
      6.   Incomplete registration - fifty dollars ($50.00).
      7.   Re-inspection after failed first inspection - one hundred dollars
($100.00)/visit.
      8.   Re-inspection after no show/denied entry - one hundred dollars
($100.00).
      9.   Failure to register within sixty (60) days of the effective date of
this chapter - one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-9: INSPECTIONS:
Both the interior and exterior of properties registered under the Rental
Registration and Inspection Program shall be periodically inspected by the City
as set forth herein.
   A.   The Council designee shall establish a schedule of periodic inspections
of registered rental properties and non-owner occupied properties within the
City to ensure compliance with this chapter as well as the Property Maintenance
Code, Building Codes established by the City and the permitted use and
residential occupancy provisions adopted by the City.
   B.   The inspection schedule shall be determined by the following factors:
      1.   By systematic wards throughout the City.
      2.   By tenant or neighbor complaints about a particular structure or
area of rental properties or non-owner occupied properties, and/or as indicated
by police or fire calls or exterior nuisance complaints about a structure or
area.
      3.   By the inspection class assigned to a particular building, pursuant
to section
3-11-11 of this chapter.
      4.   By the overall condition of the neighborhood in which the property
is located.
      5.   By the frequency of prior inspections and date of most recent
inspection of the property.
      6.   By such other factor as the City deems appropriate. (Ord. 889, 6-24-
2019)
3-11-10: NOTICE OF INSPECTION AND RIGHT TO REFUSE:
   A.   Periodic inspections of rental properties shall occur once an
appointment has been scheduled with the owner and/or occupant. When an
appointment has been scheduled with the Homeowner and/or Tenant and/or Agent of
Homeowner, no additional notice is required,
   B.   Objections to such inspections may be provided by telephone, fax or
email or in person at the City Office during normal business hours, but at
least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the inspection.
   C.   If any owner objects to a periodic inspection, “e an inspection of the
rental unit shall can still be undertaken if the occupant agrees to the
inspection.
   D.   Failure to reschedule an inspection or respond to a notice of
inspection shall be treated as an agreement to the date and time of the
inspection. The owner shall be liable for the cost of re-inspection if the
renter, owner, or owner’s agent fails to provide access to the rental property
as scheduled. Failure to provide access as scheduled or rescheduled shall also
constitute a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019; amd. Ord. 935, -
-2023)
3-11-11: ASSIGNMENT OF CLASSIFICATION:
Upon completion of a rental property's or non-owner occupied property's
inspection, the rental property shall be classified by the rental inspector
according to the classification system set forth herein. A rental property
shall be considered for reclassification at each subsequent inspection.
   A.   Class A - The rental property or non-owner occupied property has no
violations of applicable codes. The rental property shall be inspected as lower
priority on regular cycle thereafter.
   B.   Class B - The rental property or non-owner occupied property has
violations of applicable codes and the violations do not pose an immediate
threat of danger to life, health and safety of the occupants of the rental
property. The rental property shall be inspected on a regular cycle thereafter.
   C.   Class C - The rental property or non-owner occupied property has
violations of applicable codes that are in excess of ten (10) in number and/or
that affect the overall habitability of the building, but do not pose a threat
of danger to life, health, or safety of the occupants of the rental property.
The rental property may be inspected as frequently as every year thereafter.
   D.   Class D - The rental property or non-owner occupied property has
violations of applicable codes and is either unsafe, contains unsafe equipment,
is unfit for human occupancy, or is unlawful. Pursuant to Property Maintenance
Codes, the rental inspector may disallow occupancy of all or any portion of the
rental property until such code violations are corrected. The rental inspector
may inspect the rental property as deemed necessary to verify that it remains
in compliance with City codes.
   E.   Class F - The rental property or non-owner occupied property is not in
compliance with the Rental Registration and Inspection Program and may not be
occupied for rental. Violations leading to a Class F designation are
violations: 1) which render the unit unsuitable for habitation according to the
City's Health, Life, Safety and/or Property Maintenance Codes after
notification and reasonable opportunity to remedy such violations; 2) repeated
and willful violations of the City's Zoning Code, including, but not limited
to, occupancy requirements; or 3) use of the unit for a criminal purpose, as
demonstrated by adjudication of the owner or a tenant for the manufacture,
distribution or sale of drugs as set forth and defined by the Illinois Criminal
Code. The Class F designation shall be withdrawn when the underlying violations
have been remedied, or in the case of subsection 3, there has been a change of
ownership in the rental property, the subject tenant has been evicted, or the
owner has taken appropriate steps to prevent the rental property from
constituting a continuing threat to the public.
   F.   Class N - New construction of a rental property or non-owner occupied
property within the past twenty four (24) months. First inspection will occur
on the next inspection cycle as lowest priority.
The owner or owner's agent shall be notified in writing of the inspection
results within twenty (20) business days after the inspection in the manner set
forth in section
3-11-10 of this chapter. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-12: CLASS LISTINGS AND VIOLATIONS:
Listings of pertinent violations for Class D or Class F properties shall also
be considered public information and be available on request. (Ord. 889, 6-24-
2019)
3-11-13: LOCAL AGENT REQUIRED:
The owner of any rental unit or non-owner occupied property covered by this
chapter shall be available to respond to an emergency on a twenty four (24)
hour per day basis. This requirement may be met by maintaining a business or
owner- occupied residence within sixty (60) miles of the rental unit, or by the
use of a local agent who resides in Tazewell County or an adjoining county,
either of whom can be contacted on a twenty four (24) hour basis. If a local
agent is used, the owner shall provide the City with the name, address and
telephone number of the local agent in addition to owner information. A post
office box, mailing address or long distance 800 number shall not be sufficient
to meet the provisions of this section. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-14: SAFETY AND SECURITY:
To ensure the safety of all residents of rental properties, every owner shall:
   A.   Restrict regular access to the rental property or non-owner occupied
property and rental unit keys to tenants occupying the relevant rental units
and to the owner or owner's agent. Keys may be issued to vendors and
contractors for the purpose of maintenance and repair, but in such cases, the
owner or owner's agent shall take the responsibility for the tracking and
prompt return of such keys in order to protect the safety and security of
tenants. If keys are lost in the course of maintenance and repair activities,
the owner shall promptly change locks at his/her own expense.
   B.   Cooperate with the City and its Police Department to address continuing
safety issues and crime problems at any rental unit or non-owner occupied
property. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-15: VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Upon completion of an inspection, whenever it is determined that any
rental property, non-owner occupied property or rental unit contains one or
more violations of the applicable codes as set forth in this chapter, the
rental inspector shall serve written notice upon the owner or owner's agent of
the rental property or non-owner occupied property as set forth in section
3-11-10 of this chapter directing the owner to correct the violations within
thirty (30) days of the date of the notice. Such notice may be provided
together with the notice of inspection results in section
3-11-11 of this chapter.
   B.   Violations of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine of not less
than one hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each day the violation continues
shall constitute a separate violation. The City may seek additional legal
remedies including injunctive relief or corrective action in addition to the
imposition of a fine as set forth herein. Upon conviction of an offense in
violation of this chapter, the City shall also be entitled to recover its costs
and reasonable attorney's fees in addition to any fines imposed by the court.
   C.   The rental inspector may refuse to register or revoke the existing
registration of any rental property or non-owner occupied property which is
assigned a Class F classification as set forth in section
3-11-11 of this chapter. In the event that the rental inspector denies or
revokes registration of a rental property, the tenants of the subject property
shall be informed by the City of the denial or revocation, and of their need to
obtain other housing. An owner or owner's agent may appeal a registration
denial or revocation according to the provisions of section
3-11-19 of this chapter. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-16: AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE:
The following shall not be affirmative defenses to a violation of this chapter.
   A.   The owner or owner's agent did not receive notice, provided that the
City issued notice according to the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   The rental property or non-owner occupied property was inspected and
issued a classification pursuant to section
3-11-11 of this chapter indicative of the City's satisfaction with the state of
the property at time of investigation.
The following are affirmative defenses to a violation of this chapter:
   A.   Full correction of each and every violation charged against the
defendant within thirty (30) days of notice.
   B.   The violation charge has been caused by the current occupant or
occupants, and the owner or owner's agent has persuasive evidence in support of
such defense.
   C.   The current occupant(s) have refused entry to the owner or owner's
agent to the rental unit or non-owner occupied property or that part of the
rental unit requiring correction, for the purpose of correcting the violation.
(Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-17: NOTICES:
Any written notice required to be given to the owner of a rental property or
non-owner occupied property under this chapter shall be addressed to such owner
at the address provided for such owner in the application for registration. If
the owner or owner's agent, to whom such notice is addressed, cannot be found
after diligent inquiry, service may be made by posting a notice in or on the
residential rental property or by publication in a newspaper of general
circulation in Tazewell County for a period of three (3) consecutive days.
(Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)
3-11-18: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
The rental inspector shall keep records of all complaints, inspections,
reports, and actions taken with respect to each rental property. (Ord. 889, 6-
24-2019)
3-11-19: ADMINISTRATIVE APPEALS:
An owner or owner's agent, may appeal a registration denial or revocation to
the City Council within ten (10) days of the date of written notice to such
owner or owner's agent of the denial or revocation of registration. The appeal
must be in writing and state the reasons the owner or owner's agent disagrees
with the determination to deny or revoke registration or the reasons for the
denial or revocation. The Mayor shall notify the owner or owner's agent in
writing within five (5) days of the receipt of the written appeal that the
appeal has been received, and the appeal shall be placed on the agenda for the
next City Council meeting. At the next City Council meeting, the owner or
owner's agent may address the Council regarding the reasons the owner or
owner's agent disagrees with the determination to deny or revoke the
registration or the reasons for denial or revocation. The Mayor shall issue the
decision of the Council in writing to the owner or owner's agent within ten
(10) days of the Council meeting. (Ord. 889, 6-24-2019)

   B.   The following regulations shall apply in addition to those found in the
international building code 2009:
      1.   Duration Of Permits: Except as may be specifically otherwise
provided in this or any order code adopted by the city, all construction or
other work to be performed pursuant to any permit issued shall be completed
within one year from the date such permit is issued.
      2.   Completion Of Exterior Work: Except as provided in section 105.3.2,
any permit issued pursuant to this code for new building construction, existing
building reconstruction or expansion, shall require that the work be completed
within six (6) months after the date of the permit. Any failure to comply with
said condition shall constitute a violation of this code.
      3.   Nonpermitted Repairs And Maintenance, Completion Of Work: Any repair
or maintenance for which a permit is not required, such as new roof shingles,
new siding, new windows or the like, shall be completed within three (3) months
after the repairs are commenced.

4-1-5: ELECTRICAL CODE AMENDMENTS:
The following regulations shall apply in addition to those found in the
national electrical code 2008:
   A.   Violation Penalties: Any person who shall violate a provision of this
code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall
erect, construct, alter or repair a building or structure in violation of an
approved plan or directive of the code official shall be guilty of a violation
of this code, which such violation shall be punishable by a fine in an amount
not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). Each day that a violation of this code exists or continues to exist
shall be deemed a separate offense.
   B.   Unlawful Continuance: Any person who shall continue any electrical work
in or about a structure after having been served with a stop work order, except
such work as that person is directed to perform or remove a violation or unsafe
conditions, shall be liable to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that a violation of the
national electrical code 2008 exists or continues to exist shall be deemed a
separate offense.
   C.   Amendments: The following insertions and amendments are made to the
national electrical code 2008:
Section 101.1: Insert:
      Residential: $50.00 plus $10.00 for each additional $1000.00 or fraction
thereof.
      Commercial: $400.00 plus $10.00 for each additional $1000.00 or fraction
thereof.
      If a permit is not obtained prior to the start of a project, ALL permit
fees are doubled.
   D.   Minimum Wire Size: All wire intended to carry electricity at 110/120 or
220/240 volts in any circuit installed in conjunction with any construction or
modification, whether new construction, repair, replacement or upgrade shall be
12 AWG (American wire gauge) or larger. All references in the code which
purport to allow the use of any wire smaller than 12 AWG in any circuit
intended to carry electricity at 110/120 or 220/240 volts shall be construed as
a reference to 12 AWG.
   E.   Licensing: It shall be unlawful for any person to perform electrical
work within the city of Marquette Heights except under the following
circumstances:
      1.   The person is the owner of the property where the work is being
performed,
      2.   The person possesses and provides to the building inspector or
electrical inspector a current valid electrician's license issued by either the
city of Pekin, Illinois, or the city of Peoria, Illinois, or
      3.   The person has obtained a waiver from the mayor. The mayor may issue
waivers to any person or contractor that possesses and provides to the building
inspector or electrical inspector a current valid electrician's license issued
by a governmental unit located within the state of Illinois. (Ord. 762, 6-8-
2009; Ord. 830, 7-14-2014; Ord. 906, 1-27-2020)

Violation/Penalties: Any person who shall violate a provision of this code or

construct, alter or repair a building or structure in violation of an approved
plan or directive of the code official, or of a permit or certificate issued
under the provisions of this code shall be guilty of a violation of this code,

$50.00 nor more than $500.00. Each day that a violation of this code exists or

Section PM-111.0 entitled "Means Of Appeal" is hereby deleted in its entirety.
Any person affected by a decision of the code official or a notice of order
issued under said code shall have the right to appeal to the city council of
the city provided that a written application for appeal is filed within twenty
(20) days after the day the decision, notice or order was served. An
application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of the
said code or the rules legally adopted thereunder have been incorrectly
interpreted, the provisions of the said code do not fully apply or the
requirements of the said code are adequately satisfied by other means. All
reference in said code to the "board of appeals" shall be deemed as a reference
to the city council. In responding to an appeal, the city council may in its
discretion seek such professional assistance as it deems necessary to make an
appropriate decision.
(Ord. 762, 6-8-2009)

CHAPTER 2
FIRE CODE
(Rep. by Ord. 358, 2-8-1988)
CHAPTER 3
ONE- AND TWO-FAMILY DWELLING CODE
(Rep. by Ord. 358, 2-8-1988)
CHAPTER 4
SATELLITE DISHES
SECTION:
4-4-1: Construction Requirements
4-4-2: Number Of Antennas
4-4-3: Permit
4-4-1: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
A large satellite dish may be permitted as an accessory use.
   A.   Definition: "Large satellite dish" is any satellite dish that exceeds
one meter (1 m) (39.37 inches) in diameter, as measured edge to edge at the
widest point.
   B.   Large Satellite Dish:
      1.   Height: Maximum height from ground shall not exceed fourteen feet
(14'), as measured to the highest point of the satellite dish.
      2.   Setback: Setback, including the concrete slab base or other
structure shall not be constructed to reach closer to the front of the property
line than five feet (5') back from the front of the structural line of the
front most building nor closer than five feet (5') from the side and rear lot
lines.
      3.   Wiring: All wiring between the satellite dish and the receiver shall
be placed underground according to the local building codes and ordinances.
      4.   Prohibition: Residential structures shall not mount a large
satellite dish to the roof of the residence. (Ord. 699, 9-12-2005)
4-4-2: NUMBER OF ANTENNAS:
The number of large satellite dish antennas shall not exceed one on any
property zoned residential within the city. (Ord. 699, 9-12-2005)
4-4-3: PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful to install a large satellite dish in the city without
first securing a permit. (Ord. 699, 9-12-2005)
CHAPTER 5
SOLAR UNITS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Construction And Installation
4-5-2: Permit
4-5-1: CONSTRUCTION AND INSTALLATION:
A solar unit shall be considered an accessory use, now therefore:
Construction and installation must comply with applicable local building codes,
ordinances and manufacturer's specifications. (Ord. 318, 3-25-1985)
4-5-2: PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful to install a solar unit in the city without first securing
a permit therefor. (Ord. 318, 3-25-1985)
CHAPTER 6
FENCES, WALLS, AND ANIMAL RUNS
SECTION:
4-6-1: Definitions
4-6-2: Compliance Required
4-6-3: Prohibited Fences
4-6-4: Permit Required
4-6-5: General Construction Requirements; All Districts
4-6-6: Design, Location And Height Requirements; Residential Districts
4-6-7: Design, Location And Height Requirements; Commercial Districts
4-6-8: Design, Location And Height Requirements; Industrial Districts
4-6-9: Fences For Specific Uses
4-6-10: Gates
4-6-11: Variance
4-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
ANIMAL RUN: Any confined area without a roof not a regular part of any other
structure on the same premises (but which may be attached thereto), designed,
maintained for domesticated pets or animals.
BUILDING LINE: That line created by the front or side of any building, as the
case may be, as extended to the property line of the property on which building
is located.
BUILDING SETBACK LINE: Shall have the same meaning as set forth in section
6-2-2 of this code (subdivision regulations).
COMMERCIAL DISTRICT: Those areas in the city of Marquette Heights designated as
"business and commercial districts" in title 5, "Zoning Regulations", of this
code.
EXTERIOR STORAGE: The storage or leaving of any goods, merchandise, inventory
or raw material intended for sale, outside of the confines of any building
located on the subject premises, for any consecutive period of twenty four (24)
hours or more.
FENCE: Permanent, living or nonliving structure forming a barrier which is not
otherwise a part of any building or structure and used to delineate a boundary
line, as a means of confinement, or for the purpose of privacy. A hedge of any
natural or planted flora used for any of the foregoing purposes shall be
considered to be a fence for the purpose of this chapter.
HEIGHT OF A FENCE: The height as measured from the existing grade level of the
property on which the fence is installed to the highest point located on the
fence.
INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT: Those areas in the city of Marquette Heights designated as
"industrial districts" in title 5, "Zoning Regulations", of this code.
OPEN FENCE: A fence including gates, with open spaces which afford direct views
through the fence comprising at least fifty percent (50%) of each one foot (1')
wide segment extending over the entire length and height of the fence.
PERIMETER FENCE: A fence which, to the extent permitted by this code, runs
generally parallel to and in close proximity to the lot lines of any given lot
or tract of land.
RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT: Those areas in the city of Marquette Heights designated
as "single-family dwelling districts" in title 5, "Zoning Regulations", of this
code.
SCREENING FENCE: A solid fence which totally obscures vision from one side to
the other, including any gate or entryway thereon or which is a part thereof.
WALL: A masonry or wood structure, two feet (2') or higher, constructed to
retain soil between two (2) differing elevations at any location on a
residential or commercial property. (Ord. 367, 7-11-1988; amd. Ord. 781, 9-13-
2010)
4-6-2: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or cause to be erected a fence on
any property within the city except as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 367, 7-
11-1988)
4-6-3: PROHIBITED FENCES:
   A.   No dangerous or hazardous type fence such as barbed wire, electrical
fences, fences with spikes, broken glass or other sharp points or materials
imbedded in them or any other type fence likely to result in injuries to
persons climbing on or over such fence shall be permitted to be erected or
maintained within the city.
   B.   Also, no fence that is leaning in such a manner that an angle of
