fifteen degrees (15°) or more is produced when measured from the vertical shall
be permitted to be maintained within the city. (Ord. 367, 7-11-1988)
4-6-4: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall erect a fence, wall, or animal run in the city without
first having received a permit from the building inspector.
   B.   Applications for a permit shall be submitted to the building inspector
on forms provided by the building inspector. An application for a permit shall
be accompanied by: 1) a sketch of the proposed project indicating the design,
the material to be used and the dimensions of the proposed fence, wall, or
animal run, and 2) a sketch or diagram drawn substantially to scale of the lot
on which the proposed project is to be located showing the location of the
proposed fence, wall, or animal run and all other structures on the property
whereon the fence, wall, or animal run is to be located. (Ord. 781, 9-13-2010)
4-6-5: GENERAL CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS; ALL DISTRICTS:
   A.   Fences:
      1.   Any and every fence to be erected in the city shall be designed and
constructed to resist and withstand a wind pressure of not less than twenty
(20) pounds per square foot of the gross proposed area of the fence less any
openings, from any angle of approach.
      2.   All fence posts used in the construction of a fence must be buried
in the ground to a depth of at least one-third (1/3) of the total length of
said fence post.
      3.   All fence posts or anchors of wood or other organic material shall
be treated with a chemical treatment to protect them from deteriorating when
they are placed in the ground.
      4.   Alterations to the existing grade level preceding the construction
of a fence for the purpose of altering the height of the fence shall not be
permitted.
      5.   All fences shall be maintained in good and sound condition and shall
not create a harborage for rodents.
      6.   If a fence is to be painted, it shall be painted with nonlead base
paint.
      7.   No fence shall be constructed in such a manner as to impede or alter
the natural surface water drainage of the property upon which the fence is
constructed or any adjoining property.
      8.   A perimeter fence, if it is an open fence shall not exceed five feet
(5') in height and if it is a screening fence, shall not exceed six feet (6')
in height.
      9.   On all screening fences, fence posts and other bracing members shall
be so situated as to face the interior of the property fenced in. This
requirement shall not apply to a basket weave or other type of fence where
approximately one- half (1/2) of the screening material is located on either
side of the fence posts and other bracing members.
   B.   Retaining Walls:
      1.   All retaining walls hereafter erected shall conform to section
1807.2 or section 2304.11.7 of the international building code.
(See R404.4 of international residential code.)
   C.   Animal Runs: See subsection 4-6-9B of this chapter. (Ord. 781, 9-13-
2010)
4-6-6: DESIGN, LOCATION AND HEIGHT REQUIREMENTS; RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS:
   A.   Except as provided in subsections B and C of this section, no fence
shall be constructed in a front yard past the front building line.
   B.   In all residential districts, a wood type split rail open face or
peeled log split rail open face may be erected on the premises anywhere within
six inches (6") of the property lines of the property on which the fence is to
be erected including the front yard past the building line and the front side
yards past the building lines in the case of corner lots. The height of such
fences shall not exceed four feet (4').
   C.   No screening fence shall be constructed closer to the front property
line than five feet (5') back from the front building line of the main
residential building.
   D.   Except as provided in subsections B and C of this section, in the case
of corner lots, no fence shall be erected beyond the building lines of those
sides of the building which face the two (2) streets forming the corner lot.
   E.   Except as limited by subsections B, C, and D of this section, perimeter
fences may be erected in the side and rear yard in back of the front building
line. (Ord. 367, 7-11-1988)
4-6-7: DESIGN, LOCATION AND HEIGHT REQUIREMENTS; COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS:
   A.   Exterior storage of any goods, merchandise, inventory or raw material
at or on any property located in a commercial district is not prohibited.
However, any goods which are the subject of such exterior storage shall be kept
or stored within the interior confines of a screening fence.
Exceptions: Sales of promotional items of a seasonal nature (i.e., lawn and
garden equipment, snowblowers and related merchandise, Christmas trees, etc.)
so long as the extended period does not exceed eight (8) consecutive months and
sales promotional items unrelated to any seasonal consideration not exceeding
sixty (60) days shall not be subject to the confines of a screening fence.
However, all items either seasonal or sales promotional that are not subject to
the screening fence requirement shall not be placed, kept, or displayed any
closer than thirty feet (30') from the front property line (both sides if on a
corner).
   B.   Any "garbage can" (as defined in section
8-3-1 of this code) kept on any premises in a commercial district shall at all
times, except as necessary for garbage collection, be kept within the interior
confines of a screening fence of not less than five feet (5') nor more than six
feet (6') in height.
   C.   Where property in a commercial district abuts by actual contiguity any
property situated in a residential district, a screening fence shall be erected
on those sides adjoining property situated in a residential district.
   D.   When required, screening fences in commercial districts shall be not
less than five feet (5') in height, nor more than six feet (6') in height, when
erected behind the building setback lines on the side and/or rear yards.
   E.   When required, screening fences in commercial districts extend beyond
the building setback lines. No screening fence may reach any closer than thirty
feet (30') from the front property line (both sides if on a corner).
   F.   Any screening fences in commercial districts extending beyond the
building setback lines shall be not less than three feet (3') in height nor
more than four feet (4') in height.
   G.   Screening fences in commercial districts are permitted across frontal
property lines so long as the setback requirements are adhered to as set forth
in subsection E of this section, and the height requirements are adhered to as
set forth in subsection F of this section. (Ord. 367, 7-11-1988)
4-6-8: DESIGN, LOCATION AND HEIGHT REQUIREMENTS; INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS:
   A.   The exterior storage of any goods, merchandise, inventory or raw
materials at or on any property located in an industrial district is not
prohibited. However, any goods which are the subject of such exterior storage
shall be kept or stored within the interior confines of a screening fence of
not less than six feet (6') nor more than eight feet (8') in height.
   B.   Any "garbage can" (as defined in section
8-3-1 of this code) kept on any premises in an industrial district shall at all
times, except as necessary for garbage collection, be kept within the interior
confines of a screening fence of not less than six feet (6') nor more than
eight feet (8') in height.
   C.   Where property in industrial districts abuts by actual contiguity or
fronts on any property situated in a residential district, a screening fence
shall be erected on those sides adjoining or fronting on the property situated
in a residential district. Such a fence shall be located within six inches (6")
of the property line that abuts the residential property. Such screening fence
shall be not less than six feet (6') in height nor more than eight feet (8') in
height in an industrial district. (Ord. 367, 7-11-1988)
4-6-9: FENCES FOR SPECIFIC USES:
   A.   Swimming Pools: Swimming pools shall be enclosed with a fence and gate
together with all other enclosure requirements as set forth in section
4-11-2 of this title. (Ord. 367, 7-11-1988; amd. Ord. 727, 8-13-2007)
   B.   Animal Runs: Animal runs shall not be larger than one hundred (100)
square feet in size and shall be enclosed by a fence not less than four feet
(4') nor more than six feet (6') in height. All animal runs shall be
constructed behind the rear building line of the main structure on the premises
and no animal run shall be located closer than five feet (5') to the property
line of any given tract of land. (Ord. 367, 7-11-1988)
   C.   Other Code Requirements: Nothing herein contained shall be construed as
superseding or lessening the requirements of title 10, chapter 7 of this code
regulating the keeping and confinement of certain animals and of title 10,
chapter 5 of this code regulating the keeping of multiple pets at any given
premises. (Ord. 378, 12-12-1988)
4-6-10: GATES:
No gate on any fence shall be left open so as to obstruct or impede the free
flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic on any sidewalk, street, alley or other
public way in the city. (Ord. 367, 7-11-1988)
4-6-11: VARIANCE:
Whenever, in specific circumstances due to exceptional or special conditions
which apply to any particular premises, lot or track of land, whereat the
strict application of the regulations of this chapter would result in practical
difficulties or the imposition of a particular hardship on the property owner,
a variance may be granted subject to the conditions hereinafter set forth.
   A.   Application for a variance shall be made to the zoning board, which
shall grant or deny the variance request within thirty (30) days from the
submission of the request and if the zoning board does not take any action
thereon within thirty (30) days the request shall be deemed denied.
   B.   The denial of a variance by the zoning board may be appealed to the
city council which may, by a majority vote, grant the variance.
   C.   A variance may be granted only when the following conditions exist:
      1.   That special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar
to the land or structure involved which are not applicable to other lands or
structures in the same zoning district;
      2.   That literal interpretation of the provisions of this chapter would
deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by other lands or structures
in the same zoning district under the terms of this chapter;
      3.   That the special conditions and circumstances do not result from the
actions of the applicant;
      4.   That the granting of the variance requested will not confer on the
applicant any special privilege that is denied by the chapter to other lands or
structures in the same zoning district;
      5.   That the reasons set forth in the application justify the granting
of the variance and that the variance is the minimum variance that will make
possible the reasonable use of the property;
      6.   That congestion in public streets will not be increased unreasonably
or that the property will be relieved of unreasonable parking requirements;
      7.   That the values or character of property within the surrounding area
will not be diminished or impaired thereby, nor nearby property adversely
affected; and
      8.   That in all other respects the public health, safety, comfort,
morals and welfare will not be impaired. (Ord. 367, 7-11-1988)
CHAPTER 7
DRIVEWAYS AND PARKING LOTS
SECTION:
4-7-1: Definitions
4-7-2: Compliance Required
4-7-3: Minimum Standards, Residential District
4-7-4: Minimum Standards, Commercial District
4-7-5: Minimum Standards, Parking Lots
4-7-6: Existing Driveways And Parking Lots (All Districts)
4-7-7: Permit Requirements
4-7-8: Variance
4-7-9: Inspections
4-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
AUTHORIZED CITY OFFICIAL: The city building inspector, or if the building
inspector is unavailable, the street superintendent or any member of the city
council.
BUILDING SETBACK LINE: Shall have the same meaning as set forth in section
6-2-2 of this code (subdivision regulations).
COMMERCIAL DISTRICT: Those districts designated as "business and commercial
districts" in title 5, "Zoning Regulations", of this code.
DRIVEWAY: That portion of a residential property used for vehicular access to a
garage or carport, or for the purpose of off street parking.
PARKING LOT: Any portion of commercial property regularly used for vehicular
access or off street parking.
RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT: Those areas in the city of Marquette Heights designated
as "single-family dwelling districts" in title 5, "Zoning Regulations", of this
code.
SECOND DRIVEWAY: Any approach or passageway regularly used to gain access to
any residential property other than an existing (prior to the effective date of
this chapter) driveway or other driveway which meets the minimum requirements
of this code, and which does not abut any other driveway on the premises.
SITE PREPARATIONS: In the case of a driveway or parking lot to be constructed
of poured concrete, site preparations include all preparations of the site
where the driveway or parking lot is to be located, which preparations must be
completed prior to pouring the concrete, including, without limitation, all
necessary excavating, grading, forming and the placement of reinforcement
materials and expansion joints. In the case of a driveway or parking lot to be
constructed with bituminous concrete placed over a compacted crushed rock base,
site preparations include all steps precedent to the placement of the
bituminous concrete at the site, including excavation, grading and the
placement and compaction of the crushed rock base. (Ord. 365, 6-27-1988; amd.
Ord. 555, 5-24-1999)
4-7-2: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
From and after the effective date of this chapter, all new driveways and
parking lots constructed in the city shall be in accordance with the minimum
standard as set forth herein; and any and all repairs and/or maintenance to
existing driveways and/or parking lots shall be in accordance with the
standards for repairs and maintenance as set forth herein. (Ord. 365, 6-27-
1988)
4-7-3: MINIMUM STANDARDS, RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT:
   A.   Width: The minimum width of a driveway with or without a garage or
carport and regardless of its length shall be ten feet (10'). Each additional
straight-in approach stall shall require a minimum additional eight feet (8')
of width.
   B.   Length: The minimum length of a driveway shall be the distance between
the curb line abutting said property and the minimum building setback line for
said property. (Ord. 365, 6-27-1988)
   C.   Materials: All newly constructed driveways on new or existing
residential properties shall, at least from the curb line to the property line,
be of concrete composition with a thickness of at least six inches (6") and one
inch (1") of compacted granular material. No wire or other reinforcing material
shall be allowed in sidewalks or apron/approach areas. All newly constructed
driveways on new or existing residential properties shall, at least from the
property line, be with concrete composition with a thickness of at least four
inches (4") and one inch (1") of compacted granular material or bituminous
concrete composition of at least one inch (1") thick with a combined compacted
crushed rock base and bituminous concrete thickness of six inches (6") total.
(Ord. 691, 5-9-2005)
   D.   Approach: All driveways shall terminate at the curb line of the street
and shall include a flared section at the curb line which shall increase the
width of the driveway a minimum of two feet (2') on each side thereof. Said
flared section shall terminate not less than four feet (4') back from the curb
line. (Ord. 365, 6-27-1988)
   E.   Curb Cuts: When curb cuts are not already available, the existing curb
and gutter shall be removed to a width of at least two feet (2') beyond the
flared portion of the driveway on each side thereof, and replaced with a new
concrete depressed curb configuration.
      1.   If the curb is being replaced, the gutter flag must be formed to
meet existing dimensions. The remaining area of street must be replaced with
bituminous concrete (asphalt); or
      2.   If removal of curb is not the desired option, and the existing curb
is not deteriorating, the curb shall be commercially cut so as to be of the
same dimensions as if it were replaced. This must be inspected by the street
department before cutting to determine soundness of the existing curb.
      3.   A curb cut bond of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be posted
with the city clerk until final inspection is completed by the public works
department. (Ord. 691, 5-9-2005)
   F.   Public Sidewalks: All portions of a public sidewalk which pass through
any driveway area shall be of concrete construction and in accordance with
section
6-4-2-2 of this code. (Ord. 365, 6-27-1988)
4-7-4: MINIMUM STANDARDS, COMMERCIAL DISTRICT:
   A.   Width: The minimum width of a driveway shall be twenty feet (20') and
the maximum width shall be thirty feet (30').
   B.   Length: The minimum length of a driveway shall be the distance between
the curb line abutting said property and the minimum building setback line for
said property or to the beginning of a parking lot.
   C.   Materials: All newly constructed driveways on new or existing
commercial properties shall be of either concrete composition with a thickness
of at least five inches (5") or bituminous concrete composition of at least one
inch (1") thick over a minimum of five inches (5") of compacted crushed rock
base.
   D.   Approach: All driveways shall terminate at the curb line of the street
and shall include a flared section at the curb line which shall increase the
width of the driveway a minimum of two feet (2') on each side thereof. Said
flared section shall terminate not less than four feet (4') back from the curb
line.
   E.   Curb Cuts: When curb cuts are not already available, the existing curb
and gutter shall be removed to a width of at least two feet (2') beyond the
flared portion of the driveway on each side thereof, and replaced with a new
concrete depressed curb (and gutter) with transitions to meet the existing curb
configuration, and said new curb (and gutter) shall not be monolithic with the
driveway.
   F.   Public Sidewalks: All portions of a public sidewalk which pass through
any driveway area shall be of concrete construction and in accordance with
section
6-4-2-2 of this code. (Ord. 365, 6-27-1988)
4-7-5: MINIMUM STANDARDS, PARKING LOTS:
In addition to the area requirements as set forth in section
5-5-3 of this code, all newly constructed parking lots shall be of either
concrete composition with a thickness of at least five inches (5") or
bituminous concrete construction of at least one inch (1") thick over a minimum
of five inches (5") of crushed rock base. (Ord. 365, 6-27-1988)
4-7-6: EXISTING DRIVEWAYS AND PARKING LOTS (ALL DISTRICTS):
   A.   All existing concrete, bituminous concrete or asphalt driveways and
parking lots may be repaired, resurfaced or reconstructed of concrete,
bituminous concrete or asphalt only.
   B.   Existing brick, crushed rock or gravel driveways in residential
districts may be repaired or maintained with brick, crushed rock or gravel so
long as that portion being repaired or maintained is within the minimum areas
required for driveways and/or parking lots as described herein and the repair
or maintenance does not increase or enlarge the area.
   C.   Existing driveways and parking lots may be enlarged with concrete or
bituminous concrete composition only in accordance with the minimum standards
set forth in this code.
   D.   All driveways, parking lots and similar paved areas shall be kept in a
state of safe and useable repair and maintained free of hazardous conditions.
If any driveway, parking lot or portion thereof, by virtue of its state of
disrepair, shall constitute a danger to public health and safety, the driveway,
parking lot or portion thereof shall be replaced in accordance with the minimum
standards set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 365, 6-27-1988)
4-7-7: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Any driveway or parking lot constructed as a part of any building or
construction project for which a building permit is required by chapter 1 of
this title, shall not require a separate permit for the construction thereof,
and the building permit issued for such building or construction project shall
be deemed to include the driveway or parking lot which is a part of such
project.
   B.   The construction or replacement of any new driveway or parking lot, not
a part of a project for which a building permit has been issued, or the
replacement of any existing driveway or parking lot shall require the issuance
of a permit as required by subsection 4-1-1A of this title.
   C.   Ordinary maintenance and repair of any driveway or parking lot shall
not require the issuance of a permit so long as such maintenance or repair does
not increase or enlarge the area of such driveway or parking lot.
   D.   Any driveway or parking lot construction or repair involving removal
and/or replacement of any public sidewalk, curb or gutter shall require a
permit and the posting of a bond as provided in section 9-2-2 of this code.
(Ord. 365, 6-27-1988)
4-7-8: VARIANCE:
Whenever, in a specific circumstance due to exceptional or special conditions
which apply to any particular premises, lot or tract of land whereat the strict
application of the regulations of this chapter would result in practical
difficulties or the imposition of a particular hardship on the property owner,
a variance may be granted subject to the conditions hereinafter set forth.
   A.   Application for a variance shall be made to the zoning board, who shall
grant or deny the variance request within thirty (30) days from the submission
of the request and if the zoning board does not take any action thereon within
thirty (30) days the request shall be deemed denied.
   B.   The denial of a variance by the zoning board may be appealed to the
city council which may, by a majority vote, grant the variance.
   C.   A variance may be granted only when the following conditions exist:
      1.   Special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar to the
land or structure involved which are not applicable to other lands or
structures in the same zoning district;
      2.   Literal interpretation of the provisions of this chapter would
deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by other lands or structures
in the same zoning district under the terms of this chapter;
      3.   The special conditions and circumstances do not result from the
actions of the applicant;
      4.   The granting of the variance requested will not confer on the
applicant any special privilege that is denied by the chapter to other lands or
structures in the same zoning district;
      5.   The reasons set forth in the application justify the granting of the
variance and that the variance is the minimum variance that will make possible
the reasonable use of the property;
      6.   Congestion in public streets will not be increased unreasonably or
that the property will be relieved of unreasonable parking requirements;
      7.   The values or character of property within the surrounding area will
not be diminished or impaired thereby nor nearby property adversely affected;
and
      8.   In all other respects the public health, safety, comfort, morals,
and welfare will not be impaired.
   D.   Second driveways are prohibited on all residential properties, but some
may be allowed as a variance, subject to the foregoing conditions. (Ord. 365,
6-27-1988; amd. Ord. 436, 11-23-1992)
4-7-9: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Inspection Of Site Preparations: After the completion of site
preparations, but before concrete is poured or bituminous concrete is applied
in connection with any driveway or parking lot subject to the provisions of
this chapter, the city shall be notified that site preparations are complete.
Neither the property owner nor any person acting on behalf of the owner shall
pour concrete or apply bituminous concrete until an authorized city official
has inspected the site preparations.
   B.   Notice To City: Inspection of completed site preparations shall be
requested in writing in advance of the time when the owner expects concrete to
be poured or bituminous concrete to be applied.
   C.   Responsibility For Notice To City: The owner of the property being
improved and any person acting on behalf of the owner for the purpose of
constructing the driveway or parking lot shall be jointly responsible for
requesting an inspection.
   D.   Modification Of Site Preparations After Inspection: After an inspection
has been completed by an authorized city official, neither the owner nor any
person acting on behalf of the owner shall make any substantial modification to
the site preparations, including in particular, any modification which would
change the quality or quantity of materials used, without requesting an
additional inspection in accordance with the terms of this section.
   E.   Failure Of Site Preparations To Meet Specifications: In the event that
an authorized city official concludes that the site preparations will result in
an installation which is inconsistent with the requirements of this chapter,
corrections shall be made to the site preparations to ensure that the finished
installation will comply with this chapter. Neither the owner nor any person
acting on behalf of the owner shall pour concrete or apply bituminous concrete
without first obtaining an additional inspection of the modified site
preparations by an authorized city official in accordance with the procedures
set forth in this section.
   F.   Failure To Request Inspection: Should any owner or any person acting on
behalf of the owner pour concrete or apply bituminous concrete prior to
completion of the inspection required by this section, the owner and the
contractor shall have the joint and several responsibility to prove compliance
with the provisions of this chapter by providing core samples or other means as
deemed necessary by the city building inspector in consultation with the city
engineer all at the sole cost and expense of the owner.
   G.   Failure Of Improvements To Meet Specifications: Should any driveway or
parking lot subject to the provisions of this chapter fail to comply with the
specifications prescribed by this chapter, such improvements shall be
immediately replaced with improvements which comply with the specifications
prescribed by this chapter all at the sole cost and expense of the owner. The
obligation to remove and replace substandard improvements shall be specifically
enforceable by the city. (Ord. 555, 5-24-1999)
CHAPTER 8
UTILITY LINES ON PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY
SECTION:
4-8-1: Definitions
4-8-2: Applicability
4-8-3: Exception For Franchise Agreements
4-8-4: Permit Required
4-8-5: Application For Permit
4-8-6: Consideration Of Application
4-8-7: Compliance Required
4-8-8: Permit Fees
4-8-9: Adjustment Of Annual Compensation
4-8-10: Manner Of Installation
4-8-11: Continuing Liability
4-8-12: Indemnification
4-8-13: Waiver Of Claims Against City
4-8-14: Insurance
4-8-15: Emergency Response
4-8-16: Relocation Of Lines
4-8-17: Termination Of Authority
4-8-18: Removal Of Lines
4-8-19: Revocation Of Permit
4-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
In the construction of this chapter, the words and terms set forth in this
section shall have the following meanings unless the context or use clearly
indicates another or different meaning or intent:
CITY SERVICE LINE: Any water line, sanitary sewer line, storm sewer line or any
other wire, cable or pipe owned by the city.
DIRECTOR: The street superintendent of the city or his authorized agent or
subordinate.
FRANCHISE AGREEMENT: Any agreement by and between the city and any utility
company, which agreement defines the terms and conditions under which the
utility company is entitled to utilize right of way.
RIGHT OF WAY: Any and all streets, alleyways, easements or other interest in
real property located within the corporate limits of the city, which property
is owned by the city or dedicated to the public use or which is otherwise under
the jurisdiction or control of the city.
UTILITY COMPANY: Any person engaged in the business of providing telephone
service, electrical service, cable television service, natural gas, water,
sanitary sewer or storm sewers, but specifically excluding therefrom the city
of Marquette Heights.
UTILITY LINE: Any wire, cable, pipe or other material used to carry, convey,
transfer or transmit any signal, any form of energy or any substance of any
nature whatsoever but specifically excluding therefrom water lines, sanitary
sewer lines, storm sewer lines or any other wire, cable or pipe owned by the
city. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-2: APPLICABILITY:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the regulations set forth in this
chapter shall apply to any utility company or other person who installs,
operates, or maintains a utility line on right of way. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-3: EXCEPTION FOR FRANCHISE AGREEMENTS:
If the city has entered into a franchise agreement containing provisions which
conflict with the provisions of this chapter, then the provisions of the
franchise agreement shall govern, but only to the extent of such conflict.
(Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-4: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person including, without limitation, any utility company, shall install a
utility line within the right of way without having first received a written
permit from the director. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-5: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Any person wishing to install a utility line within the right of way or retain
an existing utility line after expiration of an existing permit or existing
authority shall first make application to the director on such form as may be
determined by the director. All applications shall set forth at least the
following information and include the following items:
   A.   The name, address and telephone number of the applicant.
   B.   The location or locations in the right of way where the applicant
proposes to install or retain utility lines. In connection therewith the
applicant shall append to the application scale drawings showing detail
satisfactory to the director, which drawings indicate the proposed location and
depth of the utility lines which the applicant wishes to install or retain.
   C.   A description of the nature and purpose of the utility lines which the
applicant wishes to install or retain.
   D.   A written traffic control plan demonstrating the protective measures
and devices that will be employed consistent with the Illinois "Manual On
Uniform Traffic Control Devices" to prevent injury or damage to persons or
property and to minimize disruptions to efficient pedestrian and vehicular
traffic.
   E.   Evidence of insurance as required in this chapter.
   F.   Such additional information as may be reasonably required by the city.
   G.   The signature of the applicant. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-6: CONSIDERATION OF APPLICATION:
Upon receipt of a completed application to install a utility line, the director
shall determine whether or not the proposed utility line will interfere with
the operation, maintenance or extension of any city service line or with any
utility line already installed in the right of way. The director shall also
determine whether or not the installation operation or maintenance of any
proposed utility line will substantially interfere with the intended use of the
right of way or will increase the risk of injury to persons or property or will
significantly interfere with the ability of adjoining property owners to use
and enjoy their property. If in evaluating this application the director
requires professional assistance from either the city engineer or from any
other professional consultant, the director shall notify the applicant of his
need for such services. The applicant shall thereafter become responsible for
the payment of reasonable expenses incurred by the city in connection with the
employment of such engineer or other professional consultant. The director
shall not issue a permit authorizing the installation of the proposed utility
lines until all such fees have been paid in full. If, based upon the standards
in this section, the director determines that the proposed utility lines will
have no adverse impact and if the applicant first complies with all other
requirements imposed under the terms of this chapter or under the terms of any
franchise agreement to which the applicant is a party, then the director shall
issue a permit authorizing the installation of the proposed utility lines.
(Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-7: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
As a condition to applying for, accepting and retaining a permit under the
provisions of this chapter, all persons owning a controlling utility line in
the right of way shall comply with the provisions of this chapter as it now
exists or may from time to time be hereinafter amended. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-8: PERMIT FEES:
Unless the utility company enters into or has entered into a franchise
agreement calling for an alternate method of computing permit fees or unless
the utility company is a properly registered telecommunications provider under
title 3, chapter 7 of this code who generates and pays an infrastructure
maintenance fee due under said title 3, chapter 7 of this code, all persons
receiving permits shall pay fees computed as follows:
   A.   If the total length of the utility lines installed or to be installed
in the right of way is less than two hundred (200) linear feet, the applicant
shall prior to issuance of a permit pay a one time fee of one dollar seventy
five cents ($1.75) per linear foot of utility line to be installed in the right
of way.
   B.   If the total length of the utility lines installed or to be installed
in the right of way is two hundred (200) or more linear feet, then the
applicant shall pay an annual fee of seventy five cents ($0.75) per linear foot
of utility line installed in the right of way. The first such payment, prorated
to the end of the year thereof, shall be made prior to or upon issuance of a
permit. Subsequent annual payments shall be made by the owner or operator of
the utility line on January 2 of each calendar year thereafter. (Ord. 547, 11-
9-1998)
4-8-9: ADJUSTMENT OF ANNUAL COMPENSATION:
The rates of compensation specified in subsection 4-8-8B of this chapter shall
be adjusted in five (5) year intervals every fifth January 2 following issuance
of the permit. The adjustment shall be made by multiplying the then existing
permit fee times a percentage factor equal to the overall change in the
consumer price index during the five (5) years immediately preceding the
adjustment date. The consumer price index to be used shall be that published
for the Chicago metropolitan statistical area by the United States department
of labor. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-10: MANNER OF INSTALLATION:
Utility lines shall be installed, maintained and repaired in such a manner that
they do not unreasonably interfere with any use of the right of way made by the
city or by the general public or with any city service line already in place.
Upon completion of any excavations, both the owner of the utility line and the
excavator, if different from the owner, shall leave the surface of the ground
in substantially the same condition as existed prior to such excavation. All
streets, sidewalks and other pavement disturbed during the installation of a
utility line shall be restored to a condition substantially the same as that
which existed prior to the disturbance. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-11: CONTINUING LIABILITY:
In the event that authority to install or maintain utility lines in the right
of way is terminated or expires or in the event that the person who originally
installed the utility line transfers title, the original owner as well as any
subsequent title holders shall, nevertheless, remain liable to the city under
the provisions of this chapter until all utility lines located in the right of
way are removed and the right of way is restored as required in this chapter.
(Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-12: INDEMNIFICATION:
The owner of any utility line located in the right of way shall indemnify and
save harmless the city and its officers, employees and agents from and against
any and all claims and liabilities of whatever nature arising from the
installation, operation, maintenance or repair of the utility lines installed
by or on behalf of the owner and shall save and keep harmless the city from any
and all damages, judgments, costs and expenses of every kind that may arise by
reason thereof including, without limitation, attorney fees and costs incurred
by the city. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-13: WAIVER OF CLAIMS AGAINST CITY:
Any person who installs or has installed utility lines within the right of way
shall, as a condition to continuation of that person's authority to maintain
utility lines in the right of way, hold harmless and indemnify the city against
any and all damages and claims arising out of injury to the utility lines
installed, operated or maintained by such person. Such person shall as a
further and additional condition be taken to waive all claims against the city
howsoever arising for any and all damages direct or indirect resulting from
injury to such person's utility lines, which injury is caused in whole or in
part by the city, its officers, employees and agents. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-14: INSURANCE:
Each utility company installing or maintaining any utility line in the right of
way shall, unless otherwise provided by franchise, license or other similar
agreement, secure and maintain the following liability insurance policies
showing the utility company as a named insured:
   A.   Commercial general liability insurance including premises operations,
explosion collapse and underground hazard coverages and products completed
operations coverage with limits not less than:
      1.   Five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death to
each person;
      2.   Five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) for property damage resulting
from any one accident; and
      3.   Five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) for all other types of
liability.
   B.   Automobile liability for owned, nonowned and hired vehicles with a
combined single limit of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for personal
injury and property damage for each accident.
   C.   Workers' compensation with statutory limits; and
   D.   Employers' liability insurance with limits of not less than one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) per employee per accident.
The policies listed in subsections A and B of this section shall contain an
endorsement naming the city and its elected and appointed officers, officials,
agents and employees as additional insureds. Such endorsement shall provide
that the insurer may not cancel or decline to renew the policies until thirty
(30) days after receipt by the city of written notice of such cancellation or
nonrenewal addressed to the mayor of the city which notice is sent by
registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. The provision of
insurance as required by this section shall in no way limit any other
obligations imposed on the utility company under the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-15: EMERGENCY RESPONSE:
Any person operating or maintaining utility lines in the right of way shall
either become a member of the joint utility locating information for excavators
system (JULIE) or, alternatively, provide the city on an annual basis in
writing a phone number where a representative of that person can be reached at
any time on any day of the year. All such persons shall respond to a request
for emergency location of utility lines within one hour after the request by
the city either through the JULIE system or through the phone number provided
to the city. In the event that the owner of the utility line fails to respond
to such an emergency request within one hour, the director is authorized and
directed to proceed with the repair without input from the owner. If at the
request of a utility company, the city delays commencing an emergency repair,
the utility company responsible for the delay shall pay to the city the cost of
the equipment, labor and loss of service or product resulting from the delay.
(Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-16: RELOCATION OF LINES:
If the director determines that a utility line unreasonably interferes with the
operation, maintenance, repair or extension of any city service line, then upon
written request from the director, the owner of the utility line shall at the
expense of the owner relocate the utility line. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-17: TERMINATION OF AUTHORITY:
The authority of all persons to maintain a utility line on right of way,
whether installed before or after the enactment of this chapter, shall expire
on October 26, 2013, or on the fifteenth anniversary of the permit authorizing
installation of the utility line, whichever is later. Upon termination of
authority to maintain a utility line in the right of way by expiration or
otherwise, the owner of the utility line shall, without cost or expense to the
city, remove the utility line and restore the right of way to a condition
substantially the same as existed prior to removal, all under the supervision
of the director. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-18: REMOVAL OF LINES:
In the event that the owner of the utility line fails, neglects or refuses to
remove or relocate a utility line required to be removed or relocated under the
provisions of this chapter, the city may either perform the work and charge the
cost thereof to the owner or pursue any other remedies provided by law. (Ord.
547, 11-9-1998)
4-8-19: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
The authority of any utility company or other person to maintain a utility line
on the right of way may be revoked or terminated by the city if the owner fails
or neglects to comply with any provision of this chapter within thirty (30)
days following written notification from the director to the owner of the
utility line. (Ord. 547, 11-9-1998)
CHAPTER 9
TELECOMMUNICATIONS TOWERS AND EQUIPMENT
SECTION:
4-9-1: Short Title
4-9-2: Purpose
4-9-3: Definitions
4-9-4: Collocation Requirements
4-9-5: Construction Requirements
4-9-6: Tower And Antenna Design Requirements
4-9-7: Setbacks
4-9-8: Height
4-9-9: Lighting
4-9-10: Signs And Advertising
4-9-11: Accessory Utility Buildings
4-9-12: Abandoned, Unused Or Portions Of Towers
4-9-13: Interference With Public Safety Telecommunications
4-9-14: Application Materials
4-9-15: Conflict And Severability
4-9-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the TELECOMMUNICATIONS TOWER AND EQUIPMENT CODE
OF THE CITY OF MARQUETTE HEIGHTS, ILLINOIS, and may be so cited and pleaded and
shall be referred to herein as this chapter. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-2: PURPOSE:
The primary intent of this chapter is to regulate telecommunications towers and
equipment to be located within the city. Therefore, the purpose of this chapter
shall be to:
   A.   Comply with all federal and state regulations regarding the placement,
use, and maintenance of telecommunications towers and equipment.
   B.   Encourage the continued improvement of wireless telecommunications
service in the city.
   C.   Minimize, to the extent permitted by law, the proliferation of
unsightly towers and equipment throughout the city.
   D.   Promote both proper maintenance and renovation of telecommunications
equipment.
   E.   Encourage the use of collocation of telecommunications towers by
multiple providers so as to reduce the number of towers needed within the city.
   F.   Ensure that these regulations are compatible with the zoning
regulations.
   G.   Recognize the commercial communication requirements of all sectors of
the business and residential community. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and terms, when used in this chapter, shall have the
following meanings unless the context clearly indicates that a different
meaning is intended:
ANTENNA: Any structure or device not exceeding fifteen feet (15') in height
which is used for the purpose of collecting or transmitting electromagnetic
waves, including, but not limited to, directional antennas, such as panels,
microwave dishes, and satellite dishes and omnidirectional antennas, such as
whip antennas.
COMMERCIAL WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATION SERVICES: Licensed commercial wireless
telecommunication services, including cellular, personal communication services
(PCS), specialized mobilized radio (SMR), enhanced specialized mobilized radio
(ESMR), paging, and similar services that are marketed to the general public.
TOWER: Any ground or roof mounted pole, spire, antenna, structure, or
combination thereof taller than fifteen feet (15'), including supporting lines,
cables, wires, braces and masts, intended primarily for the purpose of mounting
an antenna, meteorological device, or similar apparatus above grade.
TOWER, MULTIUSER: A tower to which is attached the antennas of more than one
commercial wireless telecommunication service provider or governmental entity.
TOWER, SINGLE USER: A tower to which is attached only the antennas of a single
user, although the tower may be designed to accommodate the antennas of
multiple users as required in this chapter. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-4: COLLOCATION REQUIREMENTS:
All commercial wireless telecommunication towers erected, constructed, or
located within the city shall comply with the following requirements:
   A.   A proposal for a new commercial wireless telecommunication service
tower shall not be approved unless the city council finds that the
telecommunications equipment planned for the proposed tower cannot be
accommodated on an existing or approved tower or building within a one mile
search radius of the proposed tower due to one or more of the following
reasons:
      1.   The planned equipment would exceed the structural capacity of all
existing or approved towers or buildings, as documented by a qualified and
licensed professional engineer, and all of the existing or approved towers
cannot be reinforced, modified, or replaced to accommodate the planned or
equivalent equipment at a reasonable cost.
      2.   The planned equipment would cause interference materially impacting
the usability of other existing or planned equipment at a tower or building as
documented by a qualified and licensed professional engineer and interference
cannot be prevented at a reasonable cost.
      3.   Existing or approved towers and buildings within the search radius
cannot accommodate the planned equipment at a height necessary to function
reasonably as documented by a qualified and licensed professional engineer.
      4.   Other unforeseen reasons that make it unfeasible to locate the
planned telecommunications equipment upon an existing or approved tower or
building.
   B.   Any proposed commercial wireless telecommunication service tower shall
be designed structurally, electrically, and in all other respects, to
accommodate both the applicant's antennas and comparable antennas for at least
two (2) additional users if the tower is over one hundred feet (100') in
height, or for at least one additional user if the tower is over sixty feet
(60') in height. Towers must be designed to allow for future rearrangement of
antennas upon the tower and to accept antennas mounted at varying heights.
(Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-5: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permits:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to erect,
construct in a place, place or reerect, replace or repair any tower to be
utilized for commercial wireless telecommunication services without first
making application to the city and securing a permit therefor as hereinafter
provided.
      2.   The applicant shall provide, at the time of application, sufficient
information to indicate that construction, installation and maintenance of the
antenna and tower will not create a safety hazard or damage to the property of
other persons.
   B.   Fee: The applicant shall pay a building permit fee in the amount of two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   C.   Construction Requirements: All antennas and towers to be utilized for
commercial wireless telecommunication services erected, constructed or modified
within the city and all wiring therefor, shall comply with the following
requirements:
      1.   All applicable provisions of this code.
      2.   The tower shall be certified by a qualified and licensed
professional engineer to conform to the latest structural standards and wind
loading requirements of the national building code (BOCA) and the Electronics
Industry Association.
      3.   With the exception of necessary electric and telephone service
connection lines, no part of any antenna or tower, nor any lines, cable,
equipment or wires or braces in connection with either shall at any time extend
across or over any part of the right of way, public street, highway, sidewalk,
or property line.
      4.   Towers and associated antennas shall be designed to conform with
accepted electrical engineering methods and practices and to comply with the
provisions of the national electrical code.
      5.   All signal and remote control conductors of low energy extending
substantially horizontally above the ground between a tower and antenna and a
structure, or between towers, shall be at least eight feet (8') above the
ground at all points unless buried underground.
      6.   Every tower affixed to the ground shall be protected to discourage
climbing of the tower by unauthorized persons.
      7.   All towers shall be constructed to conform with the requirements of
the occupational safety and health administration.
      8.   Antennas and towers shall not be erected in residential zoning
districts in violation of the following restrictions:
         a.   Notwithstanding the general provisions of this chapter, and the
applicable provisions of title 5 of this code relating to zoning, the required
setback for an antenna or tower attached directly to the ground shall be equal
to the height of the antenna and tower. Those antennas and towers attached to a
building and whose base is not on the ground, may be constructed if set back a
distance equal to the height of the tower less the distance from the point of
attachment on the building to the ground.
         b.   No tower shall exceed a height equal to the distance from the
base of the antenna and tower to the nearest overhead electrical power line
which serves more than one dwelling or place of business. Those antennas and
towers originally attached to a building, and whose base is not on the ground,
shall not exceed an overall height from the point of attachment to the top of
tower which is greater than the distance from the point of attachment to the
nearest overhead electrical power line serving more than one dwelling or
business.
         c.   Metal towers shall be constructed of, or treated with, corrosive
resistant material. Wood poles shall be impregnated with rot resistant
substances.
         d.   The applicant will provide a written statement from a licensed
engineer certifying that the applicant will be prohibited from providing
commercial wireless telecommunication services unless a tower is constructed in
a residential zoning district.
   D.   Existing Antennas And Towers: Antennas and towers in existence as of
December 15, 1998, which do not conform to or comply with this chapter are
subject to the following provisions:
      1.   Towers may continue in use for the purpose now used and as now
existing, but may not be replaced or structurally altered without complying in
all respects with this chapter.
      2.   If such towers are hereafter damaged or destroyed due to any reason
or cause whatsoever, the tower may be repaired and restored to its former use,
location, and physical dimensions upon obtaining a building permit therefor,
but without otherwise complying with this section; provided, however, that if
the cost of repairing the tower to the former use, physical dimensions, and
location would be ten percent (10%) or more of the cost of a new tower of like
kind and quality, then the tower may not be repaired or restored, except in
full compliance with this chapter. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-6: TOWER AND ANTENNA DESIGN REQUIREMENTS:
Proposed or modified towers and antennas shall meet the following design
requirements:
   A.   Towers and antennas shall be designed to blend into the surrounding
environment through the use of color and camouflaging architectural treatment,
except in instances where the color is dictated by federal or state
authorities, such as the federal aviation administration. For the purpose of
this subsection, camouflaging architectural treatment shall consist of
disguising the applicable tower as an object which would otherwise be fully
consistent with the surrounding area, such as a tree, church steeple, or
building spire, as appropriate. The camouflaging shall disguise the existence
of the tower, while retaining the natural or improved appearance of the
surrounding area, to the maximum extent possible.
   B.   Commercial wireless telecommunication service towers shall be of a
monopole design unless the city council determines that an alternative design
would better blend into the surrounding environment. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-7: SETBACKS:
Towers shall conform with each of the following minimum setback requirements:
   A.   Generally: Towers shall meet the setback requirements of buildings
found in the underlying zoning district unless otherwise specified herein;
provided, however, no tower shall be set back a distance less than fifty
percent (50%) of its height from the top of tower to existing grade or, if the
tower was originally attached to a building, to the point of attachment.
   B.   Residential Zoning Districts: Towers shall meet the setback
requirements provided in subsection 4-9-5C8 of this chapter. (Ord. 549, 12-14-
1998)
4-9-8: HEIGHT:
Towers shall not exceed one hundred twenty five feet (125') in height from
existing grade or, if attached to an existing building, one hundred fifty feet
(150') less the distance from the existing grade to the point of attachment. A
variation to this height requirement may be granted by the zoning board of
appeals after receiving an application therefor and holding a public hearing at
a regularly scheduled or special meeting. Notice of the time and place of the
hearing, together with a brief description of the subject matter shall be
published one time not more than thirty (30) nor less than fifteen (15) days
prior to the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. A
variation from the height requirement in this section shall be granted by the
zoning board of appeals only if the applicant establishes by clear and
convincing evidence that it will be unable to provide wireless communication
services without such a variation. Under no circumstance shall a tower be
erected to a height greater than that required to provide wireless
communication services. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-9: LIGHTING:
Towers shall not be illuminated by artificial means and shall not display any
strobe or flashing lights unless such lighting is required by the federal
aviation administration or other federal or state authority for a particular
tower. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-10: SIGNS AND ADVERTISING 1 :
Signs displaying warning or equipment information and meeting reasonable size
limitations may be placed on towers. All other signs, including signs used for
advertising purposes, are prohibited. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 5-15-3A2 of this code.
4-9-11: ACCESSORY UTILITY BUILDINGS:
All utility buildings and structures accessory to a tower shall be
architecturally designed to blend in with the surrounding environment. Further,
such buildings shall meet minimum setback requirements of the underlying zoning
district. Ground mounted equipment shall be screened from view by suitable
vegetation and/or landscaping, except where a design of nonvegetative screening
better reflects and complements the architectural character of the surrounding
area, in which case, such nonvegetative screening shall be utilized. (Ord. 549,
12-14-1998)
4-9-12: ABANDONED, UNUSED OR PORTIONS OF TOWERS:
Abandoned or unused towers or portions of towers shall be removed as follows:
   A.   All abandoned or unused towers and associated facilities shall be
removed within six (6) months of the cessation of operations at a site unless a
time extension is required, in writing, by the person or entity owning such
tower and/or facility, in which case such person or entity shall be allowed an
additional six (6) months to remove the applicable tower and/or facility. A
copy of the relevant portions of a signed lease which requires the applicant to
remove the tower and associated facilities upon cessation of operations at the
site shall be submitted at the time of application. In the event that a tower
is not removed in a timely manner as provided herein, the tower and associated
facilities may be removed by the city and the cost of removal assessed against
the property.
   B.   Unused portions of towers above utilized communications or other
electrical equipment shall be removed within six (6) months of the time of
antenna relocation. The replacement of portions of a tower previously removed
requires the issuance of a new building permit and special use permit as
applicable. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-13: INTERFERENCE WITH PUBLIC SAFETY TELECOMMUNICATIONS:
No new or existing telecommunication service shall interfere with public safety
telecommunications. All applications for new service shall be accompanied by an
intermodulation study which provides a technical evaluation of existing and
proposed transmissions and indicates all potential interference problems.
Before the introduction of new services or changes in existing service,
telecommunication providers shall notify the city at least ten (10) calendar
days in advance of such changes and allow the city to monitor interference
levels during the testing process. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-14: APPLICATION MATERIALS:
An application to construct a tower shall include written documentation
evidencing compliance with each provision of this chapter as well as the
applicable zoning regulations together with the following supplemental
information:
   A.   A report from a qualified and licensed professional engineer which:
      1.   Describes the tower height and design, including a cross section in
elevation;
      2.   Documents the height above grade for all potential mounting
positions for collocated antennas and the minimum separation distances between
antennas;
      3.   Describes the tower's capacity, including the number and type of
antennas that it can accommodate;
      4.   Documents what steps the applicant will take to avoid interference
with established public safety telecommunications;
      5.   Includes an engineer's stamp and registration number;
      6.   Includes other information necessary to evaluate the request.
   B.   Architectural drawings depicting the constructed tower with
camouflaging treatment set in the surrounding area. These drawings shall
include at least one perspective from the north, south, east and west.
   C.   An overhead map of the city showing the subject tower's location as
well as the location of each of the applicant's existing and planned future
tower sites.
   D.   For all commercial wireless telecommunication service towers, a letter
of intent committing the tower owner and his or her successors to allow the
shared use of the tower if an additional user agrees in writing to meet
reasonable terms and conditions for shared use.
   E.   Before the issuance of a building permit, the following supplemental
information shall be provided:
      1.   Proof that the proposed tower complies with regulations administered
by the federal aviation administration; and
      2.   Proof that the proposed tower complies with the emission standards
promulgated by the federal communications commission; and
      3.   Report from a qualified and licensed professional engineer which
demonstrates the tower's compliance with the aforesaid structural and
electrical standards. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
4-9-15: CONFLICT AND SEVERABILITY:
   A.   Conflict: If any portion of this chapter is found to be in conflict
with any other provision of any zoning, building, fire safety, or other
ordinance of this code, the provision which establishes the higher standard
shall prevail.
   B.   Severability: If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of
this chapter or its application to any person or circumstance is held invalid
by the decision of any court or administrative tribunal of competent
jurisdiction, the remainder of this chapter, or the application of the
provision to other persons or circumstances is in effect and shall remain in
full force and effect. (Ord. 549, 12-14-1998)
CHAPTER 10
EROSION, SEDIMENT AND STORMWATER CONTROL
SECTION:
4-10-1: Definitions
4-10-2: Applicability
4-10-3: Permanent Control Measures
4-10-4: Temporary Control Measures
4-10-5: Small Site Control Permits
4-10-6: Large Site Control Permits
4-10-7: Maintenance Of Permanent Stormwater Control Measures
4-10-8: Enforcement And Stop Work Order
4-10-9: Penalty
4-10-10: Appeals Board
4-10-11: Appeals To Appeals Board
4-10-12: Appeals To Court
4-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
ADJACENT LANDS: Land surrounding a site that may either substantially impact
that site, or be substantially impacted by potential soil erosion, sediment
and/or stormwater runoff as a result of land disturbing activities conducted on
that site.
APPEALS BOARD: The erosion, sediment and stormwater control appeals board.
AREAS OF CONCENTRATED FLOW OR BODIES OF WATER: Any area where water may
accumulate or flow, whether continual or as the result of a storm event,
including, but not limited to, lakes, rivers, streams, creeks, ponds, ditches,
swales, gullies, ravines, street gutters and other similar features.
CITY: The city of Marquette Heights, Tazewell County, Illinois.
CONTROL MEASURE: Any proposed temporary or permanent measures to be installed
to control erosion, sediment and stormwater runoff from a project area.
DEVELOPMENT: The division of a parcel of land into two (2) or more parcels; the
construction, reconstruction, conversion, structural alteration, relocation, or
enlargement of any structure; any mining, excavation, landfill, or land
disturbing activity; and any use or extension of the use of land.
DISTURBED AREA: Any area of land on which the predevelopment ground surface
will be affected or altered by development. This includes, but is not limited
to, grading, clearing, stockpiling, tracking and other similar activities.
EROSION CONTROL ADMINISTRATOR: The street superintendent, or other person
appointed by the city council of the city to administer this chapter.
5-YEAR FREQUENCY STORM EVENT: The rainfall intensity, in a twenty four (24)
hour period, with the probability of being equaled or exceeded once in a five
(5) year period.
FLOOD INSURANCE RATE MAPS (FIRM): Maps prepared by the federal emergency
management agency (FEMA) that depict the special flood hazard areas (SFHA)
within a community. These maps include insurance rate zones and floodplains and
may or may not depict floodways.
INSTITUTIONAL USE: A religious, or public use, such as a church, library,
public or private school, hospital, or government owned or operated building,
structure or land use for public purpose.
LAND DISTURBING ACTIVITY: Any change in land within the city, which may result
in soil erosion from water or wind and the movement of sediments into waters of
the state or onto lands in the city, or a change in the amount and/or intensity
of stormwater runoff, including, but not limited to, the covering with an
impervious surface, stockpiling, clearing, grading, excavating, rehabilitating,
transporting, depositing or filling of land.
LARGE SITE PLAN: Any land disturbing activity which affects an area of more
than one acre or a project requiring subdivision approval by the city.
NORMAL AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES: Activities associated with the preparation and
tilling of land for the purposes of growing crops, or raising livestock, which
may include, but are not limited to, the construction of conservation measures,
plowing, disking and cultivating.
PERIMETER CONTROL: Any control measure installed between the downslope side of
the disturbed area and the property line and/or between the downslope side of
the disturbed area and any area of concentrated flow.
PREPROJECT CONDITION: The characteristics of a site prior to the initiation of
any land disturbing activity. The preproject condition shall be based on the
predominant land use for the past five (5) years. For example, if a site has
been cropland for four (4) of the past five (5) years, and in grass just prior
to development, the land use would be cropland for the preproject condition.
PROJECT: Any development involving modification to land which involves a land
disturbing activity.
REGIONAL STORMWATER MANAGEMENT SYSTEM: A system which is designed, constructed,
and maintained to provide stormwater control for multiple landowners.
ROAD: Any right of way that has been improved for the purposes of providing a
surface for vehicular traffic, including any federal, state, county, township,
and municipal controlled facilities.
SINGLE-FAMILY DWELLING: A building designed for residential occupancy by one
family.
SITE: The lot or parcel on which the project is to be developed.
SMALL SITE PLAN: Any land disturbing activity which involves modification to
land where such modification affects an area of five thousand (5,000) square
feet or greater but less than one acre.
STANDARDS: The Illinois environmental protection agency's "Illinois Urban
Manual", a technical manual designed by urban ecosystem protection and
enhancement published in 1995, and Illinois procedures and standards for urban
soil erosion and sedimentation control published in 1988, by the urban
committee of the Association of Illinois Soil and Water Conservation Districts
now in effect or as hereafter amended, which is incorporated by reference
herein, and the city standards for stormwater design analysis, found in
appendix A of the ordinance codified herein available for inspection in the
office of the city clerk, and the erosion and sediment control criteria and
specifications found in appendix B of the ordinance codified herein available
for inspection in the office of the city clerk.
SUBSTANTIAL COMPLETION: The point at which all exterior work is completed and
the site can be used for the use intended.
25-YEAR FREQUENCY STORM EVENT: The rainfall intensity, in a twenty four (24)
hour period, with the probability of being equaled or exceeded once in a twenty
five (25) year period.
TWO-FAMILY DWELLING: A building designed for residential occupancy by two (2)
families.
2-YEAR FREQUENCY STORM EVENT: The rainfall intensity, in a twenty four (24)
hour period, with the probability of being equaled or exceeded in a two (2)
year period.
UTILITY SERVICE LINE: Means by which utility service is provided to service
users, such as electric, telephone and television cable, or gas, water and
sewer pipes.
WORKING DAY: Shall not include Saturday, Sunday or any holiday when city
offices are closed. (Ord. 591, 9-9-2000)
4-10-2: APPLICABILITY:
   A.   Before commencing any project involving construction of any new
residential dwelling, commencing any project with an area of five thousand
(5,000) square feet or greater or any commercial project regardless of size,
the owner of the land, or his representative, shall be required to file an
application for an erosion, sediment and stormwater control permit, as either a
small or large site plan, except as follows:
      1.   Land disturbing activities for which the disturbed area is less than
five thousand (5,000) square feet; or
      2.   Projects undertaken by the city's department of public works; or
      3.   Routine maintenance of roads and utility service lines; or
      4.   Any land within the boundaries or jurisdiction of the city on which
there is located a permanent stormwater control measure which was installed
pursuant to this chapter.
The erosion control administrator reserves the right to require any land
disturbing activity, regardless of size of disturbed area or type of activity,
to comply with this chapter if it is determined to be the cause of, or a
contributor to substantial existing or potential erosion, sediment, or
stormwater impact. (Ord. 591, 9-9-2000)
4-10-3: PERMANENT CONTROL MEASURES:
   A.   Erosion And Sediment Control Measures: All control measures required
under this chapter shall conform to the design criteria, standards, and
specifications provided in the applicable standards, referenced in appendix B
of the ordinance codified herein available for inspection in the office of the
city clerk, now in effect or as hereafter amended. All control measures
installed shall be sufficient to prevent observable sediment from leaving the
site during a 5-year frequency storm event. When observable sediment does leave
the site, the owner, developer or contractor shall remove the sediment within
twenty four (24) hours, or by no later than the end of the next working day
whichever occurs later.
   B.   Permanent Stormwater Control Measures: Stormwater detention facilities
shall be designed for a minimum 25-year frequency storm event. Each stormwater
detention area shall be provided with a method of emergency overflow in the
event that a rainfall event in excess of a 25-year frequency storm event
occurs. This emergency overflow facility shall be designed to function without
attention or maintenance. Detention facilities shall be designed to have a dry
bottom except when inundated immediately following a storm event. The
stormwater runoff rate from the site shall not exceed the stormwater runoff
rate from the site in its preproject condition.
   C.   Regional Stormwater Control Systems: To allow for the beneficial
development and maintenance of regional stormwater management systems, where
they are available and they are appropriate, an applicant may submit a design
dependent on such a system. The applicant may submit documentation of the
approval for the use of the regional stormwater management facility from the
governmental agency having jurisdiction over it. The applicant shall submit
evidence showing that there will be no adverse flooding impact to any receiving
stream between the point of discharge and the regional stormwater facility. If
the erosion control administrator approves the use of a regional stormwater
management system, the applicant shall be exempt from the requirements in this
section for permanent on site stormwater controls. Such exemption shall not
apply to any temporary stormwater control measures required by this chapter.
(Ord. 591, 9-9-2000)
4-10-4: TEMPORARY CONTROL MEASURES:
   A.   Temporary Control Measures Required: On site sediment control measures
shall be constructed and functional prior to initiating land disturbing
activities on the site.
Fully functioning temporary sediment control measures (including, but not
limited to, perimeter sediment controls) shall remain in place until the ground
is stabilized with permanent ground cover. In cases where it is not practical
to leave the temporary sediment control measures in place prior to establishing
permanent ground cover (for example when control measures need to be removed in
order to grade the area or install pavement or sod) an exception will be made
only if one of the conditions listed below will be met. In no way does adhering
to one of the conditions below relieve the owner of responsibility to clean up
or repair any damages caused from sediment or stormwater runoff leaving the
site.
      1.   Permanent ground cover shall be established with pavement, aggregate
or sod within three (3) working days of the removal of temporary sediment
barriers; or
      2.   Permanent vegetation shall be established by seeding with anchored
mulch within three (3) working days of removal of sediment barriers during the
spring or fall seeding periods. However, on project areas with slopes not
exceeding five percent (5%), permanent vegetation shall be established by
seeding within five (5) working days of the removal of sediment barriers during
the spring or fall seeding periods. Summer seeding is acceptable on project
areas which shall be watered. This does not apply to concentrated flow areas.
   B.   Maintenance: Sediment control measures and temporary stormwater control
measures are to be maintained so they are operating effectively until permanent
ground surface protection and permanent stormwater control measures are
established in a manner specified in the applicable permit issued pursuant to
this chapter.
   C.   Additional Control Measures: The erosion control administrator may
require additional control measures pursuant to the standards if determined as
necessary after site inspection, and prior to issuing the permit. (Ord. 591, 9-
9-2000)
4-10-5: SMALL SITE CONTROL PERMITS:
Before commencing any project which involves modification to land where such
modification affects an area of five thousand (5,000) square feet or greater
but less than one acre, the owner of the land, or his representative, shall
file an application for a small site erosion sediment and stormwater control
permit, accompanied by either a small or large site plan, except as otherwise
provided in sections
4-10-2 and
4-10-6 of this chapter.
   A.   Application: The applicant shall file the application with the city
clerk on forms provided by the city. The fee for a small site plan application
shall be in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each permit. However, no
fee shall be required for any project the purpose of which is agricultural, or
initiated by a local unit of government. There shall be no refund of any fees
paid and no application shall be accepted for filing unless the fee has been
paid in full.
   B.   Application Review: Review of an application for a small site erosion
and sediment control permit shall be limited to verifying that the required
information has been provided and that it meets the standards. The erosion
control administrator shall issue or deny an application by: 1) approving the
permit for a small site plan within ten (10) working days of the filing of a
complete application; or 2) initiate the review process for a large site plan
and approve the same within twenty (20) working days of the filing of a
complete application. If the permit is denied, it shall be returned to the
applicant with a written explanation of its denial. The application shall be
deemed approved if no response is made within the time frames provided above.
   C.   Duration: The small site erosion, sediment and stormwater control
permit shall expire upon completion of the project or one year from the date of
issuance, whichever first occurs.
   D.   Stormwater Control Measures Applicable To Certain Nonresidential Uses:
With respect to any site to be developed for any use other than a one- or two-
family dwelling, the applicant shall submit a site plan showing the location of
stormwater detention facilities to be constructed in compliance with the
provisions of this chapter and shall provide the calculations upon which the
size, location and operation of those facilities were based.
   E.   Content Of Small Site Erosion, Sediment And Stormwater Control Permit:
The small site erosion, sediment and stormwater control permit shall contain at
a minimum the following general conditions:
      1.   That written approval be obtained from the erosion control
administrator prior to making any modification to the erosion, sediment and
stormwater control plan as set forth in the application; and
      2.   That all control measures identified in the application shall be
installed; and
      3.   That all control measures shall be maintained during construction;
and
      4.   Such other conditions as the erosion control administrator deems
appropriate to ensure compliance with the specific requirements and the intent
of this chapter.
   F.   Permanent Ground Surface Cover: Under all circumstances, temporary
control measures shall be maintained in accordance with section
4-10-4 of this chapter. Without exception, all disturbed areas must have
permanent ground cover within six (6) months of project completion, or within
six (6) months of occupancy, whichever comes first. Temporary erosion control
measures shall remain in place until permanent ground cover has been
established. (Ord. 591, 9-9-2000)
   G.   Application Contents: Residential small site permit application shall
also include the following:
      1.   Direction of storm runoff from building structures.
      2.   Downspout locations and means of dispersal away from abutting
properties.
      3.   Any other permanent stormwater control measures as deemed necessary
by the erosion control administrator. (Ord. 730, 8-13-2007)
4-10-6: LARGE SITE CONTROL PERMITS:
Before commencing any project land disturbing activity which affects an area of
more than one acre, excluding normal agricultural practices; or a project
requiring subdivision approval by the city of Marquette Heights, the owner of
the land, or his representative, shall file an application for a large site
erosion, sediment, and stormwater control permit.
   A.   Application: The applicant shall file the application with the city
clerk on forms provided by the city. The applicant shall supply the number of
copies of application documents as provided in the application. Each
application shall be accompanied by the following information:
      1.   Site Map: A map of existing site conditions on a scale of at least
one inch equals one hundred feet (1" = 100'), showing the site and immediately
adjacent areas and the locations of the following site information:
         a.   Site boundaries and adjacent lands which accurately identify site
location;
         b.   Lakes, streams, wetlands, channels, ditches, and other
watercourses on and immediately adjacent to the site;
         c.   Floodways and/or zone A of the floodplain as determined on the
flood insurance rate map (FIRM), and indicating the map panel number;
         d.   All off site drainage onto or through the project site;
         e.   Location and dimensions of stormwater management systems on or
adjacent to the site;
         f.   Locations and dimensions of structures, roads, highways,
easements and paved areas; and
         g.   Site topography; show contours at vertical intervals as follows:
            (1)   Slope of six percent (6%) or less, two foot (2') intervals.
            (2)   Slope of over six percent (6%) but less than fifteen percent
(15%), five foot (5') intervals.
            (3)   Slope of over fifteen percent (15%), ten (10) or twenty foot
(20') intervals;
      2.   Plan Of Final Site Conditions: A plan of final site conditions drawn
to the same scale as the existing site map submitted pursuant to subsection A1
of this section, and which includes information to accurately depict
postconstruction appearance of site, e.g., paved areas, buildings, landscaping,
and other changes to the site, along with other predominant site features,
