   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to store or permit or allow the
storage of garbage on or about any premises in the city owned or occupied by
him except in a garbage can or dumpster with the lid in place.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to store or permit or allow the
storage of refuse or rubbish on or about any premises in the city owned or
occupied by him except in a container.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to store or permit or allow the
storage of mattresses, discarded furniture and appliances or any other rubbish,
refuse or other discarded material whereby its nature is unsuitable for storage
in a container, on or about any premises in the city owned or occupied by him
except for garbage collection purposes as set forth in subsection 8-3-3B of
this chapter. (Ord. 280, 4-26-1982)
8-3-3: PLACEMENT AND STORAGE OF CONTAINER:
   A.   Except as provided in subsection B of this section, containers shall at
all times be stored and kept within side and rear lot lines of any premises
owned or occupied by the person or persons who own or use such containers, and
containers shall further be stored and kept behind the front (and side for
corner lots) setback lines established for any structure on such premises.
(Ord. 280, 4-26-1982)
   B.   For garbage collection purposes only, containers (excluding dumpsters)
and materials described in subsection 8-3-2C of this chapter, may be placed in
the parkway area in front of any premises at or near the curb line no sooner
than the day preceding the regularly scheduled garbage collection day for such
premises and shall be removed no later than the day next following such
regularly scheduled garbage collection day. The regularly scheduled garbage
collection days shall be Monday and Tuesday. Wednesday will be the in lieu of
collection day if Monday or Tuesday is a holiday. (Ord. 756, 12-22-2008)
   C.   Except as provided in subsection B of this section, no privately owned
container shall be stored or kept in or on any street, sidewalk, alley or other
public place or public property within the city.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for any person, other than owner of the container,
occupant, tenant or members of their families, or a scavenger employed or
licensed by the city, or the owner's agent, employees or servants to deposit
any article, substance or thing in any container, or to remove, displace,
injure, deface, destroy, uncover or in any manner disturb such container or any
container that is placed at any curb line for collection. (Ord. 280, 4-26-1982)
   E.   Dumpsters located within either the A single-family dwelling district
or the B single-family larger homes district shall be governed by the following
restrictions:
      1.   Existing homes shall not have a dumpster remain on the residence for
a total of more than sixty (60) calendar days during any period of one hundred
eighty (180) consecutive calendar days.
      2.   New homes under construction shall not have a dumpster remain on the
residence for a total of more than sixty (60) calendar days after the issuance
of an occupancy permit.
The city council may grant exceptions, by the issuance of a permit allowing the
dumpster to remain on a property outside of these guidelines. (Ord. 715, 8-21-
2006)
8-3-4: LITTERING:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or allow any litter to
collect or accumulate on or about any premises in the city owned or occupied by
him or from which he operates a business, except in a properly placed
container.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit any litter upon
any private property or, in or upon any street, sidewalk, parkway (except for
garbage collection purposes as provided in subsection 8-3-3B of this chapter),
park or other public place or property within the city, except in public
receptacles or containers provided for such purposes.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to store or permit or allow the
exterior storage on or about any premises owned or occupied by him of any
bricks, concrete blocks, lumber or other building materials; except when the
storage of such brick, concrete block, lumber or other building materials is
necessarily incident to the remodeling or expansion of any structure located on
such premises and is kept at all times behind the front and side yard setback
lines established for any structure on said premises and when such storage does
not continue or exist for more than ninety (90) days. For the purposes of this
subsection, "exterior storage" shall mean the storage of any of the above
enumerated material or things outside of any structure located on the subject
premises. This section shall not apply to new construction. (Ord. 280, 4-26-
1982)
   D.   (Rep. by Ord. 672, 3-8-2004)
   E.   It shall be the duty of the police department, to enforce the
provisions of this chapter, and to notify persons violating the same to remove
the litter within forty eight (48) hours from the date of the service of the
notice.
Notice shall be given by means of personal service of a copy of the complaint
or by certified or registered mail of a copy of the complaint, which is
addressed to the residence or usual place of business of the owner or person in
control of the private property. Personal service shall be made by any police
officer of the police department or any person authorized by law to make
personal service.
   F.   The city may dispose of litter within forty eight (48) hours after the
proper individual has received written notice provided for in subsection E of
this section. If the notice provided for in subsection E of this section is
returned to the United States post office because of its inability to make
delivery thereof, the responsible city officials are hereby authorized and
empowered to dispose of such litter.
   G.   The cost and expense of removing and disposing of such litter from
private property shall be recoverable from the owner or owners of the real
estate and is a lien thereon, which lien shall be superior to all prior
existing liens and encumbrances except taxes; provided, however, that within
ninety (90) days after completion of the removing and disposing of litter, the
city attorney shall file a notice of lien for the cost and expense incurred by
the city, in the office of the recorder of deeds of Tazewell County. Upon
payment of said cost of removing and disposing of the litter, the lien shall be
released by the city attorney.
The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in case of mortgages or
mechanic's liens. Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced by the city
attorney within three (3) years after the date of filing of notice of lien.
If payment of the city's cost of removing and disposing of the litter is not
paid to the city within fifteen (15) days of the filing of the notice of lien,
the city attorney may commence proceedings in the circuit court seeking a
personal judgment from the owner of the subject property in the amount of said
costs. The action authorized by this subsection G shall be in addition to, and
without waiver of, any other remedies. (Ord. 280, 4-26-1982)
8-3-5: LITTERING; ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS:
   A.   No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other
public place within the city an accumulation of litter from any building or lot
or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying
property shall keep the sidewalk and city right of way in front of their
premises free of litter.
   B.   No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle shall throw or
deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city.
   C.   No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the
city unless such vehicle is so constructed and loaded as to prevent any load of
material or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or
other public place. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck
within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any
street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances or foreign
matter of any kind.
   D.   No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the
city any litter, handbill or any other object.
   E.   It shall be unlawful for any person to spill any turpentine, kerosene,
gasoline, benzine, naphtha, coal oil or any product thereof, or any oil for
lubricating, illuminating or fuel purposes, or to allow any of such fluid to
escape to or upon any asphalt or other pavement of the city, or to operate or
permit to be operated any tank wagon or other vehicle from which any of such
fluids are permitted to escape.
   F.   All persons hauling dirt, sand, gravel, cinders or other materials, or
any waste matter on streets or alleys, shall so construct and maintain their
vehicle as at all times to prevent the spilling of such material or matter from
the same. (Ord. 280, 4-26-1982)
8-3-6: DISTRIBUTION OF HANDBILLS AND ADVERTISING MATERIAL:
   A.   No person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any sidewalk,
street or other public place within the city. It shall not be unlawful on any
sidewalk, street or other public place within the city for any person to hand
out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any handbill to any
person willing to accept it.
   B.   No person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any vehicle;
however, it shall not be unlawful in any public place for a person to hand out
or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, a handbill to any
occupant of a vehicle who is willing to accept it.
   C.   No person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any private
premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant.
   D.   No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any handbill in or upon
private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any
such handbill directly to the owner, occupant or other person then present in
or upon private premises; provided, however, that in case of inhabited private
premises, such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do
so, shall have the authority to place or deposit any such handbill in or upon
such inhabited private premises, if such handbill is so placed or deposited as
to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such
premises or sidewalks, streets or other public places, and except that
mailboxes may not be used when so prohibited by federal postal law or
regulations.
   E.   No person shall paste, post, paint, nail or otherwise fasten any
handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind whatsoever or cause
the same to be done on any curbstone, flagstone or any other portion or part of
any sidewalk or street or upon any tree, lamppost, telephone pole, electric
light pole, hydrant, public litter receptacle, bridge, pier or upon any
structure within the right of way limits of any street or alley in the city
except as such may be permitted by this code or other ordinances of the city.
(Ord. 280, 4-26-1982)
      1.   Real estate signs advertising and directing towards open house
locations are permitted between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. on
Thursday through and until six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on Sunday. Signs must be of
a size, nature and location so as not to restrict the safe flow of traffic or
jeopardize pedestrians.
      2.   All signs must be freestanding and unattached to any tree, sign or
structure within the right of way limits of any street in the city. Any signs
not removed within the time guidelines may be removed by officers of the city
and disposed of. No signs allowed by the above conditions shall be permitted
within four hundred feet (400') of State Route 29 on LaSalle Boulevard.
      3.   The city council may approve permits that allow freestanding signs
to be placed along the right of way. The permit shall include the duration,
size and location of each sign. (Ord. 617, 12-10-2001)
   F.   No person shall paste, post, paint, print, nail or otherwise fasten any
handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind or cause the same
to be done upon any private wall, window, door, gate, fence, advertising board
or sign or upon any other private structure or building, unless he is the
owner, agent or lessee thereof, or without the consent, in writing of the owner
of such wall, window, fence, gate, advertising board or sign or other building
or structure. (Ord. 280, 4-26-1982; amd. Ord. 436, 11-23-1992)
8-3-7: PLACEMENT OF INDOOR FURNITURE OUTDOORS:
   A.   Except as provided in subsection B of this section, no person shall
place, use, keep, store or maintain outdoors any indoor furniture not
manufactured for outdoor use, including, but not limited to, upholstered chairs
and couches or mattresses designed for indoor bedding use. As used in this
section, "outdoors" means any place exposed to weather, including, but not
limited to, yards, porches, decks, patios, balconies and rooftops, but
excluding enclosed weatherproof porches.
   B.   Indoor furniture shall only be allowed to stay outdoors for a period
not to exceed thirty six (36) hours in any seven (7) day period, only under the
following circumstances:
      1.   When said indoor furniture is placed at the curb on the customary
collection day for it to be removed as part of bulky waste removal.
      2.   When said indoor furniture is placed outdoors as part of a garage
sale.
   C.   It shall be the duty of the police chief to serve or cause to be served
a notice upon the owner or occupant of any premises where a violation of this
section is occurring, and to demand abatement of the violation within twenty
four (24) hours. If the person so served fails to abate the violation within
twenty four (24) hours, the police chief, or any police officer under his
direction, shall commence enforcement proceedings against the owner or
occupant. (Ord. 623, 2-11-2002)
8-3-8: DISPOSAL AND STORAGE OF TREE WASTE:
   A.   Tree waste intended for use as a fuel may be neatly stored with regular
maintenance and kept free from other foliage and debris, on the exterior of any
structure, but shall at all times be kept and stored behind the front and side
yard setback lines established for any structure on such premises.
   B.   Tree waste may be placed in the parkway area in front of any premises
at or near the curb line no sooner than seven (7) days before the regularly
scheduled pick up published by the city. (Ord. 672, 3-8-2004)
CHAPTER 4
DELIVERY AND POSSESSION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS
SECTION:
8-4-1: Definitions
8-4-2: Delivery To And Possession Of By Minors
8-4-3: Penalties
8-4-4: Enforcement
8-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this chapter:
POSSESSION: To have upon one's person or have in close proximity to one's
person or in one's control.
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Cigarettes, cigars, smokeless tobacco (which means tobacco in
any form which is suitable for dipping and/or chewing), or in any other form,
(vape products). (Ord. 890, 7-8-2019)
8-4-2: DELIVERY TO AND POSSESSION OF BY MINORS:
   A.   Delivery Of Tobacco Products To Minors: It shall be unlawful for any
person, whether acting individually or acting through an owner, officer,
employee or agent, to sell, give, distribute, furnish, or deliver any tobacco
products in any form to any person under the age of twenty one (21) years old.
   B.   Possession Of Tobacco Products By A Minor: No person under twenty one
(21) years of age shall have in his or her possession any tobacco product in
any of its forms. It shall not be a violation of this section for any such
person to have tobacco products in his or her possession while in the presence
of his or her parents or legal guardian, or in the performance of a religious
ceremony or while participating in any theatrical performance where possession
of a tobacco product is necessary. (Ord. 890, 7-8-2019)
8-4-3: PENALTIES:
   A.   A violation of subsection
8-4-2A of this chapter is a petty offense and shall be punishable by a fine of
two hundred dollars ($200.00), four hundred dollars ($400.00) for the second
offense in a twelve (12) month period, and six hundred dollars ($600.00) for
the third or any subsequent offense in a twelve (12) month period.
   B.   A violation of subsection
8-4-2B of this chapter is a petty offense and shall be punishable by a fine of
one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense, and a fine not to exceed
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a second or subsequent offense; provided,
however, that in addition to or in lieu of a fine, a final disposition may
include community service and/or education regarding the effect of tobacco
products on the human body. (Ord. 890, 7-8-2019; amd. Ord. 909, 7- 13-2021)
8-4-4: ENFORCEMENT:
The observation of a violation of subsection
8-4-2B of this chapter shall not constitute the sole basis for law enforcement
authorities to stop a motor vehicle in which an alleged offender is a driver or
passenger. (Ord. 890, 7-8-2019)
CHAPTER 5
BODY PIERCING
SECTION:
8-5-1: Definitions
8-5-2: License Required
8-5-3: License Fee
8-5-4: Application For License
8-5-5: Licensed Physician Required
8-5-6: Violations
8-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the words and terms defined below shall have the
following meanings:
BODY PIERCING: Any procedure whereby a part or parts of the human body are
pierced by a sharp instrument in order to allow insertion of a piece or pieces
of jewelry, a ring or other ornamental device through the orifice thus created.
OPERATOR: Any individual, firm, company, corporation or association that owns
or operates an establishment where body piercing is performed for a fee or
performed in conjunction with the sale of jewelry, rings or other ornamental
devices inserted through orifices created by body piercing. (Ord. 532, 4-13-
1998)
8-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any operator or any agent of any operator to engage in
or offer to engage in body piercing unless the operator has first obtained a
license from the city. (Ord. 532, 4-13-1998)
8-5-3: LICENSE FEE:
Each operator shall pay a license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each
calendar year or part thereof during which such operator engages in or offers
to engage in body piercing. (Ord. 532, 4-13-1998)
8-5-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
All applications for a license to operate a body piercing establishment shall
be made in writing to the city clerk and shall be accompanied by the license
fee for the period for which the application is made. Any change of ownership
in such establishment shall require a new application and license with payment
of fees thereafter. (Ord. 532, 4-13-1998)
8-5-5: LICENSED PHYSICIAN REQUIRED:
Each operator must be licensed to practice medicine or osteopathic medicine in
the state of Illinois as set forth in the Illinois medical practice act of 1987
1  or any replacement legislation. All body piercing performed within such
establishment shall be either done by a licensed physician or osteopath or in
the presence and under the direct supervision of a licensed physician or
osteopath. This provision shall not apply to those lawfully engaged only in the
piercing of earlobes. (Ord. 532, 4-13-1998)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 60/1 et seq.
8-5-6: VIOLATIONS:
A violation of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine of not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each offense. (Ord. 532, 4-13-1998)
CHAPTER 6
TATTOOING BODY
SECTION:
8-6-1: Definition
8-6-2: License To Practice Medicine Required
8-6-3: Penalties
8-6-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, to "tattoo" means to insert pigment under the surface
of the skin of a human being, by pricking with a needle or otherwise, so as to
produce an indelible mark or figure visible through the skin. (Ord. 531, 4-13-
1998)
8-6-2: LICENSE TO PRACTICE MEDICINE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a person licensed to practice
medicine in all its branches, to tattoo or offer to tattoo a person. (Ord. 531,
4-13-1998)
8-6-3: PENALTIES:
Violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine of not
less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 531, 4-13-1998)
CHAPTER 7
PONDS
SECTION:
8-7-1: Definition
8-7-2: Construction Standards
8-7-3: License
8-7-1: DEFINITION:
A "pond" is any body of water within the city having a volume in excess of two
thousand (2,000) gallons, or a depth at any point in excess of twenty four
inches (24") which is not intended to be a swimming pool. (Ord. 731, 9-24-2007)
8-7-2: CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
All ponds must meet the following requirements:
   A.   Ponds must be constructed with circulating pumps and filters of
sufficient size to recycle at least twenty five percent (25%) of the volume of
the pond each hour, or be certified by a professional engineer licensed in the
state of Illinois that the natural exchange of water is sufficient, in a year
where one-third (1/3) the normal rainfall occurs, that the pond will not become
stagnant. Circulating systems must be operated from April 1 through October 31.
   B.   Ponds must be equipped with a piping system which allows for the
discharge of excess water in such a manner that no water cascades over earthen
material during or due to the runoff created by a 50-year storm, and to ensure
that under any circumstance excess water does not erode soil in the vicinity of
the pond.
   C.   A professional engineer licensed in the state of Illinois must certify
that any pond created by damming a watercourse is constructed such that, in a
year of three (3) times the normal rainfall, the pond will not exceed the
design boundaries.
   D.   Ponds must be enclosed by a fence or a combination of a fence and
buildings not less than four feet (4') tall. All gates, doors or other devices
which allow access to the pond through the fence must be equipped with a
locking mechanism which is sufficient in the opinion of the building inspector
to exclude children under the age of eight (8). (Ord. 695, 6-27-2005)
   E.   Ponds shall not exceed ten thousand (10,000) gallons or three feet (3')
in depth. (Ord. 731, 9-24-2007)
8-7-3: LICENSE:
   A.   Required: Prior to construction or reconstruction of any pond, the
owner, tenant or other person in possession of property upon which the pond is
to be constructed, reconstructed, created or otherwise allowed to exist must
obtain a license from the city for such pond. The owner of an existing pond
shall annually apply for renewal of the license issued for that pond by March 1
of each calendar year. No license shall be issued for any pond which will not
or does not meet the construction standards established in section
8-7-2 of this chapter.
   B.   Application: Any person seeking to construct or reconstruct a pond
shall first submit an application to the building inspector which includes the
following information:
      1.   The name, address and telephone number of the applicant.
      2.   The location of the proposed or existing pond.
      3.   A description of the manner in which the pond will be constructed or
reconstructed.
      4.   The volume and depth of the pond.
      5.   A detailed description of a circulation system and overflow system
which will be incorporated into the pond.
      6.   Any certifications required by section
8-7-2 of this chapter.
      7.   A description of the fence which will control access to the pond.
      8.   A diagram showing the location of the pond and all related
improvements on the parcel where the pond will be located.
   C.   Term: Pond licenses shall have a term from April 1 of each calendar
year through March 31 of the following calendar year.
   D.   Renewal: Pond licenses are renewable following inspection and approval
by the city building inspector.
   E.   Fees:
      1.   All persons obtaining a license to construct or reconstruct a pond
shall pay an application fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00) which shall
include the first year's license fee. If the application for a license is
denied, the fee is forfeited.
      2.   License renewal fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00). If the
application for license renewal is denied, the fee is forfeited.
      3.   License reinstatement after revocation shall be thirty five dollars
($35.00).
   F.   Revocation: The mayor may at any time revoke any pond license for any
violation of this chapter or violation of any other provision of this code
including, without limitation, the following reasons:
      1.   The pond is stagnant, emits a noxious smell or otherwise creates any
condition which interferes with the use or enjoyment of nearby properties.
      2.   The pond is constructed or maintained in a manner inconsistent with
the regulations set forth in section
8-7-2 of this chapter.
After such revocation, the owner or occupant of the property where the pond
exists shall have thirty (30) days to either remove the pond from the property
or remediate the deficiencies which are the basis for revocation. Notice of
revocation of license shall be mailed to the license holder both by certified
mail and regular mail at the last known address of the license holder or,
alternatively, the notice may be personally served on the licensee on an adult
member of the licensee's household.
   G.   Appeal: Any applicant or license holder may appeal any denial of an
application for a pond license or any revocation of a pond license to the city
council. The appeal must be in writing, must explain the basis of the appeal
and must be delivered to the office of the city clerk within ten (10) days
after denial of an application or after notice of revocation was mailed or
personally delivered to the license holder. Any party to the appeal may present
evidence and be represented by counsel at the expense of the party. The city
council shall convene within ten (10) days after receipt of the appeal for the
purpose of hearing the appeal. The city council will by roll call vote in open
session render a decision regarding the appeal. The decision of the city
council shall be final. (Ord. 695, 6-27-2005)
TITLE 9
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS, PUBLIC WAYS AND EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Supervision
9-1-2: Right Of Way Defined
9-1-3: Obstructing Right Of Way Prohibited
9-1-4: Permitted Uses Within Right Of Way
9-1-5: Prohibited Uses Of Right Of Way
9-1-6: Construction Requirements
9-1-7: Defects; Repairs
9-1-8: Street Opening Repairs
9-1-9: Repairs To Sidewalks, Shoulders, Curbs And Gutters
9-1-10: Notification And Protection Of The Public
9-1-11: Nonliability Of City
9-1-12: Emergency Excavations
9-1-13: Fines And Penalties
9-1-14: Moving Of Houses Within Rights Of Way
9-1-1: SUPERVISION:
All public streets, sidewalks and other public ways in the city shall be under
the supervision of the superintendent of streets. He shall be charged with the
compliance of all ordinance provisions relating to such public places. (Ord.
550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-2: RIGHT OF WAY DEFINED:
"Right of way" means that portion of any street, roadway, sidewalk, or other
public passageway reserved to the public use or otherwise owned or controlled
by the city (or any other governmental entity) including, but not limited to,
any unpaved or unimproved part or parts thereof. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-3: OBSTRUCTING RIGHT OF WAY PROHIBITED:
Other than as permitted or allowed by this code, it shall be unlawful for any
person, corporation, firm or other entity to place, deposit, install or
maintain any structure, material, debris, artifact or thing, in, on or upon any
right of way within the city. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-4: PERMITTED USES WITHIN RIGHT OF WAY:
The placement of any of the following things within a right of way is hereby
permitted:
   A.   Any traffic control sign, signal device, street sign, barricade or the
like installed by any governmental entity with authority to install and
maintain same.
   B.   Any other sign or device deemed in the public convenience and/or
necessity installed and maintained by the city.
   C.   Any utility pole, wire, line, conduit, water line, shutoff valve, fire
hydrant or the like which is either:
      1.   Installed and maintained by the city; or
      2.   Permitted or allowed by any ordinance, resolution or franchise
enacted or adopted by the city, or otherwise expressly authorized by the city.
   D.   Mailboxes and newspaper boxes.
   E.   Driveways, to the extent permitted and regulated by title 4, chapter 7
of this code.
   F.   Grass, flower arrangements and other decorative plantings (other than
trees and shrubs) not exceeding eighteen inches (18") in height and not planted
in any manner so as to obstruct vehicular traffic sightlines or so as to cause
any other obstruction or danger to vehicular or pedestrian traffic. (Ord. 550,
2-22-1999)
9-1-5: PROHIBITED USES OF RIGHT OF WAY:
The placement of the following things within a right of way are hereby
prohibited:
   A.   Trees and shrubs except to the extent permitted and regulated by
chapter 8 of this title.
   B.   Garbage, garbage cans, litter, refuse and rubbish, except as permitted
for pick up purposes, title 8, chapter 3 of this code.
   C.   Weeds which are in violation of title 8, chapter 2 of this code.
   D.   Any other structure, thing, artifact or device except as specifically
allowed by section
9-1-4 of this chapter.
   E.   Discharge of snow, ice, or any like material into the street portion of
the right of way. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-6: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required:
      1.   Street Openings: No public street may be cut or opened except by an
approved contractor who shall first have obtained a permit for same.
   B.   Obtaining Permits; Cash Or Surety Bond:
      1.   Franchise Utility Companies And Sewer Contractors: The permit for
said cut or opening shall be obtained from the city, after first having paid a
bond for street opening, or cut, in the amount as set forth below. Said bond
shall cover the cost of inspection. A permit may be denied to any contractor
who has previously failed to comply with this code.
      2.   Maintenance And Excavation Contractors; Bond: Maintenance and
excavation opening permit for replacement or renewal/removal of facilities:
         a.   In order to obtain said permit, said person, firm, or corporation
shall file with the city clerk a written application therefor, which
application shall set forth the type of hole, digging or excavating proposed to
be done, giving the approximate length and depth thereof, and when same shall
be done. Whereupon, the city clerk shall refer said application to the
superintendent of the streets, and if said superintendent approves said
application, the city clerk shall thereupon, issue said permit; provided,
however, that before said permit is issued the said applicant shall file with
the city clerk a cash or surety bond in the sum of five hundred dollars
($500.00), which bond shall be for the purpose of guaranteeing to the city that
said applicant replace, cover and surface said hole, digging or excavating, in
the same manner and in as good condition as said street or public property was
in before said work was done, and shall be retained by the city as damages and
for the purpose of paying for the replacement of said work in the proper
manner. Said applicant shall also be responsible for replacement costs
exceeding the five hundred dollar ($500.00) bond. The city shall have sixty
(60) days from completion of said work before the city shall be required to
approve or disapprove same.
   C.   Compliance With Specifications Of City Council: All street and sidewalk
pavements shall be made in conformity with specifications laid down or approved
from time to time by the city council. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-7: DEFECTS; REPAIRS:
   A.   Reports Of Defects: It shall be the duty of every city officer, or
employee becoming cognizant of any defect in any street or sidewalk, or any
obstruction thereof, to report the same to the superintendent of streets as
soon as possible.
   B.   Repairs Required: All public streets and sidewalk pavement shall be
kept in good repair. Such repair work, whether done by the city or by the
abutting owner shall be under the supervision of the superintendent of streets.
(Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-8: STREET OPENING REPAIRS:
The permittee must repair the area affected by the disruption of the street
surface and subsurface to a condition equal to or better than the surrounding
street surface and maintain the area affected by the disruption until such time
as the street, sidewalk or other area is either rebuilt or overlaid. The
permittee must further repair or remove and replace any street or other surface
scarred by work performed pursuant to this section. All repairs shall be
inspected and approved by the superintendent of streets upon completion. If a
repair is not approved by the superintendent of streets, it must be repaired
again to meet approval.
Restoration or repair of streets shall be in accordance with the "Standard
Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois", July 1994,
subject to the provisions in subsections A and B of this section. (Ord. 550, 2-
22-1999)
   A.   If the excavation is less than ten feet (10') deep from the existing
ground level to the bottom of the excavation, the restoration or repair shall
be made as follows:
      1.   All street openings that are to be repaired in the area of an
existing pavement subgrade or where the inner edge of a trench for such
conduits of closer than two feet (2') to the edge of the existing pavement,
stabilized shoulder, curb, gutter or sidewalk shall be backfilled with the
following materials:
         a.   All trenches, structures, culverts, utility cuts and other work
extending under pavement locations shall be filled with control low strength
material (CLSM). No material excavated may be placed back in the excavation.
         b.   CLSM shall consist of one of the following mixtures:
            MIXTURE NO. 1
 
Portland cement               50      pounds
Fly ash                       200     pounds
Fine aggregate (SSD saturated 2,990   pounds
surface dry)
Water                         49 - 57 gallons
 
(Ord. 575, 3-27-2000)
            MIXTURE NO. 2
 
Portland cement          185     pounds
Fine aggregate (SSD)     2,990   pounds (SSD)
Air-entraining admixture 6       fluid ounces
Water                    49 - 57 gallons (as directed)
 
These quantities will give an approximate yield of one cubic yard. The flow
ability of the mixture shall be observed by the street superintendent or his/
her designee and the water content increased/decreased within the stated limits
for mixture no. 1 and the water content and the air-entraining admixture
content increased/decreased as directed for mixture no. 2.
The mixing of the CLSM shall be as specified in section 803 of the "Standard
Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" adopted July 1994, by the
Illinois department of transportation or as approved by the street
superintendent.
         c.   All materials incorporated shall meet all requirements of the
"Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" adopted July 1994,
and more specifically the following or as approved by the street superintendent
or his/her designee:
 
Water                     702
Fine aggregate            703 ASTM C 33
Portland cement (type 1)  718.19 (b)
Fly ash (class C)         701
Air-entraining admixtures 718.01 (b)
 
         d.   The CLSM must be free of frost prior to placement of any surface.
(Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
      2.   Areas that have been opened in existing pavement to facilitate the
installation or repair of utilities shall be saw cut to provide a square edge
with the existing pavement. All holes shall be temporarily patched with a
minimum of six inches (6") of bituminous cold patch mixture or shall be
permanently patched as set forth below.
A permanent patch shall be constructed by October 15 following the installation
of the temporary patch in the following manner: a) if concrete, the same
thickness of concrete as the existing pavement, but not less than six inches
(6") of PCC concrete; b) if bituminous surface, three inches (3") of bituminous
cap and six inches (6") of PCC concrete base, or if the pavement is full depth
bituminous eight inches (8") or greater, then bituminous of the same thickness
as the existing bituminous. (Ord. 636, 5-13-2002)
   B.   If the excavation is greater than ten feet (10') deep from the existing
ground level to the bottom of the excavation, the restoration or repair may be
made as provided in subsection A of this section, or shall be made as follows:
      1.   All street openings that are to be repaired in the area of an
existing pavement subgrade or where the inner edge of a trench for such
conduits is closer than two feet (2') to the edge of the existing pavement,
stabilized shoulder, curb, gutter or sidewalk shall be backfilled with the
following materials:
The top ten feet (10') shall comply with the CLSM requirements as provided in
subsection A of this section. Below the initial ten feet (10') of CLSM,
selected granular backfill materials for the repair of said openings shall
consist only of sand, stone sand, crushed stone, or crushed gravel with
gradations as specified in 20-2, 21C of the said standard specifications. This
backfill material is to be placed and compacted in lifts not to exceed eighteen
inches (18") and placed to within six inches (6") of the finished surface.
(Ord. 575, 3-27-2000)
      2.   Areas that have been opened in existing pavement to facilitate the
installation or repair of utilities shall be saw cut to provide a square edge
with the existing pavement. All holes shall be temporarily patched with a
minimum of six inches (6") of bituminous cold patch mixture or shall be
permanently patched as set forth below.
A permanent patch shall be constructed by October 15 following the installation
of the temporary patch in the following manner: a) if concrete, the same
thickness of concrete as the existing pavement, but not less than six inches
(6") of PCC concrete; b) if bituminous surface, three inches (3") of bituminous
cap and six inches (6") of PCC concrete base, or if the pavement is full depth
bituminous eight inches (8") or greater, then bituminous of the same thickness
as the existing bituminous. (Ord. 636, 5-13-2002)
      3.   The material for granular cradle for restoration of streets opened
for the repair or installation of sanitary sewer, storm sewers or water
distribution shall be stone, screening, crushed stone, pit run gravel, washed
gravel, crushed boiler slag, or other granular material approved by the city or
its representative and conform to gradations specified in said standard
specifications. (Ord. 575, 3-27-2000)
   C.   If the permittee fails to repair in accordance with this section or
section
9-1-9 of this chapter, after notification by the superintendent of streets,
then the city may, at its option, repair or replace such portion of the street,
sidewalk or other area and the permittee shall be liable for the city's
reasonable costs, including labor, engineering and attorney fees. Said
notification shall be in writing and shall grant the permittee five (5) days to
repair or replace in accordance with these provisions before the city
undertakes repair or replacement. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-9: REPAIRS TO SIDEWALKS, SHOULDERS, CURBS AND GUTTERS:
All sidewalks, shoulders, curbs and gutter openings shall be restored to their
original condition and with original materials or their equivalent. Said
repairs shall be inspected and approved by the superintendent of streets upon
completion. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-10: NOTIFICATION AND PROTECTION OF THE PUBLIC:
   A.   All franchisees, utility companies, and other users of the public ways
for utility purposes shall barricade as necessary to respond to emergency
situations involving or caused by their use of the public ways as directed by
the police department or street department. If the emergency is discovered by
the city and the city barricades, the user shall reimburse the city for its
costs, including labor, if deemed necessary by the street superintendent.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any barricade which any
officer of the city has placed upon a public street or public place in the
city, or to drive any motor vehicle of any kind or pass over any street or
public place which has been closed from traffic by any city officer.
   C.   All franchisees, utility companies, and other users of the public ways
for utility purposes shall notify the street department when they become aware
of actual or potential structural damage to the public right of way or
structures which is or may be caused by their installations.
   D.   The city shall be notified by each permittee of its schedule for
backfilling and roadway repairs prior to commencing the work. Roadway repairs
made without notification are subject to the fines listed in section
9-1-13 of this chapter and will require reexcavation and replacement in
compliance with subsection 9-1-8A or B of this chapter, as applicable. All
franchisees, utility companies, and other users of the public ways for utility
purposes shall supply the street superintendent with proof of the backfilling
materials, i.e., CLSM tickets, within seven (7) days of the completion of the
backfilling.
   E.   Franchisees, utility companies, and other users of the public ways for
utility purposes shall remove or repair all utility structures determined by
the street superintendent to pose a threat to public safety within twenty four
(24) hours after notification by the city.
   F.   Failed patches shall be repaired within twenty four (24) hours after
notification by the city.
   G.   All temporary patches shall be converted to approved permanent patches
by October 15 of each year.
   H.   All test holes drilled in public ways shall be backfilled with CLSM, or
compatible fill, capped with a permanent patch on the same day that the public
way is patched.
   I.   Franchisees, utility companies, and other users of the public ways for
utility purposes shall use normally accepted treatment and precautionary
measures to control water and ice on streets and sidewalks resulting from
breakage or repair work. If such measures are not used promptly after
notification by the city, the city may take such measures as it deems necessary
to control water and ice and the user shall reimburse the city for its costs,
including labor. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-11: NONLIABILITY OF CITY:
The said applicant shall save and keep harmless the city from any and all
liability of any kind and character in connection with said work, including
damages or suits for damage in connection therewith. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-12: EMERGENCY EXCAVATIONS:
In the event of an emergency which requires immediate excavating or digging,
the superintendent of streets, superintendent of water, mayor or chairman of
streets shall have the right to authorize the immediate digging and excavating,
in which event said applicant shall comply with all of the provisions of this
chapter as soon as it is possible. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-13: FINES AND PENALTIES:
   A.   Violations of subsections 9-1-10A through D and I of this chapter shall
be subject to a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per violation.
   B.   Violations of subsections 9-1-10E through G of this chapter shall be
subject to a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per day per violation.
   C.   Violations of subsection 9-1-10H of this chapter shall be subject to a
fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day per hole. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
9-1-14: MOVING OF HOUSES WITHIN RIGHTS OF WAY:
   A.   It is unlawful to move any house within or upon the right of way of the
city.
   B.   For purposes of this section, "house" means any structure intended to
be used as a single- or multi-family residence, or any other structure of
whatever use having a floor area of two hundred fifty (250) square feet or
more, any of which has been constructed and at any time placed on a permanent
foundation.
   C.   Subsection A of this section does not apply to any new structure
intended to be used for residential purposes which is of prefabricated, precut
or modular construction. (Ord. 732, 10-8-2007)
CHAPTER 2
BLOCKS RENUMBERED
SECTION:
9-2-1: Certain Blocks Renumbered
9-2-1: CERTAIN BLOCKS RENUMBERED:
Certain blocks abutting LaSalle Boulevard in the city shall be renumbered as
designated below:
   A.   That portion of land abutting LaSalle Boulevard and lying between Route
29 and St. Clair Drive will be designated as zero to ninety nine (0–99) block
of LaSalle Boulevard.
   B.   That portion of land abutting LaSalle Boulevard and lying between St.
Clair Drive and Cavalier Road will be designated as the one hundred (100) block
of LaSalle Boulevard. (Ord. 550, 2-22-1999)
CHAPTER 3
MOVING BUILDINGS
(Rep. by Ord. 305, 3-12-1984)
CHAPTER 4
CITY PARKS AND PUBLIC PLACES
SECTION:
9-4-1: Alcoholic Beverages
9-4-2: Closing Hours
9-4-3: Sale, Possession And Consumption Of Alcoholic Beverages In City Parks
9-4-1: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES:
   A.   Except as provided by subsection 3-9-6H of this Code and section
9-4-3 of this chapter, no person shall sell, give away, possess or consume
alcoholic beverages at any time in any park within the City unless such
alcoholic beverage is purchased from a Class H licensee at special event as
provided in subsection 3-9-6H of this Code. Possession and consumption of such
alcoholic beverages is limited to the area and time approved in the Class H
license application. No person shall be under the influence of intoxicating
liquors while in such parks, no person shall bring within, have in his/her
possession or transport, carry or have any alcoholic beverages in, upon or
about any motor vehicle in any such park, except in the original package and
with the seal unbroken.
   B.   No person may consume or have in his/her possession an open container
or a container with a broken seal containing alcoholic beverages in any
vehicle, vehicle parking area, or on any public street, sidewalk, alley or
other public way, or in any restaurant or eating places not licensed to serve
alcoholic beverages within the City. (Ord. 897, 8-12-2019)
9-4-2: CLOSING HOURS:
   A.   No person shall enter upon Marquette Heights Park, at LaSalle Boulevard
or Sangamon Road, or upon Independence Park on LaSalle Boulevard between the
hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) pm and six o'clock (6:00) am except when
authorized to do so by written consent of the City Council or Mayor.
   B.   No person shall enter upon Marquette Heights Skate Park or Basketball
Court or Dog Park between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) pm and six o'clock
(6:00) am.
   C.   No person shall enter upon the Dog Park, Highline Park, between Lincoln
Road and Fulton Road, or the Main Street Park, between dusk and dawn. (Ord.
865, 5-8-2017; amd. Ord. 919, - -2021)
9-4-3: SALE, POSSESSION AND CONSUMPTION OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES IN CITY PARKS:
   A.   A Class H liquor license holder as defined by subsection 3-9-6H of this
Code, may, upon the approval of the City Council, offer for retail sale,
alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises of a City park pursuant to
the terms of the Class H license.
   B.   A person may possess and consume alcoholic beverages in a City park if
such alcoholic beverage is purchased or received from a Class H licensee and
the possession and consumption of such alcoholic beverage remains within the
area governed by the Class H license. (Ord. 897, 8-12-2019)
CHAPTER 5
COMBINED WATER AND SEWER UTILITY
SECTION:
9-5-1: Combined Utility
9-5-2: Department Created, Superintendent
9-5-3: Clerk, Duties
9-5-4: Audit Of Accounts
9-5-5: Deposit Of Receipts
9-5-6: Sewer Replacement Fund
9-5-7: Water And Sewer Capital Improvement Fund
9-5-8: Penalties
9-5-1: COMBINED UTILITY:
The waterworks and sewerage systems of the city are hereby combined and shall
be operated by the city as one combined utility. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-5-2: DEPARTMENT CREATED, SUPERINTENDENT:
There is hereby established a department of the city known as the "combined
waterworks and sewerage department" (hereinafter in this title called the
"department"). There shall be placed in charge of the general management and
control of said department a superintendent, who shall be appointed by the
mayor with the approval of the city council (hereinafter in this title called
the "superintendent"), who shall also be the superintendent of water pollution
control as provided in subsection 9-7-2A of this title. The superintendent
shall be bonded in the amount as may be determined by the city council. All
other full time employees of the department shall likewise be appointed by the
mayor with the approval of the city council. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-5-3: CLERK, DUTIES:
   A.   The city clerk is designated as collector for the collection of water
and sewer charges, and it shall be the duty of the clerk to render bills for
service and all other charges in connection therewith and to collect all monies
due thereon. All monies so collected shall be promptly delivered over to the
city treasurer.
   B.   The method of computing rates and service charges established in this
title for the combined water and sewer utility shall be made available to any
user of the utility within seven (7) days of receipt by the clerk of a written
request from the user for such information. Any user billed for water or sewer
charges may submit a written appeal to the superintendent regarding either the
method utilized in calculating the charge or the application of that method to
calculate the charge. The superintendent shall enter a written decision in
response to any such appeal within ten (10) days after receipt of the appeal.
The decision of the superintendent shall be final. (Ord. 671, 2-9-2004)
9-5-4: AUDIT OF ACCOUNTS:
   A.   The city clerk shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall
keep proper books and records of accounts in which complete and correct entries
shall be made of all transactions relative to the waterworks and sewerage
system, and at regular annual intervals shall cause to be made an audit by a
certified public accountant of the books to show receipts and disbursements.
   B.   Either the Illinois environmental protection agency ("IEPA") or the
United States environmental protection agency ("USEPA") shall through any
authorized representative during business hours of the city have prompt access
to any books, documents, papers or records of the city which are applicable to
the combined water and sewer utility operated by the city for the purpose of
monitoring compliance with the terms and conditions of any grant or loan
received by the city from either the IEPA or the USEPA. Any such agency may
audit and examine any such records and extract such excerpts and/or
transcriptions thereof as such agencies deem necessary to ensure compliance
with the terms and conditions under which any such grant or loan was provided
to the city. (Ord. 671, 2-9-2004)
9-5-5: DEPOSIT OF RECEIPTS:
The city treasurer shall deposit all funds delivered to him by the city clerk
in a separate fund designated as the waterworks and sewerage fund and shall
administer such fund in a manner provided by the Illinois municipal code, and
as provided by city ordinance. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-5-6: SEWER REPLACEMENT FUND:
   A.   There is hereby created by the city, the "sewer replacement fund" (the
"fund"). The fund shall be created and used solely and only for the purpose of
accumulating funds for replacement, for the purpose of retaining their design
capacities, any existing sewer lines, equipment and other facilities which
constitute a part of the existing city sewer system or as same may hereafter be
expanded. Said fund shall be maintained in the form of a savings (or similar)
account in a financial institution designated by the city treasurer in the same
manner as are other city funds. Sums on deposit in the fund may also, from time
to time, be invested and reinvested by the city treasurer in the manner and to
the extent permitted by law. Interest accumulating on the investment of sums on
deposit in the fund shall remain in and become a part of the fund.
   B.   The city shall designate as a part of its sewer user rates, a specific
amount of money to be deposited in the fund on a monthly basis. (Ord. 390, 9-
11-1989)
9-5-7: WATER AND SEWER CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT FUND:
   A.   There is hereby created by the city, the "water and sewer capital
improvement fund" (the "fund"). The fund shall be created and used solely and
only for the purpose of accumulating funds for the replacement, extension,
expansion or improvement of any equipment, water mains, storage and treatment
structures, sewer lines, or other facilities which constitute a part of the
existing city water and sewer system or as same may hereafter be expanded. Said
fund shall be maintained in the form of a savings (or similar) account in a
financial institution designated by the city treasurer in the same manner as
are other city funds. Sums on deposit in the fund may also, from time to time,
be invested and reinvested by the city treasurer in the manner and to the
extent permitted by law. Interest accumulating on the sums on deposit in the
fund shall remain in and become a part of the fund.
   B.   The city shall designate as a part of its water rate structure, and its
sewer user charge rates, a specific amount of money to be deposited in the fund
on a monthly basis. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-5-8: PENALTIES:
   A.   Any person who violates any provision of chapters 6 through 9 of this
title, or who fails to comply with any requirement thereof, shall be fined for
each such offense in an amount not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day a violation or noncompliance is
found to exist, shall constitute a separate offense.
   B.   Any person violating any of the provisions of chapters 6 through 9 of
this title shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage
occasioned by the city including attorney fees by reason of such violation.
   C.   Violation of chapter 6, 7, or 9 of this title shall be punishable by an
ordinance violation and/or disconnection of service. If disconnection of
service is necessary, sections
9-6-21 and
9-6-22 of this title shall apply. (Ord. 700, 9-26-2005)
CHAPTER 6
WATER SERVICE PROCEDURES, REGULATIONS AND RATES
SECTION:
9-6-1: Definitions
9-6-2: Connections, Permits Required; Fee
9-6-3: Service Installation
9-6-4: Lateral Connections (Water)
9-6-5: Compliance With Codes
9-6-6: Shutoff Boxes
9-6-7: Right Of Access
9-6-8: Water Meters
9-6-9: Multi-Unit Structures
9-6-10: Water Wells
9-6-11: Resale Or Distribution
9-6-12: Tampering Or Obstructing System
9-6-13: Nonliability Of City
9-6-14: Application For Service And Payment Of Deposit
9-6-15: Refund Of Deposit
9-6-16: Rates And Charges
9-6-17: Billing And Payment Dates
9-6-18: Late Charges
9-6-19: Exceptions And Extensions
9-6-20: Delinquencies
9-6-21: Disconnection
9-6-22: Reconnection Procedures And Fees
9-6-23: Liability Of Owner, Occupant And Service User
9-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used herein, the following terms shall have the following meanings unless
the context in which they are used clearly indicates otherwise:
COMMERCIAL USER: Any service user other than a homeowner or a renter.
DEPOSIT: The sum hereafter required to be paid by system users of the water and
sewer system in the city, for the initial provision of water and sewer service.
Said deposit shall be:
Commercial user   $ 75.00
Homeowner   75.00
Renter   150.00
HOMEOWNER: Any adult person (and his or her spouse) living in any home in the
city who owns the home (and the property) wherein he or she lives, or who is
purchasing said home and property subject to mortgage, contract for deed or
similar arrangement.
RENTER: Any adult person (and his or her spouse) living in a home in the city
who is not a homeowner and who, as the occupant thereof, is the person
responsible for said premises.
SENIOR CITIZEN: A person being the head of a household who is age sixty two
(62) or older who is the registered user of water service at any specific
premises and who has provided proof of his or her date of birth to the office
of the city clerk on a yearly basis during the month of January. A person is
the "head of the household" if such a person provides at least one-half (1/2)
of the cost of maintaining the household and resides at such address where
water service is registered. Senior citizens shall qualify for the water rate
as set forth in subsection 9-6-16B of this chapter.
SERVICE USER: Any homeowner, renter or commercial user to whom water service is
provided by the city. (Ord. 642, 7-22-2002; amd. Ord. 944, 12-11-2023)
9-6-2: CONNECTIONS, PERMITS REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   No connections to or with the city’s water system shall be made without
a permit being issued and twenty four (24) hours’ notice having been given to
the superintendent. All such connections shall be made and all such work done
at the expense of the applicant who shall furnish all materials necessary for
such work. The connections shall be made under the supervision of the
superintendent and shall not be covered over until the work has been inspected
and approved by him. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
   B.   No connection or tap into the water system shall be made until a permit
for same is first obtained from the superintendent and all required fees are
paid to the department. The water service tap fee shall be two thousand dollars
($2,000.00) per connection, plus the actual cost to the city for all materials
provided in relation thereto, including, but not limited to, water meter, pipe
and shutoff box. (Ord. 852, 5-9-2016; amd. Ord. 930, 11-14-2022)
9-6-3: SERVICE INSTALLATION:
All service pipes, tiles or other conduit from the main line to the premises
served shall be installed by, and at the cost of the owner of the property to
be served or the applicant for the service. No service shall be installed
unless said pipes or tiling have first been inspected by the superintendent and
found by him to meet the specifications required by the city. (Ord. 390, 9-11-
1989)
9-6-4: LATERAL CONNECTIONS (WATER):
   A.   A lateral connection is the water pipe extending from a water main into
any lot, property or tract of land.
   B.   The city shall be responsible for the maintenance and repair of all
lateral connections extending from any water main up to and including the
shutoff box, except for damage to the shutoff box caused by the owner or
occupier of the property being served.
   C.   The owner of any lot, property or tract of land shall be responsible
for the maintenance and repair of any lateral connection extending from the
shutoff box to any other point on the property so served, and the city shall
have no responsibility for the repair and maintenance of same. The owner shall
further be responsible for any damage to the shutoff box caused by the owner
and/or occupier of the property so served. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-6-5: COMPLIANCE WITH CODES:
In addition to the requirements set forth in this code, all installations of
water service to any premises in the city shall comply with all building codes
and other regulations duly adopted by the city and in force on the date an
application for a permit is made. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-6-6: SHUTOFF BOXES:
   A.   Water shutoff boxes or service boxes shall be placed on every service
pipe, and shall be located between the curb line and the sidewalk line where
this is practical. Such boxes shall be located so that they are easily
accessible and protected from frost.
   B.   After final construction and landscaping is completed, shutoff boxes
must be exposed and in an undamaged condition. Notification of completion of
construction and landscaping must be given to the department within twenty four
(24) hours and an inspection shall be made by the department. (Ord. 390, 9-11-
1989)
9-6-7: RIGHT OF ACCESS:
Employees of the department shall have ready access to the premises, place or
building where service is supplied for the purpose of inspecting and testing
any part of the system. In the event that access to a remote meter reader
becomes impaired for any reason including, without limitation, the growth or
placement of vegetation, the placement of fencing, the construction of an
addition or the presence of pets, the city may in its discretion, relocate the
remote reader to a location deemed by the city to be reasonably and efficiently
accessible. The owner of the property shall cooperate with the relocation and
shall provide access to the premises to the extent reasonably necessary to
facilitate such relocation. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere
with, prevent or obstruct any employee or agent of the city in the performance
of his duty. In addition, in the event of impaired access to any premises for
purposes of this section, the city may after not less than ten (10) days' prior
written notice mailed to the person to whom the water service for such premises
is billed interrupt water service to such premises until representatives of the
city have been provided with the access necessary to allow completion of any
inspection or testing or relocation of a meter or remote meter reader. (Ord.
667, 12-8-2003)
9-6-8: WATER METERS:
All premises using the city water supply must be equipped with an adequate
water meter and remote purchased from the city. It shall be the duty of the
city to maintain all meters in good and accurate working condition, and to
replace all meters which are determined to have become inaccurate or faulty.
Meters and remotes shall be installed in a location that will provide easy
access for repair and monthly reading. (Ord. 667, 12-8-2003)
9-6-9: MULTI-UNIT STRUCTURES:
Each separate unit of any multi-unit structure regardless of use (i.e.,
residential, commercial, etc.) shall be supplied with separate water and sewer
service, and a separate water meter. It shall be unlawful for the owner or
occupier of any multi-unit structure to construct, reconstruct, alter, renovate
or occupy same in violation of this section. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-6-10: WATER WELLS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to dig, drill, sink or operate any water
well and use the same for a water supply for any purpose within the corporate
limits of the City. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-6-11: RESALE OR DISTRIBUTION:
No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the City
water supply to any premises other than that for which application has been
made and the meter installed, except in case of emergency and with the
permission of the City Council. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-6-12: TAMPERING OR OBSTRUCTING SYSTEM:
It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the City to tamper with,
alter, injure or obstruct any part of the water system. Any person violating
this section shall be liable for the damage caused in addition to any penalty
imposed. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-6-13: NONLIABILITY OF CITY:
All services of the combined water and sewerage system which are applied for
and utilized shall be upon the express condition that the City shall not be
liable, nor shall any claim be made against it, for damages or injury caused by
breakage of said system, or for any interruption of services by reason of
breakage, repairs, cleaning, acts of nature, alteration or extension of any
part of the system. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-6-14: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE AND PAYMENT OF DEPOSIT:
   A.   From and after the effective date of this chapter all applications for
water service in the City must be in writing, signed by the applicant and
accompanied by a fully paid deposit.
   B.   All applicants for water service must pay in full the deposit before
water service will be provided to the requested premises. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
   C.   No deposit will be accepted for water service to any property that has
an outstanding unpaid utility bill due and owing to the City. Said unpaid
utility bill must be paid in full before a deposit will be accepted and water
service provided to such premises. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989; amd. Ord. 706, 3-13-
2006; Ord. 953, 8-12-2024)
9-6-15: REFUND OF DEPOSIT:
   A.   Homeowner And Renter: The deposit paid by a homeowner or renter shall
be retained by the City for as long as water service is provided to the
premises for which such deposit has been paid. Said deposit (or appropriate
part thereof) shall be refunded to the homeowner or renter only after a request
for discontinuance of service has been received from said homeowner or renter
and all water service provided to said premises has been paid in full through
the date of discontinuance of service. All charges due or unpaid for water
service through the date of discontinuance of service as determined by City
personnel and reported to the City Clerk’s Office may be deducted from the
deposit and the balance, if any, refunded to the homeowner or renter. (Ord.
390, 9-11-1989; amd. Ord. 951, 7-8-2024; Ord. 953, 8-12-2024)
9-6-16: RATES AND CHARGES:
There are hereby established rates and charges for the use and service supplied
by the municipal water system of the city of Marquette Heights.
   A.   Residential And Commercial Rates: Each residential or commercial user
shall pay a minimum monthly charge of thirteen dollars thirty eight cents
($13.38) regardless of the quantity of water used to cover the following costs:
 
Fixed overhead associated with operation and maintenance of the      $ 5.26
water system
Construction of water treatment plant                                5.00
Construction of water tower                                          2.80
Construction of water well                                           0.32
                                                                Total $ 13.38
 
      The minimum monthly charge shall be paid even if no water is used in any
given month. In addition to the minimum monthly charge, each such user shall
pay for water used each month at the following rate:
      Beginning with bills mailed on or after May 1, 2007, $0.500 per one
hundred (100) gallons of water or any part thereof used. On May 1, 2008, and on
each May 1 thereafter, the city clerk shall adjust the rate for water used by
adding to the rate in effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to three
percent (3%) of such rate.
      The minimum monthly charges and rates in effect prior to September 1,
2008, shall continue to apply with respect to water used and billed prior to
September 1, 2008.
   B.   Senior Citizen Rates: Each senior citizen user shall pay a minimum
monthly charge of thirteen dollars thirty eight cents ($13.38) per month
regardless of the quantity of water used to cover the following costs:
 
Fixed overhead associated with operation and maintenance of the      $5.26
water system
Construction of water treatment plant                                $5.00
Construction of water tower                                          2.80
Construction of water well                                           0.32
                                                                Total $ 13.38
 
      The minimum monthly charge shall be paid even if no water is used in any
given month. In addition to the minimum monthly charge, each such user shall
pay for water used each month at the following rates:
      Beginning with bills mailed on or after May 1, 2007, $0.200 per one
hundred (100) gallons of water or any part thereof used up to a total of four
thousand (4,000) gallons. For water used in excess of four thousand (4,000)
gallons, $0.500 per one hundred (100) gallons of water or any part thereof
used. On May 1, 2008, and on each May 1 thereafter, the city clerk shall adjust
each of the foregoing rates for water used by adding to the respective rates in
effect on the date of adjustment a sum equal to three percent (3%) of such
rates.
      The minimum monthly charges and rates in effect prior to September 1,
2008, shall continue to apply with respect to water used and billed prior to
September 1, 2008.
   C.   Fire Department Rates: Each qualifying member of the Marquette Heights
fire department shall pay a minimum monthly charge of thirteen dollars thirty
eight cents ($13.38) regardless of the quantity of water used to cover the
following costs:
 
Fixed overhead associated with operation and maintenance of the      $5.26
water system
Construction of water treatment plant                                $5.00
Construction of water tower                                          2.80
Construction of water well                                           0.32
                                                                Total $ 13.38
 
      The minimum monthly charge shall be paid even if no water is used in any
given month. In addition to the minimum monthly charge, each such user shall
pay for water used each month at the following rates:
      Beginning with bills mailed on or after May 1, 2007, $0.200 per one
hundred (100) gallons of water or any part thereof used up to a total of four
thousand (4,000) gallons. For water used in excess of four thousand (4,000)
gallons, $0.500 per one hundred (100) gallons of water or any part thereof. On
May 1, 2008, and on each May 1 thereafter, the city clerk shall adjust each of
the foregoing rates for water used by adding to the respective rates in effect
on the date of adjustment a sum equal to three percent (3%) of such rates.
      The minimum monthly charges and rates in effect prior to September 1,
2008, shall continue to apply with respect to water used and billed prior to
September 1, 2008.
      After one year service, any member in good standing of the Marquette
Heights fire department shall receive the fire department rate. This rate will
be applied to the member’s home address.
      On May 1, the fire chief is required to submit to the city office a list
of qualified members. Any changes to this list must be submitted to the city
office by the twentieth of each month.
   D.   Outside Of City Limits: All users of city water service outside of the
city limits shall pay two hundred percent (200%) plus an additional five dollar
($5.00) fee depending upon which classification is applicable to each user,
except senior citizen rates, which apply only to those residing within the city
limits. (Ord. 752, 8-11-2008; amd. Ord. 934, 2-13-2023; Ord. 950, 6-10-2024)
9-6-17: BILLING AND PAYMENT DATES:
The city will send out water bills on or about the first day of each month for
all water service provided as of the most recent reading of each service user's
water meter. Water bills will be due and payable on or before the twentieth day
of each month following receipt thereof by each service user. Each service user
shall be deemed to have received his or her monthly water bill on the fifth day
after the sending thereof by the city through the United States postal service.
When the twentieth day of any month shall be a weekend or legal holiday, then
such bills for service shall be payable on the next succeeding business day
without any penalty. (Ord. 796, 9-12-2011)
9-6-18: LATE CHARGES:
   A.   All water bills not paid by the twentieth day of the month following
the receipt thereof by the service user shall be subject to a late charge
penalty of ten percent (10%) of the total water and sewer charges for the
month, which shall be added to all bills not paid by the twentieth day of the
month in which they are sent out. (Ord. 446, 6-28-1993)
   B.   Whenever any check received by the city for the payment of any water
and/or sewer bill is returned by the drawee bank for nonsufficient funds, said
user shall be assessed a penalty of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each check
so returned, plus any late charges as may be required. This twenty five dollar
($25.00) penalty may be added onto the user's next or any subsequent water and
sewer bill. (Ord. 486, 10-24-1995)
9-6-19: EXCEPTIONS AND EXTENSIONS:
   A.   Office Authorized Extensions: Any service user may, by contacting the
city clerk's office, receive a seven (7) day extension (beyond the first day of
the month) for payment of a water bill, but only if all previous water bills
are paid current. Any bill for which such an extension has been granted, not
paid by the end of the seven (7) day extension period, shall be deemed to be
delinquent and the service user shall be subject to disconnection of water
service.
   B.   Additional Authorized Extension: Any service user may be granted an
additional extension of time to pay a water bill (beyond a 7 day office
authorized extension) for good cause shown, by applying for and being granted
same by either the chairman of the water and sewer committee of the city
council, the mayor or the city clerk, or in the absence of all three (3) of
said city officials, then by any member of the city council, but in no event
shall such an additional extension be for a period of time in excess of twenty
one (21) days beyond the expiration of an office authorized extension. An
additional authorized extension may be granted only if all previous water bills
(of the applicant) are paid current. Any water bill for which an additional
authorized extension has been granted which has not been paid by the end of
such extension period shall be deemed delinquent and the service user shall be
subject to a disconnection of water service.
   C.   Partial Payments: Payments of one-half (1/2) or more (of the monthly
water bill) may be accepted for any monthly bill without such water bill being
deemed delinquent, but only if all previous water bills are fully paid up and
current. Any water bill for which a partial payment has been accepted must be
paid up in full by no later than the payment due date of the service user's
next succeeding monthly water bill.
   D.   High Usage Exception: If any service user has an unusually high water
usage for any given month, a two (2) part payment (on that month's water bill
only) may be granted to the service user at the discretion of the water
superintendent, chairman of the water and sewer committee of the city council,
mayor or city clerk, without such water bill being deemed delinquent. Any water
bill for which a high usage exception is granted, must be paid up in full by no
later than the payment due date of the service user's next succeeding monthly
water bill. For purposes of this section, an "unusually high water usage" shall
mean usage in excess of one hundred seventy five percent (175%) of the user's
average water usage for the immediately preceding six (6) months. A high usage
exception when promptly paid as above provided shall not be subject to any
"late charges".
   E.   Special Payment Due Date Exception: Any service user on a fixed income
or in a similar circumstance may, upon application to the chairman of the water
and sewer committee of the city council, be granted a different monthly payment
due date, subject to all other requirements of these regulations, and if same
is granted, any allowable exceptions or extensions, late payment charges and
delinquencies shall be determined as of such adjusted monthly due date.
   F.   Unforeseen Events:
      1.   In the event any service user experiences any unforeseen event, such
as a broken water pipe, catastrophe, act of God or similar event which causes
an abnormal amount of water to run through the user's water meter, and which
said water is not in fact used or consumed by the user, then in such event, the
user may apply to the Superintendent for an abatement of water service charges
as set forth in section
9-6-16 of this chapter. No event will be considered to be an "unforeseen event"
as contemplated herein, unless the quantity of water which runs through the
service user's water meter for the billing period during which the event occurs
is at least two hundred percent (200%) of the service user's average monthly
water bill for the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the event, or if
twelve (12) immediately preceding water bills are not available for said
service user, then the average for the number of, consecutive months preceding
the event which are available.
      2.   Upon the finding by the Superintendent that a legitimate, unforeseen
event (as described in this subsection F) has occurred, he may abate all or any
part of the water service charge for the period or periods as affected by the
excess usage, but in no event may the service user be charged less than one
dollar ($1.00) per thousand gallons of water consumed during the unforeseen
event in excess of the monthly average (as described in subsection F1 of this
section).
      3.   If any service user affected by an unforeseen event as contemplated
herein is not satisfied by the ruling of the Superintendent as to an adjustment
of the water service charge, said service user may appeal the decision of the
Superintendent to the Water and Sewer Committee of the City Council.
      4.   The Water and Sewer Committee may, by majority vote thereof, affirm
the ruling of the Superintendent or adjust his ruling upward or downward within
the limits prescribed in this subsection. The vote of the Water and Sewer
Committee shall be final with respect to the water service charge in question.
(Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-6-20: DELINQUENCIES:
   A.   Any water bill not paid by the first day of each month following
receipt thereof by the service user shall be deemed to be delinquent.
   B.   Any water service user, who has been deemed delinquent and fails to pay
before nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. on the shutoff date, shall be charged an
administrative fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 753, 9-8-2008, eff.
11-1-2008)
9-6-21: DISCONNECTION:
   A.   Any water service user, whose bill is not paid by the due date, and
delinquent, shall be subject to having his or her water service disconnected
without any further notice. (Ord. 877, 5-14-2018, eff. 7-1-2018)
   B.   Whenever water service is disconnected to any nonowner occupied (or
used) premises, the City will attempt to notify the owner thereof (if owner's
identity is known) of the fact of disconnection. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-6-22: RECONNECTION PROCEDURES AND FEES:
There are hereby established reconnection procedures and fees for the Municipal
water system of the City of Marquette Heights.
   A.   Payment In Full Required: Any service user whose water service has been
disconnected for nonpayment of a water bill may have water service restored by
the payment of the bill in full, plus all required administrative charges and
reconnection fees due on such unpaid bill.
   B.   Water Service Reconnection Fee:
      1.   Water service reconnection fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for
the reconnection.
      2.   An additional twenty five dollars ($25.00) will be added to the
connection fee if the reconnection occurs after office hours. (Ord. 877, 5-14-
2018, eff. 7-1-2018)
9-6-23: LIABILITY OF OWNER, OCCUPANT AND SERVICE USER:
The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the service user of the
utility services provided by the city shall be jointly and severally liable for
payment of the utility service on the premises, and the utility service is
furnished to the premises by the city only upon the condition that the owner of
the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the utility service are
