jointly and severally liable thereof to the city. (Ord. 706, 3-13-2006)

9-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used
in this chapter shall be as follows:
ACT: The federal water pollution control act, as amended, 33 USC 1151 et seq.
ADMINISTRATOR: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency.
BOD (Denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand): The quantity of oxygen utilized in
the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure
in five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C), expressed in milligrams
per liter.
BUILDING DRAIN: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system
which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside
the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five
feet (5') outside the inner face of the building wall.
BUILDING SEWER: The sewer pipe from the building drain to the connection point
on the public sewer main or other place of disposal.
CITY: The city of Marquette Heights and any reference to "within the city"
shall mean all territory within the perimeter of the city of Marquette Heights
boundaries.
COMBINED SEWER: A sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage.
COMMERCIAL USER: Any user of publicly owned treatment works identified in the
"Standard Industrial Classification Manual", 1972, office of management and
budget, as amended and supplemented, under the following divisions:
 
Division F Wholesale trade.
Division G Retail trade.
Division H Finance, insurance and real estate.
Division I Services except establishments that discharge "industrial wastes".
 
COMPATIBLE POLLUTANT: Biochemical oxygen demand, suspended solids, pH and fecal
coliform bacteria, plus additional pollutants identified in the NPDES permit.
DEBT SERVICE CHARGE: A charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost
of any bond debt to be paid by revenue generated from the operation of the
treatment works.
DEPRECIATION: The decrease in the monetary value of an asset with time.
DIRECTOR: The chief administrative officer of a state water pollution control
agency or interstate agency. In the event responsibility for water pollution
control and enforcement is divided among two (2) or more state or interstate
agencies, the term "director" means the administrative officer authorized to
perform the particular procedure to which reference is made.
EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
FEDERAL GRANT: The U.S. government participation in the financing of the
construction of treatment works as provided for by title II - grants for
construction of treatment works in the act.
FLOATABLE OIL: Oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will
separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment
facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable oil if it is
properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection
system.
GARBAGE: Solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking,
and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce.
INCOMPATIBLE POLLUTANT: Any pollutant which is not a "compatible pollutant" as
defined in this section.
INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVERY: Recovery by the grantee from the industrial users of
a treatment works the grant amount allocable to the treatment of wastes from
such users pursuant to section 204(b) of the act.
INDUSTRIAL USER: Any user of publicly owned treatment works identified in the
"Standard Industrial Classification Manual", 1972, office of management and
budget, as amended and supplemented, under the following divisions:
 
Division A Agriculture, forestry and fishing.
Division B Mining.
Division D Manufacturing.
Division E Transportation, communications, electric, gas and sanitary services.
Division I Services.
 
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: The wastewater discharges from industrial manufacturing
process, trade, or business separate from or in combination with their
employees' domestic wastes and wastes from sanitary conveniences.
INTERGOVERNMENTAL AGREEMENT: That agreement entered into between the city of
Marquette Heights, Illinois, and the village of Creve Coeur, Illinois, and
dated December 18, 1982, pertaining to (among other things) the use, operations
and maintenance by said city and village of the combined Creve Coeur/Marquette
Heights regional sewage treatment facility and establishing certain rights and
obligations between said city and village with respect thereto.
MAJOR CONTRIBUTING INDUSTRY (Significant Industrial User): An industrial user
of the publicly owned treatment works that:
   A.   Has a flow of twenty five thousand (25,000) gallons or more per average
workday;
   B.   Discharges more than seventy three (73) pounds per day of BOD5 or
suspended solids;
   C.   Has in its waste, a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in
standards issued under section 307(a) of the act; or
   D.   Is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the
issuance of an NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving the
waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other
contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of
effluent from that treatment works.
MILLIGRAMS PER LITER: A unit of the concentration of water or wastewater
constituent. It is 0.001 gram of the constituent in one thousand milliliters
(1,000 ml) of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly (parts per
million) to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting results of water
and wastewater analyses.
NPDES PERMIT: Any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the
administrator, or, where appropriate by the director, after enactment of the
federal water pollution control amendments of 1972, to regulate the discharge
of pollutants pursuant to section 402 of the act.
NATURAL OUTLET: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body
of surface or ground water.
OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE: Those actions, materials and services necessary for
the proper functioning of treatment and collection facilities over their useful
life.
ppm: Parts per million by weight.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or
group.
pH: The logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per
liter of solution.
POPULATION EQUIVALENT: A term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or
other waste on a treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is one
hundred (100) gallons of sewage per day, containing seventeen hundredths (0.17)
pound of BOD and twenty hundredths (0.20) pound of suspended solids. The impact
on a treatment works is evaluated as the equivalent of the highest of the three
(3) parameters. Impact on a stream is the higher of the BOD and suspended
solids parameters.
PRETREATMENT: The treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction
into the wastewater treatment works.
PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and
dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles
will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public
sewers, with no particles greater than one-half inch (1/2") in any dimension.
PUBLIC SEWER: A sewer main in which all owners of abutting properties have
equal rights, and is controlled by public authority.
REPLACEMENT: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories,
or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of the treatment
works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were
designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes
replacement.
RESIDENTIAL USER: Any single-family residence, or any single- family quarters
as a part of a duplex, apartment house or multi-family dwellings and complexes
shall be defined as a separate residential user of the system.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface, and
ground waters are not intentionally admitted.
SEWAGE: A combination of the water carried wastes from residences, business
buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such
ground, surface, and storm waters as may be present.
SEWAGE TREATMENT PLANT: Any arrangement of devices and structures used for
treating sewage.
SEWAGE WORKS: All facilities for collection, pumping, treating, and disposal of
sewage.
SEWER: A pipe or conduit for carrying sewage.
SEWER RATE: A charge for the use of and services supplied by the sewage works
of the city. This charge shall consist of a "user charge" and a "debt service
charge" as such terms are defined in this section.
SHALL: Is mandatory; "may" is permissive.
SLUG: Any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste which in
concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any
period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times
the average twenty four (24) hour concentration or flow during normal
operation.
STORM DRAIN (Sometimes Termed STORM SEWER): A sewer which carries storm and
surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other
than unpolluted cooling water.
SUPERINTENDENT: An employee of the city charged with the responsibility of
overseeing the general day to day operation of the sewage works.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in
suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by
laboratory filtering.
UNPOLLUTED WATER: Water of quality equal to or better than the effluent
criteria, in effect, and water that would not cause violation of receiving
water quality standards.
USEFUL LIFE: The estimated period during which the treatment works will be
operated and is anticipated to exceed thirty (30) years from the date of
startup of any wastewater facilities constructed with a federal grant.
USER (OR USER OF THE SYSTEM, OR SYSTEM USER): Any person who occupies any
building which is connected to the public sewer, or, in the case of an
unoccupied building, any person who owns any building which is connected to the
public sewer.
USER CHARGE: A charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of
operation and maintenance including replacement.
USER CLASS: The type of user either "residential", "commercial" or
"industrial", as defined herein.
WASTEWATER: The spent water of a community. From this standpoint, of course, it
may be a combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from residences,
commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with any
ground water, surface water, and stormwater that may be present.
WASTEWATER FACILITIES: The structures, equipment, and processes required to
collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of
the effluent.
WASTEWATER TREATMENT WORKS: An arrangement of devices and structures for
treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge. Sometimes used as
synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "pollution control plant".
WATERCOURSE: A channel in which flow of water occurs, either continuously or
intermittently. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-2: WATER POLLUTION CONTROL:
   A.   The superintendent of the combined waterworks and sewage department
shall have general supervision of the public sewers and sewage treatment plant
of the city. He shall ascertain the conditions and needs thereof and shall from
time to time report the same to the city council. The superintendent shall keep
proper records of the location of all sewers, Y branches, and building sewer
connections and the condition of private sewage disposal systems and building
sewers. He shall also have the duties specifically set forth in this chapter
and shall have authority to supervise the construction and installation of
building sewers and to issue permits therefor. The superintendent shall be
responsible for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter, and he is
hereby authorized to make such inspections, observations, and measurements, and
authorized to enter any property for that purpose. (Ord. 708, 6-12-2006)
9-7-3: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be
deposited in an unsanitary manner on public or private property within the
city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said city, any human or animal
excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the
city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said city, any sewage or other
polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in
accordance with subsequent provisions of this chapter.
   C.   Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or
maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility
intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
   D.   The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human
occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes, situated within the city
and abutting on any street, alley, or right of way in which there is now
located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of
the city, is hereby required at his own expense to install suitable toilet
facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper
public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within ninety
(90) days after date of notice by certified letter, return receipt requested,
to do so, provided that said public sewer is within two hundred feet (200') of
the property line, and provided capacity is available in downstream sewers,
lift stations, pumping stations, force mains and the sewage treatment plant
including pollutant removal capacity for BOD and suspended solids. (Ord. 390,
9-11-1989)
9-7-4: LATERAL CONNECTION (SEWERS):
   A.   A lateral connection is the building drain and building sewer from the
main sanitary sewer into any lot, property or tract of land.
   B.   The owner of any lot, property or tract of land shall be responsible
for the maintenance and repair of all lateral connections from the point of
connection with the main sanitary sewer to any other point on the property
serviced, and the city shall have no responsibility for the repair and
maintenance of same.
   C.   When any failure, obstruction or other malfunction of any lateral
connection is the apparent cause of surface deterioration (such as erosion,
sinkholes or the like) within any public right of way and, in the opinion of
the superintendent, such surface deterioration poses an immediate threat to
public health or to the safety of persons and/or property within such public
right of way, then in such event, the city may, after notice to the owner(s) of
the property served by the failed, obstructed or malfunctioning lateral
connection, make such repairs or alterations to the lateral connection as may
be necessary to correct the problem and recover the cost of such repairs or
alterations from the owner(s) of the property served by such lateral
connection. (Ord. 818, 5-28-2013)
9-7-5: CONNECTIONS, PERMITS REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   No unauthorized persons shall uncover, make any connections with or
opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof
without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent.
   B.   There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits:
      1.   For residential service, and
      2.   For service to a commercial or industrial user.
      In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a
special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall besupplemented
by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the
judgment of the superintendent.
   C.   A permit and inspection fee shall be paid to the city clerk at the time
of application for permit. The minimum fee for permit and inspection of sewer
connection for users within the city limits shall be two thousand dollars
($2,000.00) for each single-family residential permit; that for each additional
single residential unit of a multiple-unit dwelling, an additional charge of
one hundred dollars ($100.00) per unit; that for a commercial or industrial
permit a fee of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) for each building; that for
each additional establishment in a single commercial or industrial building,
single-family apartments in a commercial building, or each room in motels,
hotels and nursing care facilities, an additional charge of one hundred dollars
($100.00). (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989; amd. Ord. 851, 5-9-2016; Ord. 930, 11-14-2022)
9-7-6: INSTALLATION:
All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the
building sewer to the public sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall
indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be
occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-7: NONCONFORMING SEWERS:
Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they
are found, on examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all
requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-8: SEWER SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   The building sewer shall be polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipe, SDR-35
minimum, conforming to ASTM specifications D-3034 type PSM with solvent weld
joints conforming to ASTM D-2855 or flexible elastomeric seals per ASTM D-3212.
Joints shall be tight and waterproof. Any part of the building sewer that is
located within ten feet (10') of a water service pipe shall be laid in a
separate trench and at such an elevation that the top of the sewer is at least
eighteen inches (18") below the bottom of the water service pipe. If it is
impossible to obtain a vertical separation of at least eighteen inches (18"),
as stipulated above, the sewer shall be constructed of mechanical or slip on
joint ductile iron pipe, and be tested to assure watertightness.
   B.   The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the
approval of the superintendent. The diameter shall be not less than six inches
(6"). The slope of such six inch (6") pipe shall be not less than one foot (1')
per one hundred feet (100'). For larger sizes of pipe, the minimum slopes shall
be according to all state and local regulations. Multiple housing units,
commercial and industrial building sewers shall be not less than six inches
(6") diameter.
   C.   All building sewers shall be provided an exterior tee type cleanout
located within ten feet (10') of the exterior foundation wall. The cleanout
shall be six inches (6") diameter and terminate four inches (4") below the
finished grade. A threaded plug shall be used to seal the cleanout.
   D.   Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building
at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be laid
parallel to any bearing wall if within three feet (3') of any said wall, which
might thereby be weakened. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection
from frost. The building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight
alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction or grade shall be allowed
only when a proper manhole is constructed at the location of the change. (Ord.
390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-9: LOW BUILDING DRAIN:
In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow
to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by
approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. Such approval
shall be obtained from the superintendent as part of the permitting process.
(Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-10: ROOF DOWNSPOUTS:
No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains,
areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or ground water to a
building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or
indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. Such connections may be made to sewers
designated as combined sewers. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-11: EXCAVATIONS:
   A.   All excavations required for the installation of a building sewer shall
be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the superintendent. Pipe
laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM specification
(C12-58-T) (or most current ASTM designation) except that no backfill shall be
placed until the work has been inspected.
   B.   All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately
guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course
of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city, and any
other governmental agency affected. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-12: CONNECTIONS:
   A.   All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight.
   B.   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer main shall
be made at the Y branch, if such branch is available at a suitable location. If
the public sewer is twelve inches (12") in diameter or less, and no properly
located Y branch is available, the owner shall, at his expense, install a Y
branch in the public sewer at the location specified by the superintendent.
Where the public sewer is greater than twelve inches (12") in diameter, and no
properly located Y branch is available, a neat machined hole may be cut into
the public sewer to receive the building sewer, with entry in the downstream
direction at an angle of about forty five degrees (45°). A forty five degree
(45°) ell may be used to make such connection with the spigot end cut so as not
to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert of the
building sewer at the point of connection shall be at the same or at a higher
elevation than the invert of the public sewer, but no higher than a point one-
half (1/2) the vertical distance between the invert and the crown of the sewer.
A smooth, neat joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and
watertight by encasement in concrete. Special fittings may be used for the
connection only when approved by the superintendent. Manholes shall be
constructed at any junction of an eight inch (8") diameter or larger building
sewer into a public sewer.
   C.   No building sewer connection shall be made in a manhole unless such
manhole is designed and constructed to receive such building sewer.
   D.   The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the
superintendent when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection
to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the
superintendent or his representative between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and four
o'clock (4:00) P.M. Monday through Friday except holidays.
   E.   No new connection shall be made to a public sewer which would cause the
average daily organic loading to exceed six hundred forty nine (649) pounds of
BOD or cause the average daily flow to exceed 0.42 million gallons per day
influent to the wastewater treatment facilities. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-13: USE OF THE PUBLIC SEWERS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the city to
tamper with, alter, injure or obstruct any part of the combined waterworks and
sewerage system. Any person violating this section shall be liable for the
damage caused in addition to any penalty imposed.
   B.   No person shall discharge or cause, by sump pump or any other means, to
be discharged any stormwater, surface water, ground water, roof runoff,
subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial
process waters to any sewer which is designated a sanitary sewer.
   C.   Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to
such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers,
or to a natural outlet approved by the superintendent. Industrial cooling water
or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the
superintendent, to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet.
   D.   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the
following described waters or wastes to any public sewers:
      1.   Sand, gravel, soil, metal filings, broken glass or any material
which by its nature could create an obstruction in the sewer.
      2.   Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, waste engine oil, or other
flammable or explosive liquid, solid, or gas.
      3.   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids,
or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other
wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a
hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in
the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant.
      4.   Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5, or having any other
corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures,
equipment, and personnel of the sewage works.
      5.   Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of
causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the
proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes,
cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar,
plastics, wood, underground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and
fleshings, entrails, and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either
whole or ground by garbage grinders.
      6.   Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 mg/l as Hg
at any time except as may be permitted based on the conditions of the "water
pollution regulations of Illinois", rule 702. A special permit must be obtained
from the superintendent prior to the discharge of any mercury in excess of
0.0005 mg/l as Hg.
      7.   Any waste containing detectable levels of cyanide at any time except
as permitted with the approval of the Illinois environmental protection agency
as specified in the "water pollution regulations of Illinois", rule 703.
   E.   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following
described substances, materials, waters, or wastes:
      1.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) (65°C).
      2.   Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease or oils, whether
emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred milligrams per liter (100 mg/l) or
containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures
between thirty two degrees (32°) and one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit
(150°F) (0° - 65°C).
      3.   Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation
and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/
4) horsepower or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the
superintendent.
      4.   Any waters or wastes containing strong acid iron pickling wastes, or
concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not.
      5.   Any waters or wastes containing in excess of the following
concentrations and similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes
exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such
material received in the composite sewage at the treatment works exceeds the
limits established by the superintendent or the current national pollutant
discharge elimination system permit (NPDES) for such materials.
Waste Or Chemical  Concentration (mg/l)
Waste Or Chemical              Concentration (mg/l)
                              
Arsenic                       0.25
Barium                        2.0
Boron                         1.0
Cadmium                       0.15
Chlorine demand               30.0
Chromium (hexavalent)         0.3
Chromium (trivalent)          1.0
Copper                        3.0
Fluoride                      2.5
Iron (total)                  2.0
Lead                          0.1
Manganese                     1.0

Oil and grease, etc. (carbon   
tetrachloride 100.0)
Phenols                       0.3
Selenium                      1.0
Silver                        0.1
Zinc                          1.0
 
      6.   Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor
producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be
established by the superintendent as necessary, after treatment of the
composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other
public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters.
      7.   Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or
concentration as may exceed limits established by the superintendent in
compliance with applicable state or federal regulations.
      8.   Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of 10.5.
      9.   Materials which exert or cause:
         a.   Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but
not limited to, fuller's earth, lime slurries and lime residues) or of
dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium
sulfate).
         b.   Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes
and vegetable tanning solutions).
         c.   Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in
such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment
works.
         d.   Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting
"slugs" as defined herein.
      10.   Water or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to
treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are
amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant
effluent cannot meet the requirements of the current national pollutant
discharge elimination system permit (NPDES) or other agencies having
jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters.
   F.   The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes having: 1)
a five (5) day biochemical oxygen demand greater than three hundred fifty
milligrams per liter (350 mg/l), or 2) containing more than four hundred
fifteen milligrams per liter (415 mg/l) of suspended solids, or 3) containing
any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in subsection D
of this section, or 4) having an average daily flow greater than two percent
(2%) of the average daily sewage flow of the wastewater treatment plant shall
be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent. Acceptance of
wastes not meeting the above stated requirements alone or in combination with
the domestic sanitary waste from the source shall be consistent with the city's
current NPDES permit, chapter 3 of the Illinois pollution control board rules
and regulations and the intergovernmental agreement between the village of
Creve Coeur and the city of Marquette Heights. Where necessary in the opinion
of the superintendent, the owner of any property discharging industrial waste
shall provide, at his expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary
to: 1) reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to three hundred fifty milligrams
per liter (350 mg/l) or 2) reduce objectionable characteristics or constituents
to within the maximum limits provided for in subsection D of this section, or
3) control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters or wastes.
Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to proposed
pretreatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the
superintendent and of the environmental protection agency of the state of
Illinois, and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until said
approvals are obtained in writing.
   G.   Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when in the
opinion of the superintendent, they are necessary for the proper handling of
liquid wastes containing grease, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other
harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for
private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type
and capacity approved by the superintendent, and shall be located as to be
readily and easily available for cleaning and inspection. Grease and oil
interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of
withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall be of
substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily removable covers
which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight. Where installed,
all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at his
expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times.
   H.   Where preliminary treatment or flow equalizing facilities are provided
for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory
and effective operation by the owner at his expense.
   I.   When required by the superintendent, the owner of any property serviced
by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control
manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the
building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the
wastes. Such manholes shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be
constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent. The
manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained
by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. The owner shall install
such control manhole within ninety (90) days of the date of written
notification to do so.
   J.   All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters
and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods For The Examination Of
Waste And Wastewater", published by the American Public Health Association, and
the most current edition of "Guidelines Establishing Test Procedures For
Analysis Of Pollutants" as published in 40 CFR, part 136. All measurements,
tests and analyses of the characteristics of water and wastes to which
reference is made in this chapter shall be determined at the control manhole
provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event
that no special manhole exists as provided for by subsection I of this section,
the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in
the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected provided
the superintendent shall be permitted to take samples within the premises of
the user, including lagoons, ponds, and other places. Sampling shall be carried
out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon
the sewage work and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and
property. The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty four
(24) hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a
grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and
suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty four (24) hour composites of
all outfalls, whereas pHs are determined from periodic samples. Each "major
contributing industry" shall be responsible for monitoring its own discharge as
required by the city's NPDES permit. As a minimum, testing will be required on
a semiannual basis for BOD5, SS, pH and those toxic chemicals listed in
subsection E5 of this section contained in the waste stream. Samples shall be
collected and tested during the month of May and November each year with the
results reported to the city by June 30 and December 30 of that year.
   K.   No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing
any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial
concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character (not
otherwise permitted by this chapter) may be accepted by the city for treatment
subject to payment therefor in accordance with section
9-7-17, "User Charge System", of this chapter. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-14: PROTECTION FROM DAMAGE:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently break,
damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or
equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Any person violating this
section shall be liable to the city for the amount of damage(s) caused in
addition to any other fine or penalty which may be imposed. (Ord. 390, 9-11-
1989)
9-7-15: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
   A.   Subject to the requirements of law regarding entry upon private
property, the superintendent, his subordinates, any duly authorized peace
officer of the city, and any duly authorized employee of the Illinois
environmental protection agency and/or the United States environmental
protection agency, bearing proper credentials are hereby authorized to enter
upon any property in the city for the purpose of inspection, observation,
measurement, sampling, or testing in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter.
   B.   While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to
in subsection A of this section, the superintendent or duly authorized
employees of the city, the Illinois and/or United States environmental
protection agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises
established by the company and the company shall be held harmless for injury or
death to the city employees and the city shall indemnify the company against
loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims
and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company
and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be
caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as
required in subsection 9-7-13I of this chapter.
   C.   The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city, the
Illinois and/or United States environmental protection agency bearing proper
credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private
properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the
purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying
within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement,
shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement
pertaining to the private property involved. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-16: PRETREATMENT:
   A.   Wastes not in conformance with subsections 9-7-13D4, E8 and F of this
chapter, shall require pretreatment of compatible pollutants.
   B.   In addition to the prohibitions set forth in subsections 9-7-13D and E
of this chapter, the pretreatment standard for incompatible pollutants
introduced into a treatment works by a major contributing industry shall be
that established by a promulgated effluent limitations guideline defining best
practicable control technology currently available pursuant to sections 301(b)
and 304(b) of the act. Compliance with pretreatment standards shall be as
provided for by the act and subsequent rules and regulations as promulgated by
the administrator. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-17: USER CHARGE SYSTEM:
   A.   There shall be monthly rates and charges for the residential,
commercial and industrial users for the use of and services supplied by the
sewerage system of the city of Marquette Heights, Tazewell County, Illinois.
The monthly sewer rate incorporates costs to the city for use of the Creve
Coeur regional treatment plant and costs of operation, maintenance, replacement
and debt service for the city sewer collection system. The city is obligated by
terms of the intergovernmental agreement, dated December 18, 1982, to pay the
village of Creve Coeur a user charge computed in accordance with sections XI,
XII, XIII, and exhibit A of the intergovernmental agreement.
   B.   There shall be no distinctions between and among classes of users of
the system, and all users shall pay the same rates as set forth herein
regardless of whether or not they live or are located within or without the
city limits. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
   C.   As of the effective date of this chapter, all users of the system shall
pay a minimum bill of eight dollars forty five cents ($8.45) per month to cover
the following costs:
 
Fixed overhead associated with operation and maintenance of the      $4.95
wastewater treatment system
Sewer main rehabilitation                                              3.50
                                                               Total $8.45
 
This minimum charge shall be billed to every user of the system, regardless of
whether or not the premises being charged such are occupied. (Ord. 786, 3-28-
2011)
   D.   Beginning with bills mailed on or after May 1, 2007, $0.339 per one
hundred (100) gallons of water used or where water consumption does not reflect
the actual quantity of wastewater tributary to the wastewater treatment plant,
$0.339 per one hundred (100) gallons of wastewater as recorded in a control
manhole as required by subsection 9-7-13I of this chapter. On May 1, 2008, and
on each May 1 thereafter, the city clerk shall adjust each of the foregoing
rates by adding to the respective rates in effect on the date of adjustment a
sum equal to three percent (3%) of such rates.
The minimum monthly charges and rates in effect prior to May 1, 2007, that
continue to apply with respect to wastewater discharged and billed prior to May
1, 2007. (Ord. 752, 8-11-2008)
   E.   When the average concentration of BOD exceeds three hundred twenty nine
milligrams per liter (329 mg/l), and/or suspended solids exceeds three hundred
eighty seven milligrams per liter (387 mg/l) a surcharge shall be added to the
base user rate. The surcharge shall be calculated by dividing the annual
treatment costs associated with treatment of BOD or suspended solids by the
current average annual loading to the treatment plant. This surcharge shall be
equal to eight cents ($0.08) per pound BOD and/or eight cents ($0.08) per pound
of suspended solids in excess of the limit. No credit shall be given for a
waste where the BOD or suspended solids are less than the limit. All
measurements, tests and analyses of characteristics of water and wastes to
determine the surcharge shall be conducted in conformance with section
9-7-13 of this chapter.
   F.   The city shall independently audit operation, maintenance and debt
service costs for the wastewater facilities, review sewer rates and charges
annually and revise sewer rates and charges periodically to reflect actual
treatment works operation and maintenance costs and the cost of debt service.
The city shall also annually review user charges and revise as necessary to
ensure that total user charges for each user class are proportional to usage of
the wastewater facilities of the city. The city shall notify annually all users
of the system within the first month of the fiscal year of the current monthly
rates charged for use of the sewerage system of the city. Nothing herein shall
be construed as prohibiting the city from making rate adjustments at any other
time during any fiscal year.
   G.   All users of the sewerage system who do not use the water services of
the city shall be required to install a metering device approved by the
superintendent which records the total sewage flow for the purpose of
determining the basis for sewer rates as provided by subsection D of this
section.
   H.   The city shall calculate necessary user charges to be billed monthly to
recover the fixed costs, debt service costs, operation and maintenance costs
and replacement cost attributed to providing sewerage services to the users of
the system. Each user and user class shall be responsible for its equitable and
proportionate costs to the city for provision of the service.
The city shall inventory the system users by user class and define the
wastewater use and waste characteristics of each user class. Whenever the waste
characteristics of the three (3) user classes are similar and no distinguishing
differences in waste characteristics attribute to differential cost for
operation of the system, all user classes shall be charged the same equitable
rates.
The rates shall be calculated as follows:

9-7-18: SECOND METER OPTION:
   A.   Any user of the city sewer system (except users without a water meter)
may, at his or her election, have installed at the use premises a second water
meter for the purpose of metering that water usage at a location at the use
premises which is not returned or drained into the city sewer system. In such
event, the second meter shall be designated the "second meter" and the regular
meter shall be designated the "master meter". In the event any user elects the
option permitted in this section, then the sewer use charge shall be calculated
by subtracting the usage recorded on the second meter from the usage recorded
on the master meter.
   B.   The specific location of the second meter on or at any use premises
shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent.
   C.   Any user electing to take advantage of the option to install a second
meter shall obtain such meter from the water and sewer department of the city,
which shall lease said second meter to the user thereof for a nonrefundable,
one time lease payment equal to the cost to the city for said meter. Any second
meter leased to a user shall at all times remain the property of the city, but
the user thereof, upon payment of the one time lease fee, shall have the use
thereof for as long as he or she desires to avail himself or herself of the
second meter option as herein provided. Installation of the second meter shall
be at the expense of the user and subject to the approval of the
superintendent. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-19: LATE CHARGES:
   A.   All sewer bills not paid by the twentieth day of the month following
the receipt thereof by the service user, shall be subject to a "late charge". A
penalty of ten percent (10%) shall be added to all bills not paid by the
twentieth day of the month in which they are sent out, and a like amount for
each month thereafter or any part thereof that the bill is not paid.
   B.   Whenever any check is received by the city for the payment of any water
and/or sewer bill is returned by the drawee bank for nonsufficient funds, said
user shall be assessed a penalty of five dollars ($5.00) for each check so
returned, plus any late charges as may be required. This five dollar ($5.00)
penalty may be added on to the user's next or any subsequent water and/or sewer
bill. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-20: EXCEPTIONS AND EXTENSIONS:
   A.   Office Authorized Extensions: Any service user may, by contacting the
city clerk's office, receive a seven (7) day extension (beyond the first day of
the month) for payment of a sewer bill, but only if all previous sewer bills
are paid current. Any bill for which such an extension has been granted, not
paid by the end of the seven (7) day extension period shall be deemed to be
delinquent and the service user shall be subject to disconnection of sewer
service.
   B.   Additional Authorized Extension: Any service user may be granted an
additional extension of time to pay a sewer bill (beyond a 7 day office
authorized extension) for good cause shown, by applying for and being granted
either the chairman of the water and sewer committee of the city council, the
mayor or the city clerk, or in the absence of all three (3) of said city
officials, then by any member of the city council, but in no event shall such
an additional extension be for a period of time in excess of twenty one (21)
days beyond the expiration of an office authorized extension. An additional
authorized extension may be granted only if all previous sewer bills (of the
applicant) are paid current. Any bill for which an additional authorized
extension has been granted which has not been paid by the end of such extension
period shall be deemed delinquent and the service user shall be subject to a
disconnection of sewer service.
   C.   Partial Payments: Payments of one-half (1/2) or more (of the monthly
sewer bill) may be accepted for any monthly bill without such sewer bill being
deemed delinquent, but only if all previous sewer bills are fully paid up and
current. Any sewer bill for which a partial payment has been accepted must be
paid up in full by no later than the payment due date of the service user's
next succeeding monthly sewer bill.
   D.   High Usage Exception: If any service user has an unusually high water
usage for any given month, a two (2) part payment (on that month's sewer bill
only) may be granted to the service user at the discretion of the water
superintendent, chairman of the water and sewer committee of the city council,
mayor or city clerk, without such sewer bill being deemed delinquent. Any water
bill for which a high usage exception is granted, must be paid up in full by no
later than the payment due date of the service user's next succeeding monthly
sewer bill. For purposes of this section, an "unusually high water usage" shall
mean usage in excess of one hundred seventy five percent (175%) of the user's
average water usage for the immediately preceding six (6) months. A high usage
exception when promptly paid as above provided, shall not be subject to any
"late charges".
   E.   Special Payment Due Date Exception: Any service user on a fixed income
or in a similar circumstance may, upon application to the chairman of the water
and sewer committee of the city council, be granted a different monthly payment
due date, subject to all other requirements of these regulations, and if same
is granted, any allowable exceptions or extensions and late payment charges
shall be determined as of such adjusted monthly due date.
   F.   Unforeseen Events:
      1.   In the event any service user experiences any unforeseen event, such
as a broken water pipe, catastrophe, act of God or similar event which causes
an abnormal amount of water to run through the user's water meter, and which
said water is not returned to the city sewer system, then in such event, the
user may apply to the superintendent for an abatement of sewer service charges
as set forth in subsection 9-7-17D of this chapter.
      2.   Upon the finding by the superintendent that a legitimate, unforeseen
event (as prescribed in this subsection) has occurred, he may abate all or any
part of the sewer service charge for the period or periods so affected by the
excess usage, but in no event may the service user be charged less than the
average of the sewer service charges for that location for the twelve (12)
month period next preceding the unforeseen event, or if no twelve (12) month
history is available, then the average sewer service charge for the preceding
months for which such records are available.
      3.   If any service user affected by an unforeseen event as contemplated
herein is not satisfied by the ruling of the superintendent as to an abatement
of the sewer service charge, said service user may appeal the decision of the
superintendent to the water and sewer committee of the city council.
      4.   The water and sewer committee may, by majority vote thereof, affirm
the ruling of the superintendent or adjust his ruling upward or downward within
the limits prescribed in this subsection. The vote of the water and sewer
committee shall be final with respect to the sewer service charge in question.
(Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-21: BILLING AND PAYMENT DATES:
The city will send out sewer bills on or about the first day of each month for
all sewer service provided as of the most recent reading of each service user's
water meter, or flow meter, as the case may be. Sewer bills will be due and
payable on or before the twentieth day of each month following receipt thereof
by each service user. Each service user shall be deemed to have received his or
her monthly sewer bill on the fifth day after the sending thereof by the city
through the United States postal service. When the twentieth day of any month
shall be a Sunday or legal holiday, then such bills for service shall be
payable on the next succeeding business day without any additional penalty.
(Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-7-22: DELINQUENCIES:
Any sewer bill not paid by the first day of each month following receipt
thereof by the service user shall be deemed to be delinquent. (Ord. 390, 9-11-
1989)
CHAPTER 8
TREES AND SHRUBS
SECTION:
9-8-1: Definitions
9-8-2: Public Nuisance
9-8-3: Trees On Private Property
9-8-4: Planting And Removal Of Trees And Shrubs
9-8-5: Trees Prohibited
9-8-6: Tree Advisory Board
9-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the following meanings
unless the context in which they are used specifically indicates otherwise:
DANGEROUS TREE: Any tree or shrub which is either:
   A.   A diseased tree or shrub;
   B.   A tree or shrub which overhangs or blocks any sidewalk, street, or
other place in the city in such a manner as to impede or interfere with
vehicular or pedestrian traffic or travel upon such street, sidewalk or public
place;
   C.   Any tree or shrub of which any part thereof has become likely to fall
on or across any public way or place;
   D.   Is a dead tree or shrub;
   E.   Is a tree or shrub, the root structure of which poses an immediate
threat or interference to or with any underground water main, sewer main,
electrical or other utility conduit.
DISEASED TREE: Any tree or shrub infected with Dutch elm disease, verticillium
wilt, dothiodella, oak wilt or other injurious parasite, fungus or disease.
PARKWAY: That public area between the sidewalk and curb, of that public area
within the dedicated right of way not used for vehicular or pedestrian traffic
including, but not limited to, all streets and street rights of way, all
sidewalks and sidewalk rights of way, all alleys and alley rights of way and
any and all other public ways within the city.
PERSON: Any natural person, firm, partnership, corporation, company,
association or organization of any kind.
PROPERTY OWNER OR OWNERS: The person owning any lot or other tract of land in
the city as such ownership is reflected on the official records of the Tazewell
County recorder of deeds.
PUBLIC TREES: All shade and ornamental trees or shrubs now or hereafter growing
on any street, right of way, or other publicly owned land in the city.
RIGHT OF WAY: Land, property or other interest therein, usually in a strip,
acquired for or devoted to vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
STREET OR HIGHWAY: The entire width of every public right of way when any part
thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of
vehicular or pedestrian traffic. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-8-2: PUBLIC NUISANCE:
All diseased trees and/or dangerous trees are hereby declared to be a public
nuisance. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-8-3: TREES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   It shall be the duty of any person or persons owning or occupying any
real property in the city to remove from said property any diseased tree found
thereon.
   B.   It shall be the duty of any person or persons owning or occupying any
real property in the city to trim, otherwise abate or remove any dangerous tree
found on such property to the extent necessary so that said tree is no longer a
dangerous tree.
   C.   It shall be the duty of any person or persons owning or occupying real
property in the city, bordering on any street, sidewalk or other public way,
upon which property there may be trees, to prune such trees in such a manner
that they will not obstruct or shade streetlights, obstruct the passage of
pedestrians on sidewalks, the vision of traffic signs, traffic signals or
obstruct the view of any street or alley intersection. The minimum clearance of
any overhang thereof shall be seven feet (7') over sidewalks and sixteen feet
(16') over all streets and alleys.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupier of any real property in
the city to suffer or permit any dangerous tree to be found or to exist on such
property at any time.
   E.   It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupier of any real property in
the city to fail to abate any dangerous or diseased tree as required by
subsection A, B or C of this section.
   F.   Upon failure of any person or persons to remove, abate or prune tree or
trees as required by subsection A, B or C of this section, the city shall give
notice to said person or persons to remove, abate or prune said tree within
fourteen (14) days. Said notice shall be sent to said person or persons by
registered mail, return receipt requested, or may be served upon said person or
persons personally by a member of the Marquette Heights police department.
   G.   When any person or persons fail to remove, abate or prune any tree or
trees for which a notice has been given, as above provided, the city may enter
upon said person's or persons' property and remove, abate or prune said tree or
trees and the cost thereof shall be payable by the owner and collected as a
debt owed to the city. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-8-4: PLANTING AND REMOVAL OF TREES AND SHRUBS:
   A.   Permit Required For Planting And Removal: It shall be unlawful to
plant, prune or remove any tree or shrub in any public street or public parkway
or other public place without first securing a permit therefor. Application for
such permits shall be made to the city clerk and shall be referred by said
clerk to the appropriate committee of the city council, for approval or
disapproval.
   B.   Liability For Destruction And/Or Damage: Any person who removes or
damages any tree or shrub located on any street, parkway or any other public
place in violation of this section shall be liable to the city, in addition to
any other fine, penalty or costs assessed for said violation, for the value of
said tree or of the damage thereto, together with the cost for the replacement
or repair thereof.
   C.   Spacing, Location And Height Restrictions: No tree shall be planted
closer than the following:
      1.   Small trees (20 to 35 feet at maturity), thirty feet (30') from
closest tree.
      2.   Medium trees (35 to 60 feet at maturity), forty feet (40') from
closest tree.
      3.   Large trees (60 feet plus at maturity), fifty feet (50') from
closest tree.
      4.   No tree shall be planted closer than thirty five feet (35') to any
street corner. No tree shall be planted closer than ten feet (10') to any fire
hydrant.
      5.   No tree other than species under twenty feet (20') to thirty five
feet (35') may be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of any overhead
utility wire or over or within five (5) lateral feet of any underground water
line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-8-5: TREES PROHIBITED:
   A.   Certain Trees Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to plant any deciduous
tree on any parkway or public property in the city of the following species:
      1.   Eastern cottonwood;
      2.   American elm;
      3.   Weeping willow;
      4.   Poplar;
      5.   Silver maple;
      6.   River birch;
      7.   Any evergreen species; or
      8.   Any fruit bearing species.
   B.   Attaching Signs, Notices: It shall be unlawful to attach any sign,
advertisement or notice to any tree or shrub in any street, parkway or other
public place. (Ord. 741, 1-14-2008)
   C.   Wires On Or Near Trees: It shall be unlawful to attach any wire or rope
to any tree without permission of the city council.
   D.   Utility Providers: Any person or company given the right to maintain
poles and wires in the streets, alleys or other public ways in the city shall,
in the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such
wires and poles free from and away from any trees or shrubs in such places so
far as may be possible and shall keep all such trees and shrubs properly
trimmed and subject to the supervision of the superintendent of public works,
so that no injury shall be done to the poles or shrubs and trees by contact.
   E.   Right Of The City To Remove Undesirable Trees: The city shall have the
right to remove from any parkway or other city property any tree considered
undesirable or dangerous to any private property, or the public welfare and
safety. The superintendent, subject to review by the city council, shall
determine when such a tree shall be removed for the reason that its roots
interfere with or obstruct a private line. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-8-6: TREE ADVISORY BOARD:
   A.   Duties: The board shall act in an advisory capacity to the chair and
shall:
      1.   Coordinate and promote Arbor Day activities;
      2.   Review and update a five-year plan to plant and maintain trees on
city property;
      3.   Support public awareness and education programs relating to trees;
      4.   Review city department concerns relating to tree care;
      5.   Submit an annual report of its activities to the city council;
      6.   Assist with the annual application to renew the Tree City USA
designation;
      7.   Recommend a list of tree species for planting on city property, and
a list of prohibited species; and
      8.   Other duties that may be assigned by city council. (Ord. 949, 3-11-
2024)
CHAPTER 9
EMERGENCY WATER CONSERVATION REGULATION
SECTION:
9-9-1: Emergency Water Shortages
9-9-2: Declaration Of Emergency Water Shortages
9-9-3: Notice Of Emergency Water Shortages
9-9-4: Restrictions
9-9-5: Municipal Conservation
9-9-6: Further Restrictions
9-9-7: Variances
9-9-1: EMERGENCY WATER SHORTAGES:
Procedures described in this chapter are for circumstances related to the
occurrence of emergency water shortage situations, such as seasonal water
shortages, pressure drops, increased consumption, prolonged periods of drought
or similar circumstances. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-9-2: DECLARATION OF EMERGENCY WATER SHORTAGES:
The declaration of a shortage situation will be issued by the mayor, explaining
the situation, the expected duration (if such is reasonably possible), the
sequential actions which will take place and the penalties for violations. The
actions will remain in effect until rescinded. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-9-3: NOTICE OF EMERGENCY WATER SHORTAGES:
The declaration of an emergency water shortage shall be publicized by the city
through all available communication media and other practicable means available
at the time. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-9-4: RESTRICTIONS:
During periods of emergency water shortages, the following water use
restrictions shall apply throughout the city:
   A.   Watering of lawns and gardens, and washing of cars and other vehicles
initially will be restricted to between eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. and eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. Occupants with even numbered residences or other structures
will be permitted to water lawns and gardens on even numbered days, and
occupants of odd numbered residences or other structures, on odd numbered days.
By administrative proclamation, following the issuance of the initial
declaration, all lawn and garden watering and washing of cars and other
vehicles may be further restricted or prohibited if conditions warrant.
   B.   The refilling of swimming pools will be prohibited until further
notice.
   C.   Other prohibited uses are as follows:
      1.   Allowing water to run off to a gutter, ditch or drain during
watering of lawns and gardens.
      2.   Failure to repair a controllable leak within a customer's property.
      3.   Washing buildings, sidewalks, driveways, parking areas, tennis
courts, patios or other paved areas, except to alleviate immediate fire or
public health hazards.
      4.   Operation of any ornamental fountain or other structure making
similar use of water. The use of treated water to fill, refill, or maintain the
level of any fountain is prohibited. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-9-5: MUNICIPAL CONSERVATION:
During periods of emergency water shortages, all municipal departments will be
enjoined to restrict activities calling for heavy water consumption. Included
in this category are the testing and cleaning of fire hydrants, the cleaning of
water mains, the conduct of fire drills, street washing, sewer flushing and the
watering of public areas. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-9-6: FURTHER RESTRICTIONS:
During periods of emergency water shortages, the city council may by resolution
impose such further water use restrictions as may be deemed appropriate in
light of the circumstances then prevailing. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
9-9-7: VARIANCES:
Variances from the regulatory standards of this chapter may be granted in
accordance with the requirements noted below. No variance shall be granted
unless the applicant for the variance can demonstrate that:
   A.   An exceptional economic or other hardship would result without the
variance; and
   B.   The relief granted is the minimum necessary; and
   C.   There will be no additional threat to public health, welfare or safety
or the creation of a nuisance; and
   D.   No additional public expense will result. (Ord. 390, 9-11-1989)
CHAPTER 10
CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
SECTION:
9-10-1: Definitions
9-10-2: Water System
9-10-3: Cross Connection Control
9-10-4: Violation
9-10-5: System Surveys
9-10-6: Premises Inspections
9-10-7: Disconnection
9-10-8: Cleanup Costs
9-10-9: Cross Connection Prohibited
9-10-10: Survey And Investigations
9-10-11: Where Protection Is Required
9-10-12: Type Of Protection Required
9-10-13: Backflow Prevention Devices
9-10-14: Inspection And Maintenance
9-10-15: Booster Pumps
9-10-16: Violations And Penalties
9-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this chapter:
AGENCY: Illinois environmental protection agency.
APPROVED: Backflow prevention devices or methods approved by the Research
Foundation for Cross Connection Control of the University of Southern
California, Association of State Sanitary Engineers, American Water Works
Association, American National Standards Institute or certified by the National
Sanitation Foundation.
AUXILIARY WATER SYSTEM: Any water source or system on or available to a
premises other than the public water supply system and includes the water
supplied by the system. These auxiliary waters may include water from another
purveyor's public water supply system; or water from a source such as wells,
lakes, or streams, or process fluids; or used water.
BACKFLOW: The flow of water, other liquids, mixtures, or substances into the
distribution pipes of a potable water system from any source other than the
intended source of the potable water supply.
BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: Any device, method, or type of construction
intended to prevent backflow into a potable water system. All devices used for
backflow prevention in the city must meet the standards of the Illinois
plumbing code, the Illinois environmental protection agency and this code.
CITY: The city of Marquette Heights, Illinois.
CONSUMER OR CUSTOMER: The owner, official custodian or person in control of any
premises supplied by, or in any manner connected to, a public water system.
CONSUMER'S WATER SYSTEM: Any water system located on the customer's premises. A
building plumbing system is considered to be a consumer's water system.
CONTAMINATION: An impairment of the quality of the water by entrance of any
substance to a degree which could create a health hazard.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any physical connection or arrangement between two (2)
otherwise separate piping systems, one of which contains potable water and the
other a substance of unknown or questionable safety or quality, whereby there
may be a flow from one system into the other.
DIRECT CROSS CONNECTION: A cross connection formed when a water system is
physically joined to any source of water, or other fluids or substances, other
than the city's public water supply.
DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY: An assembly composed of single independently
acting check valves approved under ASSE standard 1015. A double check valve
assembly must include tight shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly
and suitable connections for testing the watertightness of each check valve.
FIXED PROPER AIR GAP: The unobstructed vertical distance through the free
atmosphere between the water discharge point and the flood level rim of the
receptacle.
HEALTH HAZARD: Any condition, device or practice in a water system or its
operation resulting from a real or potential danger to the health and well
being of consumers. The word "severe" as used to qualify "health hazard" means
a hazard to the health of the user that could be expected to result in death or
significant reduction in the quality of life.
INDIRECT CROSS CONNECTION: A cross connection through which an unknown
substance can be forced, drawn by vacuum or otherwise introduced into a safe
potable water system.
INSPECTION: A plumbing inspection to examine carefully and critically all
materials, fixtures, piping and appurtenances, appliances and installations of
a plumbing system for compliance with requirements of the Illinois plumbing
code, 77 Illinois administrative code 890, as same now exists or may hereafter
be amended.
NONPOTABLE WATER: Water not safe for drinking, personal, or culinary use as
determined by the requirements of 35 Illinois administrative code 604, as same
now exists or may hereafter be amended.
PLUMBING: The actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or extension
of a plumbing system by any person. Plumbing includes all piping, fixtures,
appurtenances and appliances for a supply of water for all purposes, including,
without limitation, lawn sprinkler systems, from the source of a private water
supply on the premises or from the main in the street, alley or at the curb to,
within and about any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work
or assemble. Plumbing includes all piping from discharge of pumping units to
and including pressure tanks in water supply systems. Plumbing includes all
piping, fixtures, appurtenances, and appliances for a building drain and a
sanitary drainage and aerated ventilation system of any building or buildings
where a person or persons live, work or assemble from the point of connection
of such building drain to the building sewer or private sewage disposal system
five feet (5') beyond the foundation walls.
POLLUTION: The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic,
radiological, or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as
to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water as potable water.
POTABLE WATER: Water which meets the requirements of 35 Illinois administrative
code 604, as same as now exists or may hereafter be amended, for drinking,
culinary, and domestic purposes.
POTENTIAL CROSS CONNECTION: A fixture or appurtenance with threaded hose
connection, tapered spout, or other connection which would facilitate extension
of a water supply line beyond its legal or intended termination point.
PROCESS FLUID(S): Any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically
or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would
constitute a health, pollution, or system hazard if introduced into the public
or a consumer's potable water system. This includes, but is not limited to:
   A.   Polluted or contaminated waters;
   B.   Process waters;
   C.   Used waters originating from the public water supply system which may
have deteriorated in sanitary quality;
   D.   Cooling waters;
   E.   Questionable or contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes,
streams, or irrigation systems;
   F.   Chemicals in solution or suspension;
   G.   Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids used in
industrial or other processes, or for firefighting purposes.
PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY: All mains, pipes and structures through which water is
obtained and distributed to the public, including wells and well structures,
intakes and cribs, pumping stations, treatment plants, reservoirs, storage
tanks and appurtenances, collectively or severally, actually used or intended
for use for the purpose of furnishing water for drinking or general domestic
and which is or are owned, operated and maintained by the city.
REDUCED PRESSURE PRINCIPLE BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: A device containing a
minimum of two (2) independently acting check valves together with an
automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located between the
two (2) check valves and approved under ASSE standard 1013. During normal flow
and at the cessation of normal flow, the pressure between these two (2) checks
shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either check
valve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall
operate to maintain the pressure between the check valves at less than the
supply pressure. The unit must include tightly closing shutoff valves located
at each end of the device, and each device shall be fitted with properly
located test cocks.
SERVICE CONNECTION: The opening, including all fittings and appurtenances, at
the water main through which water is supplied to the user.
SUPERINTENDENT: The duly designated superintendent of the water and sewer
department of the city of Marquette Heights, Illinois.
SURVEY: The collection of information pertaining to a customer's piping system
regarding the location of all connections to the public water supply system and
must include the location, type and most recent inspection and testing date of
all cross connection control devices and methods located within that customer's
piping system. The survey must be in written form, and should not be an annual
plumbing inspection.
SYSTEM HAZARD: A condition through which an aesthetically objectionable or
degrading material not dangerous to health may enter the public water supply
system or a consumer's potable water system.
WATER PURVEYOR: The city of Marquette Heights municipal water system. (Ord.
439, 12-28-1992)
9-10-2: WATER SYSTEM:
   A.   The water system shall be considered as made up of two (2) parts: the
public water supply system and the consumer's water system.
   B.   The public water supply system shall consist of the source facilities
and the distribution system, and shall include all those facilities of the
potable water system under the control of the water purveyor up to the point
where the consumer's water system begins.
   C.   The source shall include all components of the facilities utilized in
the production, treatment, storage, and delivery of water to the public water
supply distribution system.
   D.   The public water supply distribution system shall include the network
of conduits used to deliver water from the source to the consumer's water
supply distribution system.
   E.   The consumer's water system shall include all parts of the facilities
beyond the service connection used to convey water from the public water supply
distribution system to points of use. (Ord. 439, 12-28-1992)
9-10-3: CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL:
All plumbing installed within the city of Marquette Heights and all plumbing
installed in or at premises serviced by the public water supply, shall be
installed in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code, 77 Illinois
administrative code 890, as same now exists or may hereafter be amended. That,
if in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code or in the judgment of the
superintendent of water, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary
for the safety of the public water supply system, the superintendent of water
will give notice to the water customer to install such an approved device
immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense, install such an
approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois
plumbing code, Illinois environmental protection agency and all applicable
local ordinances and regulations, and shall have inspections and tests made of
such approved devices upon installation and as required by the Illinois
plumbing code, Illinois environmental protection agency and local ordinances
and regulations. (Ord. 439, 12-28-1992)
9-10-4: VIOLATION:
No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be established or
maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary
or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the
city may enter the supply or distribution system of the city, unless such
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and
use of such supply shall have been approved by the superintendent and the
Illinois environmental protection agency. (Ord. 439, 12-28-1992)
9-10-5: SYSTEM SURVEYS:
It shall be the duty of the superintendent of water to cause surveys and
investigations to be made of commercial industrial properties served by the
public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the
public water supply exist. The superintendent may survey such other properties
whereat he may have reason to believe a hazard to the public water supply
exists. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of public record
and shall be in compliance with IL Pollution Control Board requirement on both
occurrence of Survey Completion and Records Keeping of such per section of IL
Pollution Control Board Regulation Code Title 35 Sec. 604.1505. (Ord. 439, 12-
28-1992; amd. Ord. 928, 7-11-2022)
9-10-6: PREMISES INSPECTIONS:
The approved cross connection control device inspector (who shall be the
superintendent) shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any
property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution
system of the city for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of
cross connections, and that the superintendent, or his authorized agent shall
have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a
connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the city for
the purpose of verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the
required cross connection control inspection. Upon request, the owner, lessees
or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the superintendent any
information which he may request regarding the piping system or systems or
water use on such property. The refusal of such information, when requested,
shall, within the discretion of the superintendent, be deemed evidence of the
presence of improper connections as provided in this code. (Ord. 439, 12-28-
1992)
9-10-7: DISCONNECTION:
   A.   The superintendent is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue,
after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service to any
property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this code is
known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as he may deem
necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply
distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored until
such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the
provisions of this chapter, and until a reconnection fee of one hundred dollars
($100.00) is paid to the city. Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can
be effected when the superintendent reasonably believes that imminent danger of
harmful contamination of the public water supply system exists.
   B.   Such action shall be followed by written notification of the cause of
disconnection. Immediate disconnection without notice to any party can be
