10-4-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to promote harmonious
relationships in the interaction between man and animal by:
      1.   Protecting animals from improper use, abuse, neglect, exploitation,
inhumane treatment and health hazards;
      2.   Delineating the animal owner's or harborer's responsibility for the
acts and behavior of his animal at all times;
      3.   Providing security to residents from annoyance, intimidation, injury
and health hazards by animals;
      4.   Encouraging responsible pet ownership; and
      5.   Providing standards for any and all persons and agencies, public or
private, engaged in confinement, buying, selling, harboring, or dealing in
animals in any manner whatsoever. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-1-1: CRUELTY:
No person shall cruelly treat any animal in the city in any way. Any person who
inhumanely beats, underfeeds, overloads or abandons any animal shall be deemed
guilty of a violation of this section. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-1-2: DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful to permit any dangerous or vicious animal of any kind to
run at large within the city; exhibitions or parades of animals which are ferae
naturae in the eyes of the law may be conducted only upon securing a permit
from the chief of police. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-1-3: STRAYS:
It shall be unlawful to permit any cattle, sheep, horses, swine, goats or
poultry to run at large in the city. Any such animal running at large in any
public place in the city shall be impounded in the manner provided in section
10-4-4 of this chapter. It shall further be unlawful to picket or tie any such
animal in any of the streets, parks or any public place in the city for the
purposes of grazing or feeding. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-1-4: KILLING DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
The members of the police department are authorized to kill any dangerous
animal of any kind when it is necessary for the protection of any person or
property. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-1-5: HOUSING:
No person shall cause or allow any stable, place or premises where any animal
is or may be kept to become unclean or unwholesome, and it shall be unlawful to
keep any live swine, horses, cattle, goats or fowl, except chickens, anywhere
in the city, except in those areas of the city zoned agricultural. (Ord. 328,
1-13-1986; amd. Ord. 910, 7-13-2020)
10-4-1-6: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
ANIMAL: Any mammal, domestic or wild, other than man, which may be affected by
rabies.
ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER: That person educated in the seizure, custody and
confinement of animals, or his agent, as appointed by the city council.
ANIMAL NUISANCE: Created when an animal:
   A.   Runs uncontrolled on any property in the city, other than of the owner
or harborer;
   B.   Molests or disturbs persons or vehicles by chasing, barking or biting;
   C.   Attacks other animals;
   D.   Damages property other than that of the owner or harborer;
   E.   Barks, meows, whines, howls, honks, brays, cries or makes other noises
excessively;
   F.   Creates noxious or offensive odors;
   G.   Defecates upon any public place or upon premises not owned or
controlled by the owner or harborer unless promptly removed by the animal owner
or harborer.
AT LARGE: An animal shall be deemed to be at large when he is off the property
of his owner and not under the control of a responsible person.
CAT: Whenever used in this section this term shall include a female as well as
a male cat, four (4) months or more of age.
DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE: The department of agriculture of the state of
Illinois.
DOG: Whenever used in this section this term shall include a female as well as
a male dog, four (4) months or more of age.
INOCULATION AGAINST RABIES: The injection subcutaneously or otherwise, as
approved by the department of agriculture of the state of Illinois, of canine
and antirabic vaccine for dogs and of feline and antirabic vaccine for cats.
OWNER: A person having a right of property in an animal or who keeps or harbors
an animal or who has an animal in his care or who acts as its custodian, or who
knowingly permits an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him.
RESTRAINT: An animal is under restraint within the meaning of this section if
he is controlled by a leash, at "heel" beside a responsible person or obedient
to that person's command, within a vehicle being driven or parked on the
street, or within the property limits of his owner or keeper. (Ord. 328, 1-13-
1986)
10-4-1-7: ANIMAL NUISANCE:
It shall be unlawful for the owner, keeper or harborer of any dog, cat or other
animal to allow or permit said dog, cat or other animal, to become to be or
create an animal nuisance in the city. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-1-8: DEAD ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or cause to be left unburied at
any place within the city, any dead dog, cat or other animal or fowl. (Ord.
436, 11-23-1992)
10-4-2: DOGS:
10-4-2-1: INOCULATION OF DOGS:
   A.   Each calendar year, or at such intervals as may hereafter be
promulgated by the department of agriculture of the state of Illinois, every
owner, keeper or harborer of a dog, four (4) months or more of age shall cause
such dog to be inoculated against rabies.
   B.   The inoculation of dogs required by this section shall be performed by
a veterinarian duly licensed to practice his profession in this state. Upon
performing such inoculation, such veterinarian shall issue to the owner,
keeper, or harborer a certificate showing such fact. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-2-2: DURATION OF INOCULATION:
The inoculation performed under the provisions of section
10-4-2-1 of this chapter shall be effective until the expiration of the
calendar year in which the vaccination was performed or the expiration of such
period of time as may be promulgated by the department of agriculture of the
state of Illinois. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-2-3: EXHIBITION OF CERTIFICATE ON REQUEST:
At any reasonable time upon request of any member of the police department or
an animal control officer, the owner, keeper or harborer of any dog shall
exhibit his certificate, issued under the provisions of section
10-4-2-1 of this chapter, showing the inoculation against rabies of any dog
owned or controlled by him. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-2-4: RESTRAINT OF DOGS:
The owner, keeper or harborer of a dog shall keep the dog under restraint at
all times and shall not permit such dog to be at large, off the premises of the
property of the owner or keeper, unless the dog is under "restraint" as defined
in section
10-4-1-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-2-5: DOG REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to own, keep or harbor any dog within the city without
first registering each such dog with the Tazewell County animal control
administrator, in the manner provided in the appropriate ordinance or
regulation of Tazewell County, Illinois. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-2-6: TAG AFFIXED TO COLLAR:
   A.   The proper registration tag issued under the provisions of section
10-4-2-5 of this chapter shall be securely fastened to a collar or harness made
of leather, metal or other substantial material which said owner, keeper or
harborer shall require dog to wear at all times.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to permit any dog to be on any public street,
sidewalk, alley, park or other public place unless such dog is under restraint
and has a collar or harness firmly attached around its neck with a current
county registration tag attached to such collar. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-2-7: DISPOSITION OF DOGS DEEMED NUISANCE:
Any dog which is, becomes or creates an "animal nuisance", as defined in
section
10-4-1-6 of this chapter, may be taken up and impounded and may be redeemed or
disposed of in the manner provided in section
10-4-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-2-8: CONFINEMENT OF FEMALE DOGS IN HEAT:
The owner, keeper or harborer of any female dog in heat, shall keep said dog
confined in a building or other secure enclosure. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-2-9: DOG BITES:
It shall be the duty of the owner or person having custody of any dog which
bites any human being, to keep such dog confined for a period of ten (10) days
following the time the dog has bitten a person. Dogs which have not been
inoculated for rabies shall be impounded by a licensed veterinarian and shall
be examined by a licensed veterinarian at the commencement and termination of
the ten (10) day period. If such dog, during this period, shall die or show
definite signs of illness, it shall be the duty of such owner or person having
custody of the dog to turn the dog over to the city officer on duty or animal
control officer, so that it can be determined whether or not the dog has
rabies. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-3: CATS:
10-4-3-1: INOCULATION OF CATS:
   A.   Each calendar year, or at such intervals as may hereafter be
promulgated by the department of agriculture of the state of Illinois, every
owner, keeper or harborer of a cat, four (4) months or more of age shall cause
such cat to be inoculated against rabies.
   B.   The inoculation of cats required by this section hereof shall be
performed by a veterinarian duly licensed to practice his profession in this
state. Upon performing such inoculation, such veterinarian shall issue to the
owner, keeper or harborer a certificate showing such fact. (Ord. 328, 1-13-
1986)
10-4-3-2: DURATION OF INOCULATION:
The inoculation performed under the provisions of section
10-4-3-1 of this chapter shall be effective until the expiration of the
calendar year in which the vaccination was performed or the expiration of such
period of time as may be promulgated by the department of agriculture of the
state of Illinois. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-3-3: EXHIBITION OF CERTIFICATE ON REQUEST:
At any reasonable time upon request of any member of the police department or
animal control officer, the owner, keeper or harborer of any cat shall exhibit
his certificate, issued under the provisions of section
10-4-3-1 of this chapter, showing the inoculation against rabies of any cat
owned or controlled by him. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-3-4: RESTRAINT OF CATS:
The owner or keeper of a cat shall keep the cat under restraint at all times
and shall not permit such cat to be at large, off the premises of the property
of the owner or keeper, unless the cat is under "restraint" as defined in
section
10-4-1-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-3-5: CAT REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to own, keep or harbor any cat within the city without
first registering each such cat with the Tazewell County animal control
administrator. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-3-6: TAG AFFIXED TO COLLAR:
   A.   A current name and address of owner tag shall be securely fastened to a
collar or harness made of leather, metal or other substantial material which
said owner, keeper or harborer shall require the cat to wear at all times.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to permit any cat to be on any public street,
sidewalk, alley, park or other public place unless such cat is under restraint
and has a collar or harness firmly attached around its neck with a current name
and address of owner tag attached to such collar. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-3-7: DISPOSITION OF CATS DEEMED NUISANCES:
Any cat which may in any manner continually disturb the quiet of any persons or
neighborhoods or shall destroy or in any manner injure any animal, plant, shrub
or other property not on the premises of its owner or keeper is hereby declared
to be a nuisance and such cat shall be taken up and impounded and may be
redeemed or disposed of in the manner provided for under section
10-4-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-3-8: CONFINEMENT OF FEMALE CAT IN HEAT:
The owner, keeper or harborer of any female cat in heat shall keep said cat
confined in a building or other secure enclosure. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-3-9: CAT BITES:
It shall be the duty of the owner or person having custody of any cat which
bites any human being to keep such cat confined for a period of ten (10) days
following the time the cat has bitten a person. Cats which have not been
inoculated for rabies shall be impounded by a licensed veterinarian and shall
be examined by a licensed veterinarian at the commencement and termination of
the ten (10) day period. If such cat, during this period, shall die or show
definite signs of illness, it shall be the duty of such owner or person having
custody of the cat to turn the cat over to the city officer on duty, or animal
control officer, so that it can be determined whether or not the cat has
rabies. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-3-10: RUNNING AT LARGE:
It shall be unlawful to permit any cat to run at large within the municipality.
Any cat found upon any public street, sidewalk, alley, park or other public
place shall be deemed running at large unless such cat is restrained as defined
in section
10-4-1-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-4: IMPOUNDMENT:
10-4-4-1: IMPOUNDMENT, CITATION:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the employees and officers of the police
department or other authorized personnel to take up and impound, in such place
as may be designated and set apart for that purpose, any animal found running
at large or unlicensed in the city, contrary to any provisions of this chapter
or other ordinances of the city.
   B.   When animals are found running at large or unlicensed and their
ownership is known to the designated employees, officers or other authorized
personnel, such animals may be impounded at the discretion of the employees,
officers or authorized person, but a citation to the owner of such animal shall
be issued to answer the charges of violating the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-4-2: NOTICE:
In case of impounding and where the owner, keeper or harborer of such animal is
disclosed by any license or name tag worn by it, or is otherwise known to the
officer or person impounding same, the police department shall at once give
notice by mail to such owner, keeper or harborer, informing him of the
impounding of his animal and shall cite the owner, keeper or harborer of such
animal to answer charges of violation of this chapter. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-4-3: REDEMPTION:
When tagged, any animal impounded under the provisions of this chapter, except
such as may have bitten any person, as specified in section
10-4-4-4 of this chapter shall, unless sooner redeemed, be held for the
specified time after notice has been given pursuant to Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/10, in order to afford opportunity to the owner, keeper or harborer
thereof to redeem the same. Any such owner, keeper or harborer desiring to
redeem his impounded animal shall pay to the city, collectable by either the
city clerk or the Tazewell County animal control administrator, in addition to
the costs of keeping such animal while impounded, an impounding fee, as
follows:
   A.   Fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first time an animal is so impounded;
   B.   Seventy five dollars ($75.00) for the second time an animal is so
impounded;
   C.   One hundred dollars ($100.00) for the third and each subsequent time
thereafter an animal is so impounded.
In addition, in those cases where the animal impounded is required to be
licensed and/or inoculated against rabies, the owner of such animal must
display proof that such animal is properly licensed and/or inoculated. In the
absence of such proof, no such animal shall be released from the shelter until
the proper license and inoculation have been obtained and the costs thereof
paid.
Any tagged animal which has been impounded and not redeemed with the statutory
requirements shall be humanely destroyed or otherwise disposed of by the
poundkeeper.
Any untagged animal shall be kept four (4) working days and if not redeemed
shall be humanely destroyed or otherwise disposed of by the poundkeeper. (Ord.
413, 1-14-1990; amd. Ord. 942, 12-11-2023)
10-4-4-4: IMPOUNDMENT OF ANIMALS BITING PERSONS:
   A.   Any animal which shall have bitten or otherwise injured any person so
as to cause an abrasion of the skin shall be immediately impounded and kept
separated from other animals for ten (10) days. If during that period such
animal develops symptoms of illness, a veterinarian shall be called to diagnose
its condition. If the symptoms disclosed are such as to indicate the presence
of rabies, such animal shall be destroyed in such a manner as to preserve,
intact, the head, which shall thereupon be detached and immediately sent to the
diagnostic laboratory of the department of agriculture of the state of
Illinois. In case such animal cannot be safely taken up and impounded, it may
be shot, care being taken to preserve the head, intact, which thereupon shall
be immediately detached and be delivered to the diagnostic laboratory of the
department of agriculture of the state of Illinois.
   B.   After having been notified that his animal has bitten or otherwise
injured any person, the owner, keeper or harborer shall not, under any
circumstances, allow or permit such animal, while under "restraint" as defined
in section
10-4-1-6 of this chapter to be on any public street, sidewalk, alley, park or
other public place unless such animal is securely muzzled.
   C.   If, at the expiration of the period of ten (10) days, no symptoms of
rabies have been developed in such animal so impounded, the same may be
redeemed by the owner upon payment of the redemption fees and charges specified
in this code. (Ord. 328, 1-13-1986)
10-4-4-5: ANIMAL NUISANCE PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of permitting an "animal nuisance" to exist as defined
in section
10-4-1-6 and/or
10-4-2-7 of this chapter shall be fined:
   A.   Not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for the first offense.
   B.   Not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for the second offense, within a consecutive twelve (12)
month period.
   C.   Not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for the third or subsequent offense, within a consecutive
twelve (12) month period. (Ord. 436, 11-23-1992)
10-4-5: CHICKENS; KEEPING OF HENS AND OUTDOOR HEN SHELTERS ON RESIDENTIAL LOTS:
10-4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
Definitions: The following items are defined as follows:
 
COOP: A structure housing hens consisting of a covered inside enclosure.
HENS: The female of the species chicken.
      An enclosure connected to a coop for the purpose of allowing hens to
RUN:  leave the coop while remaining in an enclosed, predator safe environment.
      (Ord. 910, 7-13- 2021)
 
10-4-5-2: LICENSE AND PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall keep hens within the City without first obtaining a
license issued by the City (Chicken License). The licenses will be limited to
ten (10). Chicken licenses shall be issued on a first come, first serve basis
and no more than one licenses shall be allowed per residential lot. If the City
receives valid chicken applications that exceed the maximum number available
licenses, all exceeding applications will be placed on a waiting list in the
order they were received, waiting list will be maintained by the Mayor's
designee. Chicken licenses are valid for one calendar year (January to
December). An annual license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) will be
required prior to the City's issuance of the chicken license and the
applicant's purchasing of the hens. A building inspection and the City's
approval of the construction and installation of any run, coop or other
enclosure used for housing of hens is required prior to obtaining a chicken
license. A chicken license for keeping hens shall not be transferable.
   B.   Building permit required. Any coop, run and other enclosure used for
housing hens may be erected only after obtaining a building permit.
   C.   Renewal License. A renewal chicken license will be required each year
after the issuance of the initial chicken license, with no additional building
inspection required unless complaint driven. An administrative fee of twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) will be required for each renewal license. (Ord. 910, 7-
13-2021)
10-4-5-3: LICENSE AND PERMIT APPLICATION PROCESS:
   A.   A completed application form provided by the City.
   B.   A completed building permit application, including a plat of survey
accurately depicting the potential location of a coop, run or other enclosure
used for the housing of hens on the applicant's property.
   C.   The required license fee for a license to keep hens in the amount of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and the required building permit fee, if any, for
the coop, run and/or enclosure used for the hens. The building permit fee for a
coop, run and/or other enclosure used for housing hens shall be the same fee as
a shed fifty dollars ($50.00).
   D.   Once the construction and installation of the coop, run and/or other
enclosure is complete, the City will inspect the site for construction and
installation approval.
   E.   After the applicant has complied with and completed items A. - D.
within the timeframes determined by the (Department of Public Works and/or
Building Inspector) the City will issue the applicant the chicken license. Only
after the chicken license has been issued by the City may the licensee obtain
hens for location on the licensed premises.
   F.   A license for keeping hens shall be granted on an annual basis. The
renewal license application requires the completion of an updated license
application and submission of the administrative fee.
   G.   Chicken licenses may be obtained for coops located only on homeowners
occupied property. (Ord. 910, 7-13-2021)
10-4-5-4: REGULATIONS FOR THE KEEPING OF HENS AND HEN SHELTER:
   A.   The following regulations shall apply to any person licensed to keep
hens and to maintain any outdoor hen shelter on a residential lot within the
City:
      1.   The keeping or harboring of any rooster and crowing hens are
prohibited
      2.   No person shall keep or harbor more than six (6) hens on any
licensed premise.
      3.   Hens are not to be maintained for financial gain or for any business
purpose, but raised for egg consumption only.
      4.   Hens shall not be permitted to run at-large in the City. Hens must
be kept within a coop with an attached run to protect the hens from predators
and to prevent hens from encroaching onto neighboring properties.
      5.   The slaughtering of hens on any residential lot is prohibited
   B.   The following regulations shall apply to all hen shelters maintained in
the City.
      1.   A coop or other covered enclosure shall be provided for housing
hens. The coops are required to have at least four (4) square feet of coop
floor space per chicken. Enclosures must have at least eight (8) square feet of
outdoor run space per chicken .
      2.   A coop, run or other structure used for housing hens shall be
located a minimum of ten (10) feet from any lot lines of the licensee's
property, and shall not be located within ten (10) feet of licensee's residence
and shall not be within twenty-five (25) feet from any neighboring residence.
      3.   All hens and coop, runs and other structures are prohibited in any
front yard or street-facing yards.
      4.   Coops or other covered enclosures for housing hens shall be
constructed of durable building materials. The enclosure shall be constructed
to a minimum height of five (5) feet. No heat lamps shall be permitted in any
coop or other structure used for housing hens.
      5.   Access door(s) to any coop must be latched and secured with chickens
inside during the hours between nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M.
      6.   Electric service to enclosures shall not be provided by an extension
cord.
      7.   All area where hens are kept shall be clean and well-maintained with
little to no accumulation of waste. All properties where hens are kept shall
not produce or cause odors that are detectable on adjacent properties. Any
odors shall be declared a nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any licensee to
allow such nuisance to exist beyond the boundaries of the licensed property.
      8.   Deceased chickens shall be properly disposed of.
      9.   All hen feed shall be kept in rodent proof containers until utilized
for consumption by the permitted hens.
      10.   No licensee shall allow hens to make noise loud enough to annoy or
disturb the comfort, health, peace or repose of reasonable persons of ordinary
sensibilities and it is hereby declared a nuisance and it shall be unlawful for
any licensee to allow such nuisance to exist. (Ord. 910, 7-13-2021)
10-4-5-5: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION AND NONRENEWAL OF LICENSES:
   A.   Whenever a licensee violates or fails to act in conformity with the
provisions of this ordinance, any license for keeping hens may be suspended or
revoked, or the City may refuse to renew the license, following notice and a
hearing before the City (Council or Mayor or Building Inspector)
   B.   If a license is revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to
the same licensee for keeping hens for a period of one year from the date of
the revocation. (Ord. 910, 7-13-2021)
10-4-5-6: SUMMARY SUSPENSION:
Upon the presence of sufficient evidence demonstrating probable cause to
believe that the licensee has violated provisions of this ordinance or has
violated State or Federal law, and that said violation possess an immediate
threat to the public health, safety or welfare, the City may, upon the issuance
of a written order stating the reason for such conclusion, and without prior
notice or hearing, order the licensed structure for the keeping of hens closed
and the license issued pursuant to this ordinance to be summarily suspended,
pending a hearing and a determination regarding suspension or revocation. The
licensee shall be provided a copy of the order and a notice of violation. A
hearing shall be commenced not more than ten (10) days following the entry of
such order, unless the licensee shall agree to a longer period of time. (Ord.
910, 7-13-2021)
10-4-5-7: INJUNCTION:
Any violation of Sections
10-4-5-1 through
10-4-5-8 is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. Upon request
by the City, an action by the City Attorney for injunctive relief may be
commenced for the abatement and removal thereof in the manner provided by law.
(Ord. 910, 7-13-2021)
10-4-5-8: REMOVAL OF STRUCTURES:
Runs, coops and other enclosures used for the housing of hens shall be removed
within thirty (30) days of a licensee no longer keeping hens, upon licensee no
longer occupying the property for which a license for keeping hens was issued,
or upon a license for keeping of hens having expired or been revoked. All hens
shall be removed within five (5) days of a final determination regarding the
suspension or revocation of license. (Ord. 910, 7-13-2021)
CHAPTER 5
MULTIPLE PETS
SECTION:
10-5-1: Definitions
10-5-2: License Required
10-5-3: Regulations
10-5-4: Inspection And Enforcement
10-5-5: Compliance
10-5-6: Penalties
10-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter the following words shall have the following
meanings unless the context clearly requires otherwise:
ANIMAL RUN: Any confined area without a roof not a regular part of any other
structure on the same premises (but which may be attached thereto), designed,
maintained or used for the confinement of dogs, cats or other domesticated pets
or animals.
MULTIPLE PET OWNER: Any person or persons who individually or in association
with any other person or persons, for any reason, harbors more than four (4)
dogs or four (4) cats or any combination thereof over the age of four (4)
months within or upon any dwelling unit, structure, single lot or other parcel
of property or within the curtilage of any dwelling or structure.
MULTIPLE PET PREMISES: Any dwelling unit, structure, single lot or other parcel
of property or the curtilage of any dwelling unit or structure wherein or
whereon more than four (4) dogs or four (4) cats or any combination thereof
over the age of four (4) months are kept or harbored. (Ord. 527, 3-9-1998)
10-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   Multiple pet owners shall obtain an annual license from the office of
the city clerk upon payment of a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00), plus ten
dollars ($10.00) for each animal over five (5). Such license shall be obtained
no later than thirty (30) days after assuming ownership of a fifth animal and
must be renewed annually by January 1. The annual renewal fee shall be ten
dollars ($10.00), plus ten dollars ($10.00) for each animal over five (5), if
the owner receives an inspection rating of excellent. Payment by a multiple pet
owner shall not exempt such licensee from payment of county registration fees
for each dog or cat owned by him. (Ord. 629, 4-8-2002)
   B.   Each application for a multiple pet license shall identify the owner or
owners of the animals in question, the number of animals (cats and dogs) owned
or kept by the applicant and any other owner thereof, and the premises wherein
or whereon such animals will be kept. Each applicant shall be given a copy of
the ordinance codified herein and each application shall include a statement to
the effect that the applicant agrees to abide by each of the regulations set
forth in section
10-5-3 of this chapter. Each application shall be signed by the applicant
before a license is issued. (Ord. 527, 3-9-1998)
10-5-3: REGULATIONS:
All multiple pet owners shall at all times abide by the following regulations
with respect to the care and keeping of such animals:
   A.   An applicant for a multiple pet license shall consent to the inspection
of the premises where his animals are kept or maintained. Such inspection shall
be performed before issuance of the license or upon receipt of a complaint.
Annual inspections may be required for multiple pet owners with marginally
acceptable standards. Such inspection may be performed by the animal shelter
director, designee or police department personnel. Failure to comply with a
request for inspection is a violation of this chapter. Holders of multiple pet
owner licenses shall conform to the following requirements:
      1.   All dogs and/or cats over four (4) months of age must be inoculated
against rabies and registered pursuant to this chapter.
      2.   All dogs and/or cats must be provided with a continuous supply of
fresh water, sufficient food to maintain acceptable body weight, proper
shelter, protection from weather and sufficient veterinary care to prevent
suffering.
      3.   If dogs and/or cats are kept or maintained within a structure or
building, such building shall:
         a.   Meet county and city health standards.
         b.   Be kept clean, free of feces, and urine.
         c.   Not constitute a nuisance or danger to the health and welfare of
its inhabitants nor surrounding residents.
      4.   If the dogs and/or cats are maintained outside a building during a
substantial portion of the day and/or night:
         a.   A shelter of sufficient height and width to permit such animal to
stand up and turn around inside when fully grown shall be provided.
         b.   The shelter provided shall provide shade from the sun.
         c.   No animal run shall be allowed in front or side yards of any lot
or other parcel of land and the perimeter of the fences shall be no closer than
five feet (5') from the property line of adjoining properties. Said animal runs
shall have an area of not more than one hundred (100) square feet and shall be
not more than six feet (6') in height.
      5.   The dogs and/or cats shall be prevented from running at large.
      6.   The dogs and/or cats shall be prevented from causing a nuisance
pursuant to section
10-4-1-6 and/or
10-4-2-7 of this title.
      7.   The owner's property shall be kept free of all feces and urine to
prevent its accumulation from constituting a health hazard or an odorous
nuisance.
   B.   No animal shall be permitted to stray or be taken anywhere outside any
building or structures on any multiple pet premises unless such animal is
restrained. Within any building, structure or animal run on any multiple pet
premises, animals shall be confined in such a manner as to protect one animal
from another and to protect persons lawfully upon such property from the danger
of biting, scratching or other injury from such animals.
   C.   All dogs in heat (estrus) shall be confined in a building or secure
enclosure and attended in such a manner that such female dog cannot come into
contact with a male of the same species except for planned breeding. (Ord. 527,
3-9-1998)
10-5-4: INSPECTION AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   By taking out a license as required in section
10-5-2 of this chapter, each such license holder consents to the inspection of
the premises where their animals are kept or maintained as stated in the
license. Such inspection shall be performed upon receipt of a complaint or upon
the existence of probable cause of a violation of this chapter, upon written
notice to the owner or occupant of the premises to be inspected, and such
inspection shall be conducted by the animal shelter director, designee or
police department personnel during reasonable hours. Failure to comply with a
request for inspection by police department personnel is a violation of this
chapter.
   B.   Failure to permit an inspection as provided in this section shall
result in the revocation of the license by the mayor upon report thereof to him
by the chief of police. Such license revocation shall take effect forty eight
(48) hours after the service of notice thereof upon licensee, unless the
licensee petitions for a hearing as provided in this section.
   C.   Upon receipt of a notice of revocation of license, the licensee or
licensees may file with the office of the city clerk, a written request for
hearing before the health and recreation committee of the city council. Such
hearing shall be conducted within fourteen (14) days after the receipt of the
request for hearing. Such hearing shall be conducted by the chairman of the
health and recreation committee in accordance with procedure generally followed
in administrative proceedings. In such hearing, the health and recreation
committee shall consider all competent and relevant evidence offered and
determine by a majority vote, supported by written findings of fact, whether or
not a violation of this chapter has occurred. Upon a finding that a violation
of this chapter has occurred, the health and recreation committee may order the
license revoked or may order such other remedial action as it deems appropriate
under the circumstances. All orders of the health and recreation committee
shall become final upon the issuance thereof. The health and recreation
committee shall have no authority to levy a fine or other monetary penalty.
No license revocation ordered by the mayor pursuant to subsection B of this
section shall be effective if the licensee or licensees file a timely petition
for a hearing pursuant to this subsection. The final action of the health and
recreation committee shall then be the determination of the matter.
   D.   Upon conviction of a second violation of the requirements pursuant to
this chapter, the animal shelter director, designee or police department
personnel shall revoke the multiple pet license for a period of not less than
three (3) months nor more than two (2) years, the length of such revocation
period to be determined by the number and severity of the violations. After
expiration of the revocation period, the license shall not automatically be
reinstated. The former licensee must reapply for the license and show an
ability to conform to the existing ordinances before he may be issued a
multiple pet license.
   E.   During the revocation period, the owner shall either relinquish
ownership of his animals to the animal shelter or place his animals in the care
of another person after that person's facility for such animals has been
inspected and approved by the animal shelter director, designee or police
department personnel.
   F.   The animal shelter director, designee or police department personnel
are further authorized to conduct such other investigations of violations of
this chapter and perform all necessary inspections in any reasonable manner as
may be permitted by law so as to ensure compliance with the provisions of this
chapter.
   G.   The animal shelter director, designee or police department personnel
may impound the dogs and cats of any multiple pet owner if such owner does not
hold a multiple pet license.
   H.   Such animals shall be redeemed by the owner upon payment to the animal
shelter director or designee the lawful fees accrued pursuant to this chapter
and after application and approval for a multiple pet owner license. (Ord. 527,
3-9-1998)
10-5-5: COMPLIANCE:
All multiple pet owners at the time of the passage of this chapter shall have
thirty (30) days from the date of passage to comply with the requirements of
this chapter. (Ord. 527, 3-9-1998)
10-5-6: PENALTIES:
   A.   Multiple pet ownership by a person or persons without obtaining a
license shall be a violation of this chapter for which, upon conviction
thereof, such person or persons shall be subject to a fine of not less than
fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
such offense.
   B.   Any person convicted of any other violation of this chapter shall be
subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00).
   C.   Each day a violation of this chapter is found to exist shall be deemed
to constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 527, 3-9-1998)
CHAPTER 6
VEHICLE, JUNK STORAGE
SECTION:
10-6-1: Junk And Vehicle Storage
10-6-1: JUNK AND VEHICLE STORAGE:
No person shall suffer or permit the storage or placing of junk; lumber;
building materials; machinery; salvage; wrecked, disabled or inoperable motor
vehicles 1  on private property in the residential area of the city.
For the purposes of this section, an "inoperable motor vehicle" shall be as
defined in section
11-1-2 of this code. (Ord. 253, 4-28-1980; amd. Ord. 325, 10-14-1985)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  11-3-10 of this code.
CHAPTER 7
DANGEROUS AND VICIOUS ANIMALS
SECTION:
10-7-1: Declaration Of Purpose
10-7-2: Legislative Intent
10-7-3: Definitions
10-7-4: Identification Of Vicious Or Dangerous Animals
10-7-5: Cruelty To Animals
10-7-6: Keeping Of Vicious Animals Prohibited And Standards
10-7-7: Keeping Of Dangerous Animals Prohibited And Standards
10-7-8: Duration And Renewal Of Vicious Animal License
10-7-9: Duration And Renewal Of Dangerous Animal License
10-7-10: Fighting Prohibited
10-7-11: Impoundment And Redemption
10-7-12: Revocation Of License
10-7-13: Exceptions
10-7-14: Penalties
10-7-15: Failure To Comply
10-7-16: Appeal
10-7-1: DECLARATION OF PURPOSE:
Findings of the city council set forth in the preamble of ordinance 371 are
incorporated herein as if fully set forth. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-2: LEGISLATIVE INTENT:
This chapter is adopted pursuant to the powers granted to municipalities in 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1-1, 5/11-5-6, and 5/11-20-9, as amended. (Ord.
680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter the following terms and phrases shall have the
meanings set forth below:
BITE: To seize or cut with the teeth.
CITY: The city of Marquette Heights, Illinois.
CONFINEMENT STRUCTURE: A securely locked pen, kennel or structure of at least
six feet (6') in height designed and constructed for the keeping of a vicious
animal and designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with the
standards set forth herein. Such pen, kennel or structure must have secure
sides and a secure top attached to the sides as well as be suitable to prevent
the entry of young children and exiting of the contained animal. All structures
used to confine vicious animals must be locked with a key or combination lock
when such animals are within the structure and left unattended. Such structure
must have a secure bottom or floor attached to the sides of the pen or the
sides of the pen must be embedded in the ground not less than two feet (2').
All structures must be adequately lighted, ventilated and kept in a clean and
sanitary condition.
CRUELTY TO ANIMALS: Shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, the
following:
   A.   Overloading, overdriving, overworking, beating, torturing, abusing,
tormenting, knowingly poisoning, knowingly attempting to poison, mutilating or
killing any domesticated animal, or causing or knowingly permitting the same to
be done.
   B.   Working any old, lame, infirm, sick or disabled animal, or causing or
knowingly permitting the same to be done.
   C.   Unnecessarily failing to provide a domestic animal in one's custody
with proper food, drink and proper sanitary shelter.
   D.   Abandoning any animal by leaving such animal on any highway or public
way or in any other place where it may suffer injury, hunger, exposure or
become a public charge.
DANGEROUS ANIMAL: A. Any individual domestic animal that, without provocation,
bites or causes the death of another domestic animal either on public property
or private property.
   B.   Any individual domestic animal which has a known propensity, tendency
or disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury, or to otherwise
endanger the safety of other domestic animals.
   C.   No animal shall be deemed "dangerous" if the animal bites, attacks or
menaces:
1. Another domestic animal on the property of its owner, or
2. Any domestic animal that is assaulting its owner, or
3. Any nondomestic animal, or
4. Is a K-9 patrol dog or a police dog.
DOG: Any and all animals of the canine family.
DOMESTIC ANIMAL: Any animal that lives, either by design or circumstance, under
the intentional care and feeding of people.
FIGHT: Prearranged conflict between two (2) or more animals but does not
include a conflict that is unintentional or accidental.
HEARING COMMITTEE: The hearing committee shall consist of the police committee
of the city council of the city of Marquette Heights. In the event that a
member of the police committee cannot serve and removes himself or herself; the
mayor shall appoint another member of the city council to serve on the hearing
committee for the duration of the removal.
K-9 PATROL DOG OR POLICE DOG: A professionally trained dog used by law
enforcement officers for law enforcement purposes and activities.
LEASH: A cord, chain, rope, strap, or other such physical restraint having a
tensile strength of not less than three hundred (300) pounds.
MUZZLE: A device constructed of strong, soft material or a metal muzzle. The
muzzle must be made in a manner which will not cause injury to the animal or
interfere with its vision or respiration, but must prevent it from biting any
person or animal.
NIP: To pinch or squeeze with teeth with no breaking of skin or tissue.
OWNER: Any person, persons, firm, corporation or other entity who keeps or
harbors a domestic animal or who acts as its custodian or who permits a
domestic animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by such person(s).
In the event that the owner, harborer, or keeper of any such animal is a minor,
the parent or guardian of such minor shall be responsible to ensure that all
provisions of this chapter are complied with and it shall be illegal for such
parent or guardian to fail to prohibit any violation of this chapter by a
minor.
PROVOCATION: Any act or conduct on the part of the animal or person who is the
subject of a bite or an attack which:
   A.   Immediately precedes the bite or attack; and
   B.   Is an act or conduct of such a nature as is likely to arouse or excite
a domestic animal of ordinary temperament into biting or attacking the animal
or person committing such act or conduct; and
   C.   Is directed towards the animal which has bitten or attacked.
RUNNING AT LARGE: Being off the premises of the owner and not under restraint
or not under physical control of the owner or an authorized person by leash.
Control known as command or voice control is not physical control when off the
premises or private property.
VICIOUS ANIMAL: A. Any individual domestic animal that, without provocation,
bites or attacks a human being either on public property or private property.
   B.   Any individual domestic animal which:
1. Has a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack without
provocation, to cause injury, or to otherwise endanger the safety of human
beings; or
2. Is owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of animal fighting
or is trained for animal fighting; or
3. Has demonstrated repeated aggressive behavior towards other domestic animals
that have resulted in the death or great bodily harm to those animals.
   C.   No animal shall be deemed "vicious" if the animal:
1. Bites, attacks or menaces a trespasser on the property of its owner, or
2. Bites, attacks or menaces anyone assaulting its owner, or
3. Bites, attacks or menaces anyone who has tormented or abused it, or
4. Is a K-9 patrol dog or a police dog. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-4: IDENTIFICATION OF VICIOUS OR DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
   A.   Any law enforcement officer or animal control officer employed by or
under contract with the city who suspects that a domestic animal may be vicious
or dangerous within the meaning of this chapter may conduct an investigation to
determine whether or not the animal has committed any act or displays any
characteristics which qualify it as either a vicious animal or a dangerous
animal. If upon the completion of such investigation the officer concludes that
the animal is a vicious animal or a dangerous animal, such officer shall issue
a written notice of determination which includes at least the following:
      1.   A description of the domestic animal;
      2.   Information available concerning the ownership of the domestic
animal;
      3.   A statement or conclusion that the domestic animal is a dangerous
animal or a vicious animal within the meaning of this chapter;
      4.   A description of the acts or characteristics which led the officer
to conclude that the domestic animal is a vicious animal or a dangerous animal;
      5.   Notice to the owner that the vicious animal or dangerous animal must
be licensed and housed in accordance with the requirements of this chapter;
      6.   Notice that the owner may appeal the determination of the officer to
the city clerk of the city of Marquette Heights within seven (7) working days
after the determination is served upon the owner.
The officer shall serve the notice of determination on the owner by certified
mail or hand deliver to the last known address of the owner.
   B.   The owner may appeal any determination that the owner's domestic animal
is a vicious or dangerous animal. An appeal must be directed to the mayor and
must be filed by the owner in the office of the city clerk within seven (7)
working days after receipt of the notice of determination which identifies the
domestic animal as a vicious animal or dangerous animal. Should the owner fail
to appeal the determination within seven (7) working days, the determination of
the investigating officer that the domestic animal is a vicious animal or a
dangerous animal shall become final. Upon receipt of an appeal, the hearing
committee shall convene a hearing for the purpose of determining whether the
animal in question is either a vicious animal or a dangerous animal.
   C.   The hearing shall be held within no less than five (5) nor more than
fourteen (14) working days after the hearing committee serves a notice of the
time, date and location of the hearing upon the owner of the allegedly vicious
or dangerous animal. At the hearing, the owner shall have the opportunity to
present evidence to explain why the animal should not be declared a vicious
animal or a dangerous animal. The owner shall have the right to be represented
by legal counsel at the owner's expense. The officer who made the initial
determination that the domestic animal is a vicious animal or a dangerous
animal, and any other persons having knowledge of the facts and circumstances,
may be heard by the hearing committee and shall be subject to cross examination
by the owner or the owner's attorney. The hearing committee shall decide all
issues for or against the owner of the domestic animal regardless of whether
the owner appears at the hearing.
   D.   The hearing committee may, after careful consideration of all evidence
presented, enter a finding that the animal is either vicious or dangerous based
on the facts regardless of the original determination by the officer.
   E.   Within five (5) working days after the conclusion of the hearing, the
hearing committee shall determine whether or not the domestic animal is a
vicious animal or a dangerous animal within the meaning of this chapter. The
hearing committee shall notify the owner in writing of its determination. The
decision of the hearing committee shall be final.
   F.   If any officer of the city determines that the public safety requires
the immediate impoundment of any animal as authorized by this chapter, the
officer shall within a reasonable time notify the owner of the facts and
circumstances relating to the impoundment. Upon receipt of such notification,
the owner may appeal the determination of the officer to the hearing committee
in accordance with the procedures established hereinabove for the
identification of vicious or dangerous animals. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-5: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any act constituting cruelty to
animals. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-6: KEEPING OF VICIOUS ANIMALS PROHIBITED AND STANDARDS:
It shall be unlawful to keep, harbor, own or in any way possess within the
corporate limits of the city any vicious animal, except and subject to the
standards and requirements herein set forth.
   A.   Sale Or Transfer Of Ownership Prohibited: No person shall sell, barter
or in any other way dispose of a vicious animal registered within the city to
any other person within the city unless the recipient person resides
permanently in the same household and on the same premises as the registered
owner of such vicious animal; provided that the registered owner of a vicious
animal may sell or otherwise dispose of a vicious animal to persons who do not
reside within the city. At any time that a vicious animal is located within the
confines of the city the standards and requirements of this section will apply.
   B.   Licensing Of Vicious Animals:
      1.   No person shall possess any vicious animal within the city for a
period of more than forty eight (48) hours without having first applied for
license therefor from the city.
      2.   An application for a license to possess a vicious animal shall be
filed with the city clerk on a form prescribed and provided by the city clerk
and shall be accompanied by all of the following:
         a.   Verification of the identity of the owner and current address by
providing a photostatic copy of the owner's driver's license, or other
acceptable identification.
         b.   Acknowledgment of ownership of the vicious animal.
         c.   A copy of any current immunization, county license and health
record of the vicious animal prepared by a veterinarian licensed to practice in
the state.
         d.   A certificate of insurance evidencing coverage in an amount not
less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) providing coverage for any
injury, damage or loss caused by the vicious animal.
         e.   Identification of the vicious animal by species and breed along
with any identifying markings.
         f.   Two (2) photographs of the vicious animal to be licensed taken
not more than one month before the date of the application.
            (1)   One photograph shall provide a front view of the vicious
animal and shall clearly show the face of the animal.
            (2)   One photograph shall show a side view of the vicious animal.
            (3)   The police department shall review the photographs and if
positive identification cannot be made with those submitted additional
photographs shall be required. The police department shall notify the owner of
the vicious animal and that owner will have ten (10) working days to provide
the photographs required by the police department.
         g.   A license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
         h.   A grant of permission by the applicant authorizing the police
department to go upon the premises whereat the vicious animal is to be kept,
for the purpose of performing the inspection required by subsection C of this
section.
         i.   Such other information as may be required by the city clerk.
   C.   Inspection: Upon receipt of an application, the city clerk shall
forward such application to the police department which shall cause an
inspection of the premises on which the vicious animal shall be kept to
determine that all provisions of this chapter relating to confinement and
posting of a sign have been complied with by the applicant. Upon completion of
the inspection, the police department shall notify the city clerk in writing
whether or not the premises comply with the requirements of this chapter.
   D.   Approval Or Denial Of License: Upon receipt of the results of the
police department inspection, the city clerk shall notify the applicant of the
approval or denial of the license. In the event that the license is denied, the
notification shall be provided in writing and the reasons for such denial shall
be stated. Upon approval, the city clerk shall issue a license to the
applicant.
   E.   Confinement Of Vicious Animal: It shall be unlawful for any person to
possess a vicious animal unless the vicious animal is confined in accordance
with this section.
      1.   Confinement Indoors: No vicious animal may be kept on a porch, patio
or in any part of a house or structure that would allow the vicious animal to
exit the structure on its own volition. No vicious animal shall be kept in a
house or structure when the windows are open or when screen windows or screen
doors are the only obstacle preventing the vicious animal from exiting the
structure.
      2.   Confinement In An Exterior Yard: No person shall permit a vicious
animal to be in an exterior area unless such vicious animal is confined in a
confinement structure constructed and maintained in accordance with this
chapter, except that a vicious animal may be confined outside of a confinement
structure in a manner set forth in the next following subsection.
      3.   Confinement On Leash: No person shall permit a vicious animal to go
outside a confinement structure, house or other structure unless the vicious
animal is securely restrained with a leash no longer than four feet (4') in
length and fitted with a muzzle. No person shall permit a vicious animal to be
kept on a leash unless a person is in physical control of the leash. No leash
restraining any vicious animal shall be attached to any inanimate object
including, but not limited to, trees, posts, stakes and buildings.
   F.   Sign Required: Any person possessing a vicious animal which has been
licensed as required herein shall at all times keep posted on the premises
whereat said animal is kept, a sign which is readable from the midpoint of the
street closest to said premises, or in the case of a corner lot from the
midpoint of the street on which any house or other structure thereon faces,
which said sign shall provide adequate warning that a vicious animal is kept on
the premises.
   G.   Reporting Requirements Of Licensee: Any person holding a license
pursuant to this chapter shall report the occurrence of any of the following
events to the police department:
      1.   The sale, barter, exchange, gift or death of any vicious animal
shall be reported within forty eight (48) hours.
      2.   The escape from confinement of any vicious animal shall be reported
upon discovery of the escape.
      3.   The biting or nipping of any person or animal by a vicious animal
shall be reported upon occurrence.
      4.   The permanent removal of any vicious animal from the territorial
limits of the city shall be reported within forty eight (48) hours of such
removal by surrender of the license of the owner to the city clerk. (Ord. 680,
8-9-2004)
10-7-7: KEEPING OF DANGEROUS ANIMALS PROHIBITED AND STANDARDS:
It shall be unlawful to keep, harbor, own or in any way possess within the
corporate limits of the city any dangerous animal, except and subject to the
standards and requirements herein set forth.
   A.   Licensing Of Dangerous Animals:
      1.   No person shall possess any dangerous animal within the city for a
period of more than forty eight (48) hours without having first applied for
license therefor from the city.
      2.   An application for a license to possess a dangerous animal shall be
filed with the city clerk on a form prescribed and provided by the city clerk
and shall be accompanied by all of the following:
         a.   Verification of the identity of the owner and current address by
providing a photostatic copy of the owner's driver's license, or other
acceptable identification.
         b.   Acknowledgment of ownership of the dangerous animal.
         c.   A copy of any current immunization, county license and health
record of the dangerous animal prepared by a veterinarian licensed to practice
in the state.
         d.   Identification of the dangerous animal by species and breed along
with any identifying markings.
         e.   Two (2) photographs of the dangerous animal to be licensed taken
not more than one month before the date of the application.
            (1)   One photograph shall provide a front view of the dangerous
animal and shall clearly show the face of the animal.
            (2)   One photograph shall show a side view of the dangerous
animal.
            (3)   The police department shall review the photographs and if
positive identification cannot be made with those submitted additional
photographs shall be required. The police department shall notify the owner of
the dangerous animal and that owner will have ten (10) working days to provide
the photographs required by the police department.
         f.   A license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
         g.   Such other information as may be required by the city clerk.
   B.   Confinement Of Dangerous Animal: It shall be unlawful for any person to
possess a dangerous animal unless the dangerous animal is confined in
accordance with this section.
      1.   Confinement On Leash: No person shall permit a dangerous animal
outside a confinement structure, house or other structure unless the dangerous
animal is securely restrained with a leash. No person shall permit a dangerous
animal to be kept on a leash unless a person is in physical control of the
leash. No leash restraining any dangerous animal shall be attached to any
inanimate object including, but not limited to, trees, posts, stakes and
buildings.
   C.   Reporting Requirements Of Dangerous Animal Licensee: Any person holding
a license pursuant to this chapter shall report the occurrence of any of the
following events to the police department:
      1.   The sale, barter, exchange, gift or death of any dangerous animal
shall be reported within forty eight (48) hours.
      2.   The escape from confinement of any dangerous animal shall be
reported upon discovery of the escape.
      3.   The biting or nipping of any person or animal by a dangerous animal
shall be reported upon occurrence.
      4.   The permanent removal of any dangerous animal from the territorial
limits of the city shall be reported within forty eight (48) hours of such
removal by surrender of the license of the owner to the city clerk. (Ord. 680,
8-9-2004)
10-7-8: DURATION AND RENEWAL OF VICIOUS ANIMAL LICENSE:
   A.   Every vicious animal license granted under this chapter shall be valid
for a period of twelve (12) months from the date thereof and must thereafter be
renewed annually.
   B.   An application for renewal of a license to possess a vicious animal
shall be filed with the city clerk on a form prescribed and provided by the
city clerk and shall be accompanied by all of the following:
      1.   Statement of the owner of the licensed vicious animal that all the
information contained in the original license application is still current,
valid and accurate; or
      2.   Statement of the owner as to any changes in the information
contained in the original license application.
      3.   A certificate of insurance evidencing coverage in an amount not less
than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) providing coverage for any injury,
damage or loss caused by the vicious animal.
      4.   Evidence that the required insurance coverage was maintained in
effect throughout the entire preceding year that the license sought to be
renewed was in effect. Failure to provide such evidence of insurance for the
preceding license year shall be automatic grounds for the nonrenewal of the
license and said license shall not under any circumstances be renewed.
      5.   A license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
      6.   Such other information as may be required by the city clerk.
   C.   Upon receipt of a license renewal application, the city clerk shall
forward such application to the police department which shall cause an
inspection of the premises on which the vicious animal shall be kept to
determine that all provisions of this chapter relating to confinement and
posting of a sign have been complied with by the applicant. Upon completion of
the inspection, the police department shall notify the city clerk in writing
whether or not the premises comply with the requirements of this chapter.
   D.   Upon receipt of the results of the police department inspection, the
city clerk shall notify the applicant of the approval or denial of the license
renewal. In the event that the license is denied, the notification shall be
provided in writing and the reasons for such denial shall be stated. Upon
approval, the city clerk shall issue a license to the applicant, which shall be
valid for a period of twelve (12) months from the date thereof. (Ord. 680, 8-9-
2004)
10-7-9: DURATION AND RENEWAL OF DANGEROUS ANIMAL LICENSE:
   A.   Every dangerous animal license granted under this chapter shall be
valid for a period of twelve (12) months from the date thereof and must
thereafter be renewed annually.
   B.   An application for renewal of a license to possess a dangerous animal
shall be filed with the city clerk on a form prescribed and provided by the
city clerk and shall be accompanied by all of the following:
      1.   Statement of the owner of the licensed dangerous animal that all the
information contained in the original license application is still current,
valid and accurate; or
      2.   Statement of the owner as to any changes in the information
contained in the original license application.
      3.   A license fee of ten dollars ($10.00).
      4.   Such other information as may be required by the city clerk. (Ord.
680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-10: FIGHTING PROHIBITED:
No person shall fight or bait, conspire to fight or bait, or keep, train, or
transport for the purpose of fighting or baiting, any animal in the city of
Marquette Heights. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-11: IMPOUNDMENT AND REDEMPTION:
   A.   Any vicious or dangerous animal as defined herein suspected of biting
or nipping any person or animal shall be subject to immediate impoundment by
the police department in a humane facility for the keeping of such animals. If
the incident giving rise to the impoundment has resulted in an injury to a
person, and the vicious or dangerous animal is a dog, upon impoundment by the
police department, the chief of police or his designee shall notify the rabies
control administrator of Tazewell County pursuant to the animal control act, as
amended and shall transfer control of the vicious or dangerous animal to the
administrator in accordance with the animal control act.
   B.   Any vicious or dangerous animal found to be running at large by any
member of the police department of the city shall be subject to impoundment by
the police department in a humane facility for the keeping of such animals.
   C.   An owner of a vicious or dangerous animal holding a license pursuant to
this chapter may redeem an impounded vicious or dangerous animal if:
      1.   The vicious or dangerous animal has been impounded pursuant to
subsection B of this section, or
      2.   The vicious or dangerous animal has not caused an injury to a person
subject to the following conditions:
         a.   Proof of valid license issued by the city under this chapter.
         b.   Payment of the cost of keeping the vicious or dangerous animal
during the period of impoundment.
   D.   An owner of a vicious or dangerous animal which has caused an injury to
a person resulting in the impoundment of the vicious or dangerous animal shall
be entitled to redeem the vicious or dangerous animal in accordance with the
animal control act, as amended. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-12: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
A license granted pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the hearing
committee upon any violation by the licensee of any provision of this chapter.
In the event of a revocation of the license, the license fee shall be retained
by the city. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-13: EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to any K-9 patrol dogs or police dogs as defined
herein. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-14: PENALTIES:
   A.   Upon a conviction of a violation of any section of this chapter the
court shall assess a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   B.   Upon a finding by the court of a violation of subsection 10-7-6B1 of
this chapter, the court may:
      1.   Order the animal in question to be impounded; and/or
      2.   Order the animal in question destroyed; and/or
      3.   Enter a mandatory injunction directing the owner(s) or keeper(s) of
such animal to comply with all requirements of this chapter within seven (7)
days or to permanently remove the animal from the city, forthwith.
   C.   Upon finding of a violation of any part of this section which involves
a vicious animal which was duly licensed pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter, the court, in addition to any other penalty imposed, shall enter an
order revoking such license and shall enter a mandatory injunction ordering
that:
      1.   Said animal be permanently removed from the city within forty eight
(48) hours; and/or
      2.   That said animal be impounded and destroyed.
   D.   Each day a violation of this chapter is found to exist shall be deemed
to be a separate offense. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-15: FAILURE TO COMPLY:
It shall be unlawful for the owner, keeper or harborer of a vicious animal
registered with the city to fail to comply with the requirements and conditions
set forth in this chapter. Any vicious animal found to be the subject of a
violation of this chapter shall be subject to immediate seizure and
impoundment. In addition, failure to comply will result in the removal of the
animal from the city. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
10-7-16: APPEAL:
Any person that owns or possesses any animal that has been determined vicious,
by the city of Marquette Heights, under any ordinance prior to September 1,
2004, may appeal that determination solely for the purpose of requesting that
the animal be identified as dangerous within the meaning of this chapter rather
than vicious. An appeal must be directed to the mayor and must be filed by the
owner in the office of the city clerk. Should an owner fail to appeal that
determination before March 1, 2005, the original determination that the animal
is vicious shall not thereafter be appealable.
Upon receipt of an appeal, the hearing committee shall convene an appeal
hearing for the purpose of determining whether the animal in question is either
a "vicious animal" or a "dangerous animal" as defined herein. The hearing shall
be held within no less than five (5) nor more than fourteen (14) working days
after the hearing committee serves a notice of the time, date and location of
the hearing upon the owner of the allegedly vicious or dangerous animal. At the
hearing, the owner shall have the opportunity to present a written statement of
appeal outlining all arguments and evidence they wish the hearing committee to
consider. The hearing committee will review the minutes, police reports and all
other evidence from the original hearing, along with the written statement from
the owner. The hearing committee will not hear new testimony.
Within five (5) working days after the conclusion of the appeal hearing, the
hearing committee shall determine whether or not the domestic animal is a
vicious animal or a dangerous animal within the meaning of this chapter. The
hearing committee shall notify the owner in writing of its determination. The
decision of the hearing committee shall be final. (Ord. 680, 8-9-2004)
TITLE 11
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL TRAFFIC PROVISIONS
SECTION:

11-1-2: Definitions

11-1-14-2: Obedience By Public Employees

11-1-15-2: Unauthorized Signs
