11-3-11: RESERVED:
(Ord. 653, 11-25-2002)
11-3-12: STOPPING, STANDING, PARKING OF BUSES:
   A.   The driver of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any
street at any place other than at a designated bus stand or bus terminal.
   B.   The driver of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any street at any
place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers other than at a
designated bus stop, bus stand, passenger loading zone or bus terminal except
in case of an emergency.
   C.   The driver of a bus shall enter a bus zone or passenger loading zone on
a public street in such a manner that the bus, when stopped to load or unload
passengers, shall be in a position with the right front wheel of such bus not
further than eighteen inches (18") from the curb and the bus approximately
parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular
traffic. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-3-13: BUS STANDS:
No vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus
loading zone. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-3-14: PARKING OF CERTAIN VEHICLES ON PUBLIC STREETS:
Unless otherwise specifically permitted in this section, no person shall park
or cause or permit any vehicle to stand on any street, roadway, public way or
parkway in the city except when such vehicle is actually delivering, unloading
or loading personal property to or from nearby premises and a qualified
operator is tending and in control of the vehicle.
   A.   The following motor vehicles are exempt from the provisions of this
section provided that any such vehicle when parked on a street or roadway does
not reduce the available road surface between the vehicle and the curb on the
side of the street opposite to the side on which the vehicle is parked to less
than sixteen feet (16') when measured perpendicular to the face of the curb on
the opposite side of the street to a point on the vehicle which is closest to
that curb, and provided further that any such vehicle contains no
modifications, accessories or loads which protrude from the exterior of the
vehicle in such a fashion as to impede, restrict or jeopardize the safety of
pedestrians:
      1.   Motor vehicle of the first division.
      2.   Motorcycles.
      3.   Trucks which carry a manufacturer's load rating of one ton or less.
      4.   Vehicles owned by the city of Marquette Heights, the state of
Illinois, or the United States.
   B.   Recreational vehicles shall be exempt from the provisions of this
section during the period of time each day which begins at seven o'clock (7:00)
A.M. and ends at sunset provided that any such vehicle when parked on a street
or roadway does not reduce the available road surface between the vehicle and
the curb on the side of the street opposite to the side on which the vehicle is
parked to less than sixteen feet (16') when measured perpendicular to the face
of the curb on the opposite side of the street to a point on the vehicle which
is closest to that curb and provided further that any such vehicle contains no
modifications, accessories or loads which protrude from the exterior of the
vehicle in such a fashion as to impede, restrict or jeopardize the safety of
pedestrians. (Ord. 653, 11-25-2002)
11-3-15: EMERGENCY AUTHORITY TO MOVE VEHICLES:
When any emergency arises necessitating the removal of any vehicle upon any
public way, members of the department of police are hereby authorized to remove
or have removed any such vehicle from one location to any other location. (Ord.
119, 1-20-1969)
11-3-16: SNOW REMOVAL:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to park any automobile or other
vehicle, or allow or permit same to be done on any street in the city, while
the city is operating a snowplow upon said streets for the purpose of removing
snow therefrom. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
   B.   It shall be the duty of the owner of any automobile or vehicle to
remove any automobile or vehicle from the street immediately after snow has
fallen and accumulated on said street to an amount of one inch (1"), which
accumulation of snow requires its removal by the city in order to allow traffic
thereon. (Ord. 158, 2-19-1973)
   C.   In the event that the owner of an automobile or vehicle shall refuse or
neglect to remove said automobile or vehicle as provided in subsection B of
this section, then in that event, the city, by its police officers or city
officials, shall have the right to have said automobile or vehicle removed from
the street by a private or public wrecker, truck or automobile at the expense
of the automobile or vehicle owner; and a violation of this section shall
constitute a separate offense for each day of such violation. (Ord. 669, 12-8-
2003)
11-3-17: STREET CLEANING:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any public street or portion
thereof in the city at any time when such street is being cleaned. Signs
indicating that a street or portion thereof is being cleaned shall be posted
before the cleaning of the street, and shall be removed after the cleaning of
the street is finished. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-3-18: VEHICLE REGISTRANT PRESUMED RESPONSIBLE FOR PARKING VIOLATIONS:
Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any provisions
prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in whose name such vehicle is
registered shall be prima facie responsible for such violation and subject to
the penalty therefor. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-3-19: NOTICE ON ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLES:
   A.   Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of any
city ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking and there is no person in
attendance upon such parked vehicle to be arrested or served immediately with a
traffic violation notice to appear in court to answer the charge of such
violation, any police officer observing such violation may attach to the
vehicle used in such violation, a traffic violation notice requiring that the
person in whose name such vehicle is registered appear in court on a day
certain named in such notice and answer to the charge of such violation.
   B.   When any vehicle is parked in a private parking lot in violation of
section
11-3-8 of this chapter and there is no person in attendance upon such parked
vehicle to be arrested or in attendance upon such parked vehicle to be served
immediately with a traffic violation notice to appear in court to answer the
charge of such violation, any police officer upon a written complaint signed by
the owner or proprietor of the lot, or by his authorized agent, that the
vehicle is not entitled to the privileges of the parking lot may attach to the
vehicle a traffic violation notice as provided herein.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the driver of the
vehicle to which said notice is attached, to remove the same from said vehicle.
(Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-3-20: IMPOUNDING VEHICLES:
The chief of police or any member of his department designated by him is hereby
authorized to remove or have removed any vehicle left at any place within the
city which reasonably appears to be in violation of this chapter or which
reasonably appears to be lost, stolen or unclaimed, or which is an inoperable
vehicle as defined herein 1 . Such vehicle shall be impounded until lawfully
claimed or disposed of in accordance with 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-
201 et seq. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969; amd. Ord. 436, 11-23-1992)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  11-1-2 of this title.
11-3-21: DESIGNATED PARKING FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS:
   A.   Designation Of Certain Parking Areas For Handicapped Persons:
      1.   Whenever signs are posted in specific areas, public or private,
which designate such specific areas as parking for handicapped persons, no
person shall park a vehicle within such an area, except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic or in compliance with directions of a police
officer or traffic control device.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person or operator, except physically
handicapped persons or those transporting physically handicapped persons, to
park a vehicle any time in any area designated for physically handicapped,
except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance
with directions of a police officer or other traffic control device.
      3.   Physically handicapped persons and transporters of physically
handicapped persons who have been issued handicapped license plates, or other
such identifying sticker placed in an area of visibility on a vehicle, by a
governmental unit may park vehicles in designated handicapped areas for periods
not to exceed three (3) hours at any time.
      4.   Any vehicle parked in a handicapped parking space must display a
handicapped license plate, or other such identifying sticker placed in an area
of visibility on a vehicle, issued by a governmental unit thus indicating the
right to park in the handicapped area under this section.
   B.   Fine And Enforcement: Any person found guilty of violating any
provision of this section shall be fined two hundred dollars ($200.00). Such
person shall also pay all required court costs. Any person receiving a citation
for violating any provision of this section shall be allowed to pay said fine
for a period of fourteen (14) days at the city clerk's office, 715 Lincoln
Road, prior to the citation being filed for prosecution in circuit court. (Ord.
508, 10-28-1996)
11-3-22: SETTLEMENT OPTION FOR ALLEGED VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Prior to the commencement of any action in circuit court, law
enforcement officers of the city may in their discretion provide any person
alleged to have violated any regulation governing stopping, standing or parking
as set forth in this chapter with notice of such alleged violation through the
issuance of a parking citation. (Ord. 551, 4-26-1999)
   B.   A parking citation issued under authority of this section shall be in
writing in a format approved by the chief of police in consultation with the
city attorney. Such parking citation shall constitute an offer to settle an
alleged violation under the following conditions:
      1.   The alleged violation, with the exception of a parking citation
written for violation of section
11-3-16 of this chapter pertaining to snow removal, may be settled within seven
(7) days after the date on which the parking citation is issued by the payment
of fifteen dollars ($15.00). A parking citation written for violation of
section
11-3-16 of this chapter pertaining to snow removal may be settled within seven
(7) days after the date on which the parking citation is issued by the payment
of twenty five dollars ($25.00).
      2.   The alleged violation, with the exception of a parking citation
written for violation of section
11-3-16 of this chapter pertaining to snow removal, may be settled within
fourteen (14) days after the date on which the parking citation is issued by
the payment of twenty five dollars ($25.00). A parking citation written for
violation of section
11-3-16 of this chapter pertaining to snow removal may be settled within
fourteen (14) days after the date on which the parking citation is issued by
the payment of forty dollars ($40.00).
      3.   The alleged violation, with the exception of a parking citation
written for violation of section
11-3-16 of this chapter pertaining to snow removal, may be settled within
thirty (30) days after the date on which the parking citation is issued by the
payment of fifty dollars ($50.00). A parking citation written for violation of
section
11-3-16 of this chapter pertaining to snow removal may be settled within thirty
(30) days after the date on which the parking citation is issued by the payment
of seventy dollars ($70.00).
      4.   Anything in this chapter to the contrary notwithstanding, alleged
violations of section
11-3-21 of this chapter pertaining to designated parking for handicapped
persons may be settled only by the payment of two hundred dollars ($200.00).
(Ord. 738, 11-26-2007)
   C.   Any offer of settlement represented by the issuance of a parking
citation may be accepted within the time limits hereinabove set forth by
payment of the appropriate amount at the office of the city clerk at the city
hall.
   D.   Should any alleged offender fail to accept the offer of settlement
represented by the issuance of a parking citation within thirty (30) days after
the issuance of that citation, such offer of settlement shall automatically
expire. Upon expiration of such offer of settlement, any law enforcement
officer of the city may without further notice to the alleged offender file a
complaint in Tazewell County circuit court charging the alleged offender with
one or more violations of this chapter. Upon conviction, the general penalty
provisions of this code shall apply; provided, however, that persons convicted
of violating section
11-3-21 of this chapter pertaining to designated parking for handicapped
persons shall be subject to the special penalty set forth in that section.
(Ord. 551, 4-26-1999)
CHAPTER 4
VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND INSPECTION
SECTION:
11-4-1: Driving Unsafe Vehicles Prohibited
11-4-2: Mufflers
11-4-3: Gas And Smoke
11-4-4: Brakes
11-4-5: Horn
11-4-6: Lights
11-4-7: Signal Lamps And Signal Devices
11-4-8: Nonskid Devices
11-4-9: Width, Length And Height; Projecting Loads
11-4-10: Spilling Loads
11-4-11: Authority Of Police To Inspect Vehicles
11-4-1: DRIVING UNSAFE VEHICLES PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to drive or move or for the owner to cause to or
knowingly permit to be driven or moved on any highway any vehicle or
combination of vehicles which is in such unsafe condition as to endanger any
person or property, or which does not contain those parts or is not at all
times equipped with such lamps and other equipment in proper condition and
adjustment as required by this chapter, or which is equipped in any manner in
violation hereof. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-4-2: MUFFLERS:
   A.   Every motor vehicle driven or operated upon the streets and highways of
the city shall at all times be equipped with an adequate muffler or exhaust
system in constant operation and properly maintained to prevent any excessive
or unusual noise. No such muffler or exhaust system shall be equipped with a
cutoff, bypass or similar device. No person shall modify the exhaust system of
a motor vehicle in a manner which will amplify or increase the noise of such
vehicle above that emitted by the muffler originally installed on the vehicle,
and such original muffler shall comply with all the requirements of this
section.
   B.   As used in this section, "muffler" means a device consisting of a
series of chambers or baffle plates or other mechanical design for the purpose
of receiving exhaust gas from an internal combustion engine and effective in
reducing noise. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-4-3: GAS AND SMOKE:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which emits dense smoke or such an
amount of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the health of persons or as to
endanger the drivers of other vehicles. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-4-4: BRAKES:
It shall be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle upon a city street unless such
vehicle is equipped with brakes in good working condition, or to operate any
vehicle which is so loaded that the operator does not have ready access to the
mechanics operating the brakes of such vehicle. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-4-5: HORN:
   A.   Every motor vehicle of the first and second division 1  when operated
upon a highway shall be equipped with a horn in good working order and capable
of emitting sound audible under normal conditions from a distance of not less
than two hundred feet (200'), but no horn or other warning device shall emit an
unreasonable loud or harsh sound or a whistle.
   B.   No vehicle shall be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a
vehicle any siren, whistle or bell, except as otherwise permitted by section
11-2-19 of this title and this section. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
 
Notes
1 1. See definition of "motor vehicle", section
  11-1-2 of this title.
11-4-6: LIGHTS:
   A.   Parked Vehicles: It shall be unlawful to operate or park on any street
any vehicle not equipped with adequate lights conforming to the requirements of
this title; provided, that vehicles may be parked at nighttime without lights
on any street or portion thereof, designated by city ordinance as a place where
vehicles may be so parked at nighttime.
   B.   Lights Required: During the period from sunset to sunrise, or at any
other time when visibility is so limited as to require the use of lights for
safety, every motorcycle operated on any street or other public place in the
city shall carry and exhibit one lighted lamp commonly known as a driving light
and every motor vehicle shall exhibit two (2) such lighted lamps showing white
lights, or lights of a yellow or amber tint, visible at least five hundred feet
(500') in the direction toward which each motorcycle or motor vehicle is
proceeding; and each motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer shall also exhibit
at least two (2) lighted lamps which shall be so situated as to throw a red
light visible for at least five hundred feet (500') in the reverse direction;
provided, that every trailer having a gross weight of three thousand (3,000)
pounds or less equipped with two (2) lighted lamps, one on each side of the
rear of such trailer which shall be so situated as to throw a red light visible
for at least five hundred feet (500') in the reverse direction.
   C.   Lamps On Vehicles Owned By Firemen: Any motor vehicle owned or fully
operated by any fireman may be equipped with not to exceed two (2) lamps which
shall emit a blue light without glare. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-4-7: SIGNAL LAMPS AND SIGNAL DEVICES:
Every motor vehicle and trailer having a gross weight of three thousand (3,000)
pounds and less, including the weight of the trailer and the maximum load,
shall be equipped with a signal lamp or signal device which is so constructed
and located on the vehicle as to give a signal of the intention to stop which
shall be red or yellow in color, and signals of intention to turn visible and
understandable in normal sunlight and at night from a distance of one hundred
feet (100') to the rear but shall not project a dazzling or glaring light;
except that a stop signal need be visible only from the rear.
Any trailer having a gross weight of three thousand (3,000) pounds or less,
including the weight of the trailer and maximum load, need not be equipped with
such turn signal device unless the distance from the steering wheel of the
swing vehicle to the left outside limits of such trailer body exceeds twenty
four inches (24").
All mechanical signal devices shall be self-illuminated during the period from
sunset to sunrise or when visibility is limited as to require the use of lights
for safety. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-4-8: NONSKID DEVICES:
It shall be unlawful to operate upon any city street any motor vehicle equipped
with any nonskid device so constructed that any rigid or nonflexible portion
thereof comes into contact with the pavement or roadway. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-4-9: WIDTH, LENGTH AND HEIGHT; PROJECTING LOADS:
No passenger type vehicle shall be operated on the streets of the city with a
load extending beyond the line of the fenders on the left side of the vehicle
nor extending beyond the line of the fenders on the right side thereof. (Ord.
119, 1-20-1969)
11-4-10: SPILLING LOADS:
   A.   No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any city streets unless such
vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any of its load from
dropping, shifting, leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom, except that sand
may be dropped for the purpose of securing traction, or water or other
substance may be sprinkled on a roadway in cleaning or maintaining such
roadway.
   B.   No person shall operate on any city streets any vehicle with any load
unless said load and any covering thereon is securely fastened so as to prevent
said covering or load from becoming loose, detached or in any manner a hazard
to other users of the streets.
   C.   No person shall operate on any public street within the city any truck
or other vehicle when mud, sand or other like substance is likely to be thrown
off the tires or treads of such vehicle and deposited on the streets in
noticeable quantities. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-4-11: AUTHORITY OF POLICE TO INSPECT VEHICLES:
All police officers are hereby empowered at all times to inspect any vehicle to
determine its compliance with the equipment and other provisions of this title.
(Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
CHAPTER 5
PEDESTRIANS
SECTION:
11-5-1: Pedestrians Subject To Traffic Control Signals
11-5-2: Pedestrian's Right Of Way At Crossing
11-5-3: Crossing By Shortest Route, Suddenly Leaving Curb
11-5-4: Prohibited Crossings
11-5-5: Use Of Sidewalks
11-5-6: Blind Persons, Right Of Way
11-5-7: Soliciting Rides
11-5-8: Pedestrians To Exercise Due Care
11-5-1: PEDESTRIANS SUBJECT TO TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNALS:
Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control signals at intersections as
provided by law but at all other places pedestrians shall be accorded the
privileges and shall be subject to the restrictions as stated in this chapter.
(Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-5-2: PEDESTRIAN'S RIGHT OF WAY AT CROSSING 1 :
   A.   Where traffic control signals are not in place or in operation the
driver of a vehicle shall yield the right of way, slowing down or stopping if
need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within any marked
crosswalk, or within any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection, except as
otherwise provided in this chapter 2 .
   B.   Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any
unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the
roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not
overtake and pass such stopped vehicle.
   C.   Whenever stop signs are in place at an intersection or at a plainly
marked crosswalk between intersections, pedestrians shall have the right of way
over drivers of vehicles. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 11-2-17 of this title.
2 2. See also section
  11-2-2 of this title.
11-5-3: CROSSING BY SHORTEST ROUTE, SUDDENLY LEAVING CURB:
   A.   No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a route
at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb
except in a marked crosswalk.
   B.   No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and
walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible
for the driver to yield. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-5-4: PROHIBITED CROSSINGS:
No pedestrians shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any business
district. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-5-5: USE OF SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian
to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway except at a crosswalk.
   B.   Persons shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of
crosswalks and sidewalks. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-5-6: BLIND PERSONS, RIGHT OF WAY:
Any blind person who is carrying in a raised or extended position a cane or
walking stick which is white in color or white tipped with red, or who is being
guided by a dog, shall have the right of way in crossing any street or highway,
whether or not traffic on such street or highway is controlled by traffic
signals, anything in this chapter to the contrary notwithstanding. The driver
of every vehicle approaching the place where a blind person, so carrying such a
cane or walking stick or being so guided, is crossing a street or highway shall
bring his vehicle to a full stop and before proceeding shall take such
precautions as may be necessary to avoid injury to the blind person. The
provisions of this section shall not apply to a blind person who is not
carrying a white cane or walking stick or guided by a dog, but the other
provisions of this chapter relating to pedestrians shall then be applicable to
such person. However, the failure of a blind person to so use or carry such a
cane or walking stick or to be guided by a guide dog when walking on streets,
highways or sidewalks shall not be considered evidence of contributory
negligence. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-5-7: SOLICITING RIDES:
No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from
the driver of any private vehicle. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-5-8: PEDESTRIANS TO EXERCISE DUE CARE:
Nothing in this chapter shall relieve a pedestrian from the duty of exercising
due care. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
CHAPTER 6
BICYCLES
SECTION:
11-6-1: Scope Of Regulations
11-6-2: Traffic Laws Apply To Riders
11-6-3: Mechanical Condition
11-6-4: Equipment Required
11-6-5: Rules Of Operation
11-6-1: SCOPE OF REGULATIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to
perform any act required in this chapter.
   B.   The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not
authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the
provisions hereof.
   C.   The regulations applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever any bicycle
is operated upon any highway or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use
of bicycles subject to those exceptions stated herein. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-6-2: TRAFFIC LAWS APPLY TO RIDERS:
Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be subject to the provisions
of the traffic and vehicle ordinances of the city, except as changed by special
regulations contained in this chapter and except as to those provisions of the
traffic ordinances which, by their nature, can have no application. (Ord. 119,
1-20-1969)
11-6-3: MECHANICAL CONDITION:
All police officers shall have authority to inspect all bicycles for mechanical
fitness. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-6-4: EQUIPMENT REQUIRED:
   A.   Brakes: Every bicycle when operated upon a highway shall be equipped
with a brake adequate to control the movement of and to stop such bicycle
whenever necessary.
   B.   Lamps And Reflectors: Every bicycle operated after sunset shall be
equipped with a lamp on the front exhibiting a white light visible from a
distance of at least three hundred feet (300') to the front and with a red
reflector on the rear. Every such reflector shall be so designed and maintained
as to be visible at night from all distances within two hundred feet (200') to
fifty feet (50') from such bicycle when directly in front of a motor vehicle
displaying lawfully lighted headlamps. A lamp exhibiting a red light visible
from a distance of two hundred feet (200') to the rear may be used in addition
to the rear reflector.
   C.   Audible Signal: No person shall ride a bicycle unless it is equipped
with a bell or other device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance
of at least one hundred feet (100'); except that no bicycle shall be equipped
with nor shall any person use upon a bicycle any siren or whistle. (Ord. 119,
1-20-1969)
11-6-5: RULES OF OPERATION:
   A.   Riding On Bicycles:
      1.   A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than upon the
permanent and regular seat attached thereto, nor carry any other person upon
such bicycle other than upon a firmly attached and regular seat thereon, nor
shall any person ride upon a bicycle other than as above authorized.
      2.   No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the
number for which it is designed and equipped.
   B.   Right Of Way On Sidewalks: When permitted or required by this chapter
to ride on sidewalks, bicycle riders shall use the right side of sidewalks
insofar as practicable. A person riding a bicycle on a sidewalk shall yield the
right of way to every pedestrian and when approaching a pedestrian from the
rear shall give audible warning signal when at least twenty five feet (25')
distant from the pedestrian.
   C.   Speed Of Bicycles: No person riding a bicycle shall ride faster than is
reasonable and proper in regard to the safety of the rider and others.
   D.   Clinging To Vehicles: No person riding upon any bicycle shall hold on
or cling to another vehicle powered by a motor.
   E.   Carrying Articles: No person riding a bicycle shall carry any package,
bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon
the handlebars.
   F.   Trick Riding: No rider of a bicycle shall remove both hands from the
handlebars, or feet from the pedals, or practice any acrobatic or fancy riding
on any street; nor shall any person operating a bicycle upon a public highway
participate in any race for speed or endurance contest with any other vehicle,
except under permit from and under the supervision of the police department.
   G.   Parking Bicycles: No person shall park a bicycle in such a manner as to
interfere with pedestrians or persons getting into or out of vehicles. (Ord.
119, 1-20-1969)
CHAPTER 7
TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS; BAIL PROCEDURE
SECTION:
11-7-1: Effect Of Provisions
11-7-2: Bail, Purpose Of
11-7-3: Bail Schedule, Traffic
11-7-4: Traffic Offenses, Court Appearance Required
11-7-5: Multiple Violations At One Time
11-7-6: Cash Bail
11-7-7: Appearance Date
11-7-8: Guilty Pleas; Hearings
11-7-9: Bail For Minors
11-7-10: Driver's License Or Bond Certificate
11-7-11: Copy Of Bond, Receipt For Cash Bail
11-7-12: Persons To Whom Bail Is Made
11-7-13: Schedule Of Bail
11-7-1: EFFECT OF PROVISIONS:
It is hereby declared by the city council that:
   A.   This chapter is intended to provide for in this title the applicable
rules of the Illinois supreme court as set forth in rules 501 through 556,
effective January 1, 1968, as said rules effect and pertain to bail and bail
procedure for traffic offenses charged under this title.
   B.   This chapter is intended, by its provisions, to require compliance with
said rules and to inform police officers and future offenders of the specific
application of said rules to offenses charged under this title.
   C.   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as an attempt to enlarge,
change or limit the powers of any court or rights of the accused with regard to
bail or bail procedures as is now or might hereafter be provided by state law
or the rules of the Illinois supreme court. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-7-2: BAIL, PURPOSE OF:
The purpose of bail is only to assure the appearance of the defendant in court.
In a serious case where the arresting officer believes the preset amount of
bail is inadequate for that purpose, the offender shall be brought before a
judge without necessary delay. When it appears that bail is not necessary to
assure defendant's appearance, none should be required. The arresting officer
instead shall issue a notice to appear. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-7-3: BAIL SCHEDULE, TRAFFIC:
There is hereby incorporated by reference and adopted as a part of this code in
haec verba, Illinois supreme court rules 501 through 556 inclusive, as same now
exist and as same may from time to time hereafter be amended. (Ord. 436, 11-23-
1992)
11-7-4: TRAFFIC OFFENSES, COURT APPEARANCE REQUIRED:
A court appearance is required for the following offenses:
Code Section  Description
Code Section   Description
11-1-14-4     Fleeing or attempting to elude police officer.
11-2-8        Failure to stop; stop sign or signal at through highway or
               intersection.
11-2-23A,B    Speeding - only 21 mph or more over limit.
11-2-23C      Speeding in school zone.
11-2-28C      Driving through safety zone.
11-2-34       Reckless driving.
11-2-35       Drag racing.
11-2-36       Driving under influence of liquor or drugs.
11-2-37       Illegal transportation of alcoholic liquor.
 
Any other traffic offense which results in an accident causing injury to or the
death of any person shall require a court appearance. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-7-5: MULTIPLE VIOLATIONS AT ONE TIME:
When a person has been arrested at one time for more than one offense under
this code, he shall be released upon furnishing bail on the charge for which
the highest bail is required. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-7-6: CASH BAIL:
The arresting officer shall supply a stamped envelope addressed to the circuit
clerk of Tazewell County and will place the appropriate portion of the ticket
in the envelope and give a copy of the ticket to the defendant. The defendant
will place in the same envelope the required amount of bail in cash or his
driver's license or bond certificate as the case may be. If a court appearance
is not required, he shall include his signed statement consenting to the entry
of an ex parte judgment if he fails to appear. In the presence of the arresting
officer he shall mail same to the circuit clerk. If he does not appear on the
appearance date, a judgment may be entered against him for an amount not more
than the bail but probably equal to it.
If a court appearance is required, the consent to ex parte judgment shall not
be signed or mailed and, if the defendant fails to appear, the bail may be
forfeited and the court may order a complaint filed and a summons or arrest
warrant issued.
When a defendant is released upon posting bail by any of the methods described
above, the arresting officer will furnish him with a copy of the ticket on
which will be noted which form of bail was accepted. The arresting officer
shall transmit the appropriate portions of the ticket and the license or bond,
if any, to the circuit clerk of Tazewell County within forty eight (48) hours
of the time set for appearance, whichever is earlier. The defendant being
released by any of these methods may select which he will use. The arresting
officer shall not require the deposit of a bond certificate or driver's license
instead of cash. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-7-7: APPEARANCE DATE:
When a court appearance is required, the arresting officer shall fix an
appearance date on the defendant's ticket or notice to appear. This date shall
be not less than ten (10) days nor more than forty five (45) days from the date
of arrest unless it is not practicable for the arresting officer or the
defendant to appear within such period.
If the arresting officer fails to appear on the date and at the time fixed for
the defendant's appearance, the case will be dismissed for want of prosecution.
If the arresting officer shall be unable to appear on the date fixed, he shall
notify the proper prosecutor beforehand so that a new date may be set and the
defendant notified. In such case a new appearance date shall be set. All
appearances of a person charged with more than one offense arising out of the
same occurrence shall be set at the same time. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-7-8: GUILTY PLEAS; HEARINGS:
If a ticket does not require a court appearance, the defendant may elect
either: a) to appear for hearing on the date to be fixed by the arresting
officer for a trial, or b) if he does not wish to appear he may deliver or mail
his plea of guilty on the form supplied to him by the arresting officer, to the
clerk not earlier than five (5) days after his arrest or later than three (3)
days before his appearance date, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. The
clerk shall apply the cash bail to the payment of the fine and costs and will
deliver or mail to the defendant the balance, if any. If the defendant has not
posted bail (in effect notice to appear) he shall enclose the total of the fine
and costs with his plea of guilty. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-7-9: BAIL FOR MINORS:
   A.   Individual Bond, Persons Under Eighteen: Persons under eighteen (18)
years of age may be released by giving individual bond (in the amount required
by this chapter) if a parent, or adult standing in the place of a parent,
executes the bond as surety.
   B.   Alternative Procedure, Persons Under Eighteen: In any case in which the
bail specified under this chapter does not exceed thirty five dollars ($35.00)
a defendant may place cash bail (in the amount required by such rule) in a
stamped envelope (to be provided by the arresting officer) addressed to the
clerk of the circuit court of Tazewell County and, in the presence of the
arresting officer, deposit that envelope in a United States government mailbox.
The defendant shall then be released from custody. The appropriate portion(s)
of the ticket shall be enclosed with the cash bail. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-7-10: DRIVER'S LICENSE OR BOND CERTIFICATE:
   A.   If a defendant deposits a driver's license with the arresting officer
in lieu of bail or in addition to bail, or deposits a bond certificate, the
arresting officer shall note that fact on the violator's copy of the ticket and
transmit the driver's license or bond certificate to the clerk within the time
provided in this chapter.
   B.   Not sooner than five (5) days after arrest (excluding Saturdays,
Sundays and holidays) and not later than three (3) days before the date set for
appearance in court (excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays), the defendant
who has deposited his driver's license or a bond certificate in lieu of cash
bail may recover either by substituting cash bail in the appropriate amount
with the clerk of the circuit court of Tazewell County. The clerk may waive the
time limit specified by this section. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-7-11: COPY OF BOND, RECEIPT FOR CASH BAIL:
A carbon copy of the bond or an official receipt showing the amount of cash
bail posted, specifying the time and place of court appearance, shall be
furnished to the accused and shall constitute a receipt for bail. The bond or
cash bail, or both, shall be delivered to the office of the circuit clerk of
Tazewell County within forty eight (48) hours of receipt or within the time set
for the accused's appearance in court, whichever is earlier. (Ord. 119, 1-20-
1969)
11-7-12: PERSONS TO WHOM BAIL IS MADE:
Bail for any offense under this title may be taken by the circuit clerk, his
deputies, and also by certain law enforcement officers. A list of these
officers is available in the circuit clerk's office of Tazewell County. They
may take the bail at any police station, sheriff's office, jail, state highway
police headquarters building, or any other government office designated by the
chief judge of the tenth judicial circuit. (Ord. 119, 1-20-1969)
11-7-13: SCHEDULE OF BAIL:
There is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated into the city code,
article V of the rules of the supreme court of Illinois (rule 501 to 600
inclusive) as the same now exist or as may hereafter be amended, as section
11-7-13 of the city code with the full force and effect as if same were set
forth herein in full form and detail. (Ord. 278, 3-8-1982)
CHAPTER 8
MOTOR VEHICLE LICENSING
SECTION:
11-8-1: Definitions
11-8-2: Presumption Of Ownership
11-8-3: Imposition Of Fee
11-8-4: Exemptions
11-8-5: Use Of Funds
11-8-6: Penalties
11-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms as used in this chapter shall have the indicated meanings:
FEE: Is a license fee for the use of motor vehicles as authorized by 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-4.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Is automobiles and all other self-propelled vehicles defined as
a motor vehicle by the Illinois Vehicle Code.
PERSON: Is a natural person, firm, partnership or corporation.
SENIOR CITIZEN: Is a person defined as a senior citizen by section
9-6-1 of this Code.
SERVICE LOCATION: Is the location within the City where a utility customer
receives water and/or wastewater service from the City.
UTILITY CUSTOMER: Is any person who receives water or wastewater service from
the City at a location within the City. (Ord. 878, 6-25-2018, eff. 1-1-2019)
11-8-2: PRESUMPTION OF OWNERSHIP:
There is a rebuttable presumption that each utility customer, a person residing
with the utility customer or a tenant of the utility customer has at least one
motor vehicle registered at the utility customer's service location. A utility
customer may rebut this presumption by filing a sworn affidavit with the City
Clerk asserting that there is no motor vehicle registered at the utility
customer's service location. Upon receipt of such an affidavit, the City Clerk
shall conduct such investigation as he or she deems appropriate. If upon
completion of such investigation the City Clerk determines that no motor
vehicle is registered at the utility customer's service location, then such
utility customer shall not be subject to the fee imposed by this chapter. (Ord.
878, 6-25-2018, eff. 1-1-2019)
11-8-3: IMPOSITION OF FEE:
Each utility customer shall pay the fee imposed by this chapter in the
following amount which shall be added each month to the bill received by the
utility customer from the City for water and/or wastewater service:
   A.   Three dollars ($3.00) per month for all utility customers other than
utility customers who qualify as senior citizens; or
   B.   One dollar fifty cents ($1.50) per month for all utility customers who
qualify as senior citizens. (Ord. 878, 6-25-2018, eff. 1-1-2019)
11-8-4: EXEMPTIONS:
The following motor vehicles are exempt from the provisions of this chapter:
   A.   Motor vehicles used as inventory and for sale at an established
automotive sales business located within a commercial zone within the City.
   B.   Motor vehicles of any kind owned by the City, any other governmental
unit, any church or charitable organization, or any other vehicle bearing an
"M" or "CV" license plate. (Ord. 878, 6-25-2018, eff. 1-1-2019)
11-8-5: USE OF FUNDS:
Revenues derived from the fee shall be used for the purpose of improving,
paving, repairing and maintaining the streets, sidewalks, curbs, gutters, and
other public right-of-ways within the City, except for the cost of collecting
the fee. (Ord. 878, 6-25-2018, eff. 1-1-2019)
11-8-6: PENALTIES:
Any fee not paid by the 20th day of the month following the receipt of the bill
for utility services shall be subject to a late charge of ten percent (10%) of
the amount of the fee which shall be added to the bill sent for the subsequent
month. (Ord. 878, 6-25-2018, eff. 1-1-2019)
CHAPTER 9
GOLF CARTS ON PUBLIC STREETS
(Rep. by Ord. 911, 9-14-2020)
CHAPTER 10
GOLF CARTS/ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES ON PUBLIC STREETS
SECTION:
11-10-1: Definitions
11-10-2: Limitations On Operation
11-10-3: Safety Equipment
11-10-4: Regulations Specifically Applicable To Golf Cart Or All-Terrain
Vehicles
11-10-5: Permits
11-10-6: Penalties
11-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, “golf cart” means a vehicle specifically
designed and intended for the purpose of transporting one or more persons and
their golf clubs or maintenance equipment while engaged in the playing of golf,
supervising the play of golf or maintaining the conditions of the grounds of a
public or private golf course.
“All-terrain vehicle” means any motorized off highway device designed to travel
primarily off highway, traveling on four (4) or more low pressure tires,
designed with a non-saddle seat for operator use, and a steering wheel for
steering control, except equipment such as lawn mowers. (Ord. 604, 5-29-2001;
amd. Ord. 888, 6-24-2019; amd. Ord. 911, 9-14-2020; Ord. 926, 3-14-2022; Ord.
947, 8-14-2023)
11-10-2: LIMITATIONS ON OPERATION:
Subject to the limitations set forth in this chapter, any person with a valid
driver’s license may operate a golf cart or all-terrain vehicle in the City of
Marquette Heights. This section shall not be construed as granting permission
for any person operating a golf cart or all-terrain vehicle to drive upon or
across any street or highway under the jurisdiction of Groveland or Pekin
Township or Tazewell County, or to drive upon or across any street or highway
under the jurisdiction of the Illinois Department of Transportation including,
without limitation, Illinois Route 29. (Ord. 604, 5-29-2001; amd. Ord. 888, 6-
24-2019; Ord. 911, 9-14-2020)
11-10-3: SAFETY EQUIPMENT:
No all-terrain vehicle may be operated on a street or highway under the
jurisdiction of the City of Marquette Heights unless, at a minimum, it has the
following safety equipment:
   A.   Brakes;
   B.   Steering apparatus;
   C.   Tires;
   D.   Rearview mirror;
   E.   Seatbelts, if applicable.
   F.   Red reflectorized warning devices on the rear;
   G.   A slow moving emblem (as required of other vehicles in 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 12-709) on the rear of the golf cart.
   H.   A headlamp that emits a white light visible from a distance of at least
five hundred feet (500') to the front;
   I.   A tail lamp that emits a red light visible from a distance of at least
one hundred feet (100') from the rear;
   J.   Brake lights; and
   K.   Turn signals. (Ord. 888, 6-24-2019; amd. Ord. 911, 9-14-2020)
11-10-4: REGULATIONS SPECIFICALLY APPLICABLE TO GOLF CART OR ALL-TERRAIN
VEHICLES:
When on a street or highway under the jurisdiction of the City of Marquette
Heights, an all-terrain vehicle shall be operated in accordance with the
following regulations:
   A.   The golf cart or all-terrain vehicle shall have its headlights and tail
lamps lighted at all times.
   B.   Any person operating a golf cart or all-terrain vehicle as authorized
in this chapter shall travel on the street or highway in the same direction as
traffic.
   C.   Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, any person operating a
golf cart or all-terrain vehicle on streets or highways under the jurisdiction
of the City of Marquette Heights shall obey any and all traffic regulations set
forth either in this Code or the Illinois Vehicle Code.
   D.   The golf cart or all-terrain vehicle shall be covered with either
automobile insurance to the extent required by State law. Insurance card must
be available upon request
   E.   When operating on the streets or highways under the jurisdiction of the
City of Marquette Heights, the operator of the golf cart or all-terrain vehicle
shall be limited to those streets or highways with a speed limit of thirty five
(35) miles per hour or less.
   F.   Each golf cart or all-terrain vehicle may transport only as many
individuals as is the less of the number of seats or as its manufacturer
designates. No individual may ride on any other portion of the golf cart or
all-terrain vehicle.
   G.   Golf carts and all-terrain vehicles may only operate on City of
Marquette Heights streets from dawn to midnight.
   H.   No person shall possess alcoholic beverages on or in a golf cart or
all-terrain vehicle on City’s streets unless it is in the original container
with the seal unbroken.
   I.   Must display City of Marquette Heights decal on the front of the
vehicle. (Ord. 947, 8-14-2023)
11-10-5: PERMITS:
   A.   No person shall operate a qualified golf cart or all-terrain vehicle
without first obtaining a permit from the Chief of Police or his designee. A
copy of said permit shall be kept in the golf cart or off-highway vehicle
whenever used on City of Marquette Heights streets. Only an individual with a
valid permit shall be allowed to operate a golf cart or all-terrain vehicle on
the streets within the City of Marquette Heights and said individual shall only
be allowed to operate a golf cart or all-terrain vehicle that has been
inspected and approved for travel on City of Marquette Heights streets and
feature a City of Marquette Heights decal as detailed above.
   B.   Permits shall be granted for a period of one year for the date
designated on the permit. Permits will have a renewal date annually of April
1st regardless of when-the permit was granted.
   C.   The cost of the permit is Fifty Dollars ($50.00). All permit renewals
are Fifty Dollars ($50.00) regardless of the month issued.
   D.   Insurance coverage is to be verified to be in effect by the City of
Marquette Heights Police Department when obtaining and renewing a permit. The
applicant must provide evidence of
   E.   The applicant must provide evidence that they are a resident of North
Pekin or the City of Marquette Heights. (Ord. 947, 8-14-2023)
11-10-6: PENALTIES:
   A.   Operating a golf cart or-all-terrain vehicle on City of Marquette
Heights streets is a privilege and not a right, any person who has a permit to
operate a golf cart or all-terrain vehicle on City of Marquette Heights streets
and is found to have violated this chapter may have his or her permit suspended
or revoked by the Chief of Police. Decisions of the Chief of Police shall only
be reversed or modified by a majority vote of City of Marquette Heights
Council.
   B.   Anyone found to operate a golf cart or all-terrain vehicle on’ City of
Marquette Heights streets, within the City in an area where golf carts and all-
terrain vehicles are not allowed, or to operate a golf cart or all-terrain
vehicle that has not been inspected and approved by the City of Marquette
Heights for travel on City streets shall be subject to a One Hundred Fifty
Dollar ($150.00) fine for the first violation, a Three Hundred Dollar ($300.00)
fine for a second violation and a Five Hundred Dollar ($500.00) fine for a
third violation within a 365 day period. The City’s- Attorney shall have the
authority to bring a complaint against any individual violating this chapter to
recover the aforementioned fines and to seek an injunction against further
violations of this chapter.
   C.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, anyone found to operate a golf cart or
all-terrain vehicle on City of Marquette Heights streets in violation of any
other provision of this chapter shall be subject to a One Hundred Fifty Dollar
($150.00) fine for the first violation, a Three Hundred Dollar ($300.00) fine
for a second violation and a Five Hundred Dollar ($500.00) fine for a third
violation within a 365 day period. Any person committing three violations of
this chapter, regardless of whether it is within a 365 day period or not, shall
forever lose their permit to obtain and maintain an off-highway vehicle.
   The City of Marquette Heights Attorney shall have the authority to bring a
complaint against any individual violating this chapter to recover the
aforementioned fines and to seek an injunction against further violations of
this chapter.
   D.   Any-person in possession of or consuming alcoholic beverages on or in a
golf cart or all- terrain vehicle on City of Marquette Heights streets, in
addition to other penalties which may be available under the laws of the State
of Illinois or other parts of this chapter, shall be subject to revocation of
his or her permit to operate a golf cart or off-highway vehicle on City of
Marquette Heights streets. If a person driving or in control of a golf cart or
all-terrain vehicle on City of Marquette Heights streets refuses to submit to a
test or analysis of the person’s blood, urine, breath or other bodily substance
to test for an alcohol or drug concentration, in addition to other penalties
which may be available under the laws of the State of Illinois or other parts
of this chapter, shall have their permit to operate a golf cart or non-highway
vehicle on City streets permanently revoked.
   E.   Any person receiving a citation under this Article shall pay any
monetary fine provided in this section at the Police Department or City of
Marquette Heights Clerk’s office within twenty-one (21) days from the date of
the citation. If any monetary penalty is not paid within that twenty-one (21)
day period, the Police Department is authorized to file a complaint alleging
the violation of this chapter and issue a notice to appear requiring the
offender to appear in the Tazewell County Circuit Court to answer to the
charge. (Ord. 947, 8-14-2023)
 
CHAPTER 11
SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES
SECTION:
11-11-1: Definitions
11-11-2: Vehicles Subject To Seizure And Impounding
11-11-3: Seizure And Impounding Of Vehicles
11-11-4: Exceptions
11-11-5: Posting Of Bond
11-11-6: Preliminary Hearing
11-11-7: Owner's Hearing
11-11-8: Unclaimed Vehicles
11-11-9: Liability Of Penalty And Costs
11-11-10: Hearing Officer
11-11-11: Decision Review
11-11-12: Vehicle Possession
11-11-13: Special Account For Funds
11-11-14: Partial Invalidity/Saving Clause
11-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever in this chapter the following words and phrases are used, they shall
have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
CANNABIS PARAPHERNALIA: Includes equipment, products, or materials intended to
be used for planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting,
manufacturing, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging,
repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, ingesting, or otherwise
introducing cannabis into the human body.
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: Any substance as defined and included in the schedule
contained in article II of the Illinois Controlled Substance Act 1  and
cannabis as defined in the Cannabis Control Act 2 .
DRIVING UNDER THE INFLUENCE: Any violation as defined in section 11-501 of the
Illinois Vehicle Code 3 .
DRIVING WHILE LICENSE, PERMIT OR PRIVILEGE TO OPERATE A MOTOR VEHICLE IS
SUSPENDED OR REVOKED: Any violation as defined in section 6-303 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code 4 .
HEARING OFFICER: A licensed attorney who is not an officer or employee of the
City.
OPERATION OF A MOTOR VEHICLE WITHOUT A VALID DRIVER'S LICENSE: Any violation of
section 6/101 of the Illinois Vehicle Code 5 , as amended from time to time.
OWNER OF RECORD: The record title holder to a motor vehicle as registered with
the Secretary of State, State of Illinois.
UNLAWFUL USE OF WEAPONS: Any violation of section 24-1 of the Criminal Code of
1961 1 . (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018; Ord. 904, 12-9-2019)

1 1. 720 ILCS 5/24-1.
11-11-2: VEHICLES SUBJECT TO SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDING:
A motor vehicle, operated with the express or implied permission of the owner
of record, shall be subject to seizure and impoundment under this chapter when
an officer has probable cause to believe such vehicle is used in connection
with any of the following violations, or which may jeopardize the public's
safety and safe vehicular movement and in furtherance of public safety, or in
the exercise by the police department of its community caretaker functions.
Violations.
   A.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of the Cannabis Control Act.
   B.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of the Illinois Controlled
Substances Act.
   C.   Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs,
intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof in violation of
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501(a).
   D.   Driving while license, permit, or privilege to operate a motor vehicle
is suspended, revoked, or expired, except that vehicle shall not be subjected
to seizure or impoundment if the suspension is for an unpaid citation (parking
or moving) or due to failure to comply with emission testing.
   E.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit an offense in violation of Section 24-1 (the unlawful use of
weapons); 24-1.5 (reckless discharge of a firearm); or 24-3.1 (unlawful
possession of firearms and firearm ammunition) in violation of the Illinois
Criminal Code of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.).
   F.   Operation or use of a vehicle in connection with the commission or
attempted commission of any other misdemeanor or felony offense defined under
chapter 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes.
   G.   Aggravated fleeing and eluding in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-204.1.
   H.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a warrant
has been issued by a circuit court in Illinois for failing to answer charges
that the driver violated Section 6-101, 6-303, or 11-501 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code.
   I.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired valid driver's
license if the period of expiration is greater than one (1) year in violation
of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101.
   J.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a
driver's license or permit, or operating a motor vehicle without ever having
been issued a driver's license or permit due to a person's age in violation of
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101.
   K.   Reckless driving while the vehicle is part of a funeral procession or
in a manner that interferes with a funeral procession.
   L.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possessing or
attempting to solicit or possess cannabis or a controlled substance, provided
however, that no vehicle shall be subject to impound or forfeiture solely for
the possession of cannabis or cannabis paraphernalia by persons twenty one (21)
years of age or older in accordance with the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act
(410 ILCS 705/1-1 et seq.) or by a registered qualifying patient or registered
designated caregiver as authorized by the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis
Program Act (410 ILCS 130/1 et seq.).
   M.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission or attempted
commission of any offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and forfeited
pursuant to the Illinois Criminal Code of 2012, 720 ILCS 5/36-1 et seq. (Ord.
875, 4-23-2018; Ord. 904, 12-9-2019)
11-11-3: SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES:
Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a vehicle is
subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this chapter, the police officer
shall cause the motor vehicle to be towed to a facility controlled by the City
or its agents. When the vehicle is towed, the police officer shall notify any
person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged
violation and/or the owner of the seizure and of the vehicle owner's right to
request a preliminary hearing as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 875, 4-23-
2018)
11-11-4: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply if at the time of the offense,
the vehicle was found to have been stolen, and the theft was reported to the
appropriate police authority within twenty four (24) hours after the theft was,
or reasonably should have been discovered. (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018)
11-11-5: POSTING OF BOND:
If a bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) is posted with the
City, the impounded vehicle will be released to the owner of record, upon the
payment by the owner of record of the towing and storage costs. If a penalty is
imposed for a violation of this chapter, the bond will be forfeited to the
City; provided in the event that a violation of this chapter is not proven, the
bond will be returned to the person posting the bond. All bond money pursuant
to this chapter will be held by the City until the Hearing Officer issues a
decision, or, if there is a judicial review, until the court issues its final
decision. (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018)
11-11-6: PRELIMINARY HEARING:
Whenever a motor vehicle is seized under the provisions of this chapter, the
owner shall be notified of this provision (preliminary hearing). If the owner
of the motor vehicle seized under the provisions of this chapter requests a
preliminary hearing within twelve (12) hours after the seizure of the motor
vehicle, a Hearing Officer of the City must conduct a preliminary hearing
within seventy two (72) business hours after the request for preliminary
hearing is received by the City; not including Saturdays, Sundays, or legal
holidays. For the purposes of this section, the following shall apply:
   A.   All interested persons will be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the preliminary hearing.
   B.   The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the hearing, and hearsay
testimony will be allowed and will be admissible.
   C.   If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the Hearing Officer determines
that there is probable cause to believe that the vehicle was used as
hereinabove provided in section
11-11-2 of this chapter, the Hearing Officer shall order the continued
impoundment of the vehicle unless the owner of the vehicle posts a cash bond
with the City in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus the towing
and storage costs.
   D.   If the Hearing Officer determines that there is not probable cause to
believe that the vehicle was used as hereinabove provided in section
11-11-2 of this chapter, the motor vehicle will be returned to the owner of
record without any penalty or other costs, and the City will be responsible for
towing and storage fees. (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018)
11-11-7: OWNER'S HEARING:
Within ten (10) days of the vehicle's impoundment, the City shall notify the
owner of record (at the address of the owner as it appears on the record of the
Secretary of State of Illinois) by certified mail, return receipt requested,
and first class mail, postage prepaid, of his/her right to a full hearing
before the Hearing Officer to determine whether the subject vehicle is eligible
for impoundment; and that, in the event the owner of record would like a
hearing, he/she must file a request for such hearing in writing with the City
of Marquette Heights within fifteen (15) days of the posted date of the notice.
If a written request is not received within fifteen (15) days of the mailing
notice, then the owner is defaulted, and the impoundment fee will be kept by
the City or, if no fee is posted, then the vehicle may be sold as abandoned
thirty (30) days after the default. For purposes of this section, the following
shall apply to the owner's hearing:
   A.   Unless continued by order of the Hearing Officer, the hearing shall be
held within thirty (30) days after a request for hearing is received by the
City.
   B.   All interested persons will be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the owner's hearing.
   C.   If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the Hearing Officer determines
by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was used as hereinabove
provided in section
11-11-2 of this chapter, the Hearing Officer shall order the continued
impoundment of the vehicle until the owner of the vehicle pays to the City a
penalty in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus the towing and
storage costs. The penalty shall be a debt due to the City.
   D.   If the Hearing Officer determines that the vehicle was not used as
hereinabove provided in section
11-11-2 of this chapter, the motor vehicle will be returned to the owner of
record without any penalty or other costs, and the City shall be responsible
for the cost of towing and storage. If a cash bond had previously been posted,
the cash bond shall be returned.
   E.   If the owner of record fails to appear at the hearing, the Hearing
Officer shall enter an order of default in favor of the City, which shall
require the payment to the City of an administrative penalty of five hundred
dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018)
11-11-8: UNCLAIMED VEHICLES:
If the administrative penalty and applicable towing and storage fees are not
paid within thirty (30) days after the expiration of time in which the
administrative review of the Hearing Officer's determination may be sought, or
within thirty (30) days after an action seeking administrative review has been
resolved in favor of the City, whichever is applicable, the vehicle shall be
deemed unclaimed and shall be disposed of in the manner provided by law for the
disposition of unclaimed vehicles under the Illinois Vehicle Code. (Ord. 875,
4-23-2018)
11-11-9: LIABILITY OF PENALTY AND COSTS:
The owner of record of a motor vehicle that is seized or impounded shall be
liable to the City for a penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00), in addition
to any fees for the towing and storage of the motor vehicle. Fees for towing
and storage are established by the towing company, and not by the City. The
penalty is to be paid to the City, and all towing and storage costs are paid to
the towing company. (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018)
11-11-10: HEARING OFFICER:
The Hearing Officer shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent
of the City Council. The Hearing Officer shall be an attorney licensed to
practice law in the State of Illinois for a minimum of three (3) years next
preceding the date of his appointment. (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018)
11-11-11: DECISION REVIEW:
Any party aggrieved by a final decision of the Hearing Officer may appeal that
decision pursuant to the provision of the Illinois Administrative Review Act 1
. (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018)
 
Notes
1 1. 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.
11-11-12: VEHICLE POSSESSION:
Except as otherwise provided by law, no owner, lien holder or other person
shall be legally entitled to take possession of a vehicle impounded under this
chapter until the bond and towing and storage costs are paid or the
administrative penalty and fees applicable under this chapter have been paid.
Whenever a person with a lien of record against an impounded vehicle has
commenced proceedings to repossess the vehicle, possession of the vehicle shall
be given to that person if he/she agrees in writing to pay the City from the
proceedings of the sale of the vehicle the administrative fee, plus applicable
towing and storage costs. (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018)
11-11-13: SPECIAL ACCOUNT FOR FUNDS:
All bonds, fines, and fees associated with the seizure and impounding of
vehicles pursuant to this chapter shall be deposited into Police Department
account 01-00-1150 - seized assets. (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018)
11-11-14: PARTIAL INVALIDITY/SAVING CLAUSE:
The provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to be separable, and the
invalidity of any portion of this chapter shall not affect the validity of the
remainder. This chapter shall not be construed to repeal any former ordinance
or resolution of the City of Marquette Heights. (Ord. 875, 4-23-2018)
